review:
《尼姆巴图 - 太空无人机建造商》
最初是被宣传片吸引的，很早就买了现在才通关，emmm···
非常棒的2D太空飞船+无人机建造模拟探险游戏！还有任务！！
可破坏地形，各种怪物和关卡收集要素

玩过单机的简单生存模式就舒服了，至于程序员模式！？想想还是算了
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3214235813
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3214236289
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3203990798

基础教程包括移动战斗资源收集等要素。
高级教程包含逻辑控制，传感器，自动无人机要素。

···至少通关简单的生存模式不需要特别复杂特别大的飞行器···

剧情流水账
[spoiler] 开局生存模式，简单+教程模式。
玩家操纵着Nimbatus（尼姆巴图），最大的移动无人机工厂前往太空探险。

没开出去多久玩家的飞船报警器就响起来了，并被科尔公司的白色飞行器攻击，玩家的飞行器的跳跃加速驱动装置被对方切断抢走了···

玩家被困在一个未知太阳系，开局，建设无人机探索小行星，收集奖励，找到黑匣子最后通过虫洞实现宇宙穿梭。

在前往Nicaese机库的时候又被科尔公司的飞船攻击了，不过玩家再次逃脱了···（说好的最大的移动无人机工厂呢！？所以对比科尔公司这最大也很小！？）

到达机库使用仅有的红色矿石修复Nimbatus船体并通过星系末端的虫洞进入下个星系。

此时可以选择舰长！最后一个程序猿选项是给真正的无人操控无人机用的···
武器工坊只有程序员难度才能解锁

通过虫洞离开就算逃离科尔公司的威胁。

正式开局，重新造一个小无人机。

探索新星球球，挖矿，做任务，买装备升级。

每次移动探索都要消耗黄矿。红矿可以升级飞船和购买装备。
飞船自身也有完整性数值，当数值为0就GameOver了。
威胁度的定义，每次探索移动都会上升威胁度，当威胁度快满了科尔公司就会强行给玩家来一发降低威胁度！
各个星系有各种商店和机库，可以对飞船进行保养升级，商店能购买各种零件来升级无人机！
在武器DC使用2个武器随机生成一个更强武器。

穿梭星球的时候还会遇到随机事件。比如：
遇到求救信号，可能获取资源或遇到陷阱
遇到海盗要资源否则给科尔公司告密
遇到科尔公司的飞船攻击
遇到很厚的星云降低威胁度

穿梭虫洞的时候会获得随机技能升级，还能降低威胁度。

进入任务也会出现随机情况，比如：
遇到科尔公司的自爆无人机（降低耐久度）

任务多种多样，比如：
找到黑匣子（靠近会有提示）
回收冻结器（碰到会冻结无人机，要加热）
捕获冰霜虹鱼（鱼会跟着你走）
捕获岩石虹鱼（鱼会跟着你走）
捕捉萤火虫群（萤火虫会冲到你身边，萤火虫会导致设备过热燃烧，需要冷却器）
摧毁科尔公司的实验室（实验室边上有敌人，还要干掉电厂来关闭防护罩）
摧毁科尔公司的信号发射器（发射器边上有敌人）
摧毁大型蜂巢（有各种小蜜蜂）
摧毁蛇蛋（有无敌的大蛇）
摧毁爆炸虫巢穴（有爆炸虫）
摧毁跳鱼巢穴（有角的吸气喷气的跳鱼）
摧毁海盗部署的地雷（地雷炸的远，建议用狙击炮）
摧毁冰霜乌龟的巢穴（有冰霜乌龟）
摧毁冷冻炸弹（就是冰霜乌龟的巢穴，在周围停留久了会变冰块）
消灭爆炸虫女王（无脑打怪）
回收桶装生化毒药（无脑回收）
取回过热容器（需要降温设备，冷却器要再磁铁边上，否则没多久磁铁就融化了）
冻结熔岩喷泉（使用冷却器把像火山一样的喷岩浆的冻住就好）
收集遗物（需要点燃星球表面火炬，之后金字塔的生米物品护盾就会解锁）
收集化石（靠近会提示，在地下，需要挖洞）
回收民用研究（限时，而且只能玩一次！注意地雷，建议提前炸掉地雷）
回收冻结器（要加热器，不然就等着变冰棍吧···）
消灭锤头鱼群（打怪）
炸毁熔岩洞（就是炸毁怪物的巢穴）

还有特殊类型任务：
阻止科尔公司的采集操作（不能打怪只能打科尔公司的敌人，还得关闭护罩）
探索古代遗迹消灭黄色蛇怪

通过做任务解锁各类组件配件武器

银河系有1,2,3,4 
在第四个银河系下，你会面对科尔前哨，任务是取回跳跃驱动器，能让玩家回到地球。
取回就算生存模式通关。

~通关后还能继续玩，毕竟是沙盒游戏~
 [/spoiler]

其实打完生存模式就不想玩了，至于多人模式那种···emm···更不想玩了~
···毕竟我的脑子不是特别好使···

~游戏是真的有趣~

review:
Unfortunately I can't recommend Nimbatus despite it having a good foundation.

The huge variety of blocks available in-game are somewhat limited during the campaign as opposed to what is showcased in store page's screenshots, more so when designing larger ship.

Additional blocks are only obtainable through three methods: completing missions (which is RNG dependent and offers low volumes), purchasing them from the shop using rare resources or selecting the Programmer captain at the beginning of the campaign. This grants you an infinite supply of all block types (with a limitation to using only autonomous drones). However, even when going with the final option, creating a more complex ship design becomes far more expensive. Which has a knock on effect with the player burning through resources faster than what is possible to mine during each mission.

Furthermore the missions are incredibly easy with the right parts, especially when using long range weaponry as the AI seems to be too dumb to fight back at greater distances. Sadly, due to the repetitive nature of missions and fairly similar randomly generated worlds, this quickly becomes tedious to play through. Strangely the game was more enjoyable during its early access when there were fewer restrictions on ship designs (i.e as not needing fuel tanks for thrusters).

Regrettably Nimbatus will not be receiving any more updates and based on its current state I don't recommend picking this game up, even when it is on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561199035120242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2129, 'last_played': 1699775987}
review:
Don't buy for solely campaign, story, or survival - campaign is underdeveloped and the other two barely exist in this game. Campaign is boring, repetitive, and lacks complexity. I have not played sandbox or PVP, so can't say much on those.

There's a physics engine? bug that causes some ship builds to be unstable and unusable. Devs have posted building tips but it doesn't look like there will be a complete fix. I've tested and noticed that placing objects directly adjacent to other objects in the grid resolves this instability.

I still love the core concept (block-by-block design) that this game uses, but the campaign isn't much fun approaching midgame. (Haven't tried programmer class captain because it's too sandbox-ish).

review:
这款游戏总的来说是好玩的。自定义建造非常上头，玩家要处理飞船的重心，结构，稳定性等等等等。不同的飞船部件放在不同的地方简直有质的改变。总的来说我推荐大家来试一下这个游戏。
但是让我仔细的玩进去这个游戏，还是有一些不尽人意的地方。鉴于制造组貌似已经停止了更新，也就权当吐槽了。游戏的类型是Roguelike性质，Roguelike有好有坏，但是缺点在这款游戏上体现的淋淋尽致。那就是没有合适的难度曲线，玩家要同时兼顾完成任务和收集资源。但是肉鸽的搭配让完成这两点非常痛苦。玩家设计的舰船受限于材料和资源成本，常常是顾头不顾尾。只能是一次一次试错。但是游戏竟然有回合限制？？！！这要求玩家还要计算自己的血量，资源，材料。在不同行星之间小心的做选择，试错成本极低。
游戏是好玩的，推荐来玩。








---------------------------------------------------
以下是ChatGPT4.0生成内容
---------------------------------------------------


文风：诙谐幽默，夹杂着轻微的讽刺

亲爱的太空建筑大师们，拿好你们的太空帽，固定好安全带，我们即将一同潜入《Nimbatus - The Space Drone Constructor》的宇宙，这个由数字化激情和稍带挫败感的星辰构成的奇妙乐土！

首先，让我们对这个游戏中最亮眼的东西给予高度赞扬：自定义建造功能。哦，伙计们，这可不是你随随便便堆几块乐高的玩意儿。在这里，你将成为一名真正的工程师，考虑飞船的重心、结构和稳定性。一不小心，你的宇宙飞船就可能变成一堆废铁在太空中飘着。部件的摆放和组合能带来革命性的变化，简直就像是太空版的“风水”。

但是，正当你沉浸在将太空船零件拼凑成诗一样的美妙过程中，游戏的Roguelike元素悄悄地爬上了你的背，一不小心，一个“喵喵拳”（这里的“喵喵”是指那些令人捉急的设计决策），你的美好太空梦就此打破。

难度曲线像是被喝醉的火箭科学家设计的，时而平稳，时而陡峭，让你根本摸不着头脑。玩家不得不在完成任务和收集资源之间找到微妙的平衡。而这两者就像是不合时宜的太空舞伴，总是跟你跳反调。你的飞船设计，受限于各种材料和资源成本，往往显得捉襟见肘，仿佛在太空中的生存就得依赖不断的试错与调整。

说到试错，这游戏还有回合限制，这是什么鬼？！在探索未知的宇宙，应对突如其来的陨石雨，还要计算自己的生命值、资源和材料。每次做决策都像是在行星间的赌场里押注，试错的成本高得惊人。

然而，虽然有这些让人咬牙切齿的时刻，游戏整体还是很有趣的。制造组可能已经停止了更新，把我们留在了这片充满挑战的星海荒野。但正是这些“生不逢时”的元素，构成了《Nimbatus》独特的魅力。

所以，亲爱的宇航员们，我还是要推荐大家来玩《Nimbatus - The Space Drone Constructor》。不为别的，就为了那个让人又爱又恨，可以在星际中自由翱翔，构建梦想飞船的无价体验。让我们一起，在这片神秘的宇宙中，找寻那失落的太空诗篇吧！

review:
The reason to like nimbatus is the drone constructing, which is done wery well. The variety of parts allows for many unique and fun designs. Sending your drone down to the planet and watching it do it's work as intended is very satisfying. Overall, the game feels polished.

However, there are some minor and one major issue. I personally play only singleplayer, so the following issues will only apply to singleplayer. The major issue is that the game is quite short. I've finished the survival with all pilots, except the programmer, in a few weeks. After retrieving your warp drive, the game unfortunatelly becomes pretty empty. You keep getting more and more resources to the point, when you don't need to worry about the Corp mothership destroying you as repairing your own is easyand becomes more of a chore. Finding more parts you don't have yet, is helpfull, but mostly it only gives your drone finishing touch. The minor issues include balancing of weapons (for example the granade launcher is hard to use because of its short range and lobing the granades betind a hill takes a long time. Sniper however, deals about the same amount of damage faster, and at longer ranges), balancing of the giant snakes (the ones on reguar planets are way more dangerous, than their temple counterpart), bugs with terrain generation (in the late stages, one in twenty planets has some form of a terrain bug), and a small number of other unremarkable things.

The reason for writing this essey about this game's issues, is to point at them, so that the game becomes even better. I'd really love to see the survival be larger, with more enemies, different kinds of planets, longer stroy, or more structural parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198295248864', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1690881290}
review:
[h1]核心玩法冲突的建造对战游戏[/h1]
不推荐，3块的key入手，但是实在忍不了给个差评。Rogue建造简直是灾难，本来建造就需要很多时间，还要过关，过关尼玛的还要扣资源扣钱，都有模块限制的建造了能不能别那么抠门。
类似的游戏比如Reassembly是自由沙盒（死了可以复活可以随时换设计）、Besiege是关卡拼搭（一关失败不会影响其他关卡）， 然而Nimbatus里集成了两者的缺点，导致游戏深度过高，精通难度过于复杂，就没兴趣了。还不如Cosmoteer，虽然也有问题，但是没有Nimbatus里面自动和手动混杂带来的复杂的进一步上升的难度。
而且敌人直接是一个设定了血量的贴图，和玩家操作的拼搭战舰完全不同，这导致玩家基本没法从敌人身上学习，像在打空气。

author: {'steamid': '76561198802404818', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1690157784}
review:
Good Concept that is mostly blundered by bare bones and uninteresting implementation. The "Campaign" is incredibly bland and uninteresting, and would be far better off with LESS procedural generation, or at least more interesting mission types. The building system is incredibly unstable and everything ends up being shaky under even mild stresses, no matter how you link up the parts. The weapons being upgradable and "procedural" is not a good thing, and adds nothing positive. There's simply not enough polish and content here to be worth 20$, and I got it for 10$ and still feel kind of ripped off. There are so many better options for building games, even in a 2D plane and this game only offers a couple interesting and unique things to the table, which are made uninteresting by uninteresting mission objectives and an uninteresting campaign. I understand that a lot of my review probably comes down to personal preference but what can't be argued is that the content is definitely lacking, and this is only reasonable for a game still in early access.

5/10, would be 2/10 if it werent for the building system being decent (still unpolished as hell)

author: {'steamid': '76561198260235972', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1379, 'last_played': 1666636864}
review:
能自定义无人机来挖矿的游戏还是比较少见的。虽然武器和模组不算太多，但该有的都有，仍有较高的可玩性，可惜没有躲过机械制造类游戏正反馈慢，容易枯燥的通病。
整体体验下来，竞速和无人机对战会更容易产生正反馈，但是生涯模式的任务就显得有点长和枯燥。
建议在生涯中加入跑酷、虫群围攻或AI控制的敌对机械对战等多种玩法和组合，会使生涯有趣很多，而不只是局限于挖矿和完成任务。

review: I played this game for all of 30 minutes and am sorely disappointed.  The most basic thing, controls, don't work.  Your drone always rotates to the left.  If there is any way to fix this I didn't find it in the 20 minutes I spent searching around the internet.  Frankly I shouldn't even have to look.  Debating returning it as I've had it for such a short time.  Thankfully I bought it half-off and only paid ten dollars.  All the same, barely worth even that just based on terrible controls alone.  If a real drone performed this way the company would be bankrupt over night.  Even more of a problem with a virtual one.  Can't be that tough to fix and it seems the dev has abandoned there game two years ago.  I'm assuming most of the positive reviews are fake.

review:
Extremely bad.

Game appears to be more of a beta that was never fleshed out, with only the most basic of mechanics in place.  It frequently stops responding to necessary buttons like mouse wheel or Ctrl while still working fine with others.  It HEAVILY punishes experimentation.  Failing a mission result in both an increase in threat level to retry OR to go somewhere else, which is what kills your mothership (absolutely no way to avoid it!) as well as consuming resources.

Developer appears to have not patched bugs or updated desperately needed QoS fixes that are frequently requested since first release.  They do reply to discussions, but it's always "unfortunately not possible" like some autistic Linux obsessed Stack Overflow troll instead of a game designer.

review:
Al juego solo le falta un workshop de Steam para añadirle mods/contenido al juego. Pues sus principales faltas se arreglarían con eso, por ejemplo, la falta de campañas (la única que hay dura pocos minutos). Sólo con mejorar el tema de la campaña ya daría muchas más horas de diversión al juego, por ejemplo, una campaña enfocada en una guerra contra insectos, otra contra marcianos clásicos... en fin, eso. Otro fallo es poner la elección de comandantes para la nave, es absurdo cuando si NO eliges el último (el de los drones autónomos) te pierdes la mitad del juego...

En definitiva es un juego con muchísima capacidad que no han usado y que aún con este lamentable fallo de los creadores del juego... sigue siendo un juego que te puede dar muchas horas de diversión. Lo recomiendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297930296', 'num_games_owned': 494, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 853, 'last_played': 1679216432}
review:
[h1]有趣的自定义建造和奇怪的生存框架[/h1]
游戏中玩家将成为一个无人机战舰的船长，在宇宙的航行中一边躲避敌人的追杀，一边派出无人机，在各类星球中探索收集资源、完成任务，用以提升战力维持航行直到最终达成目标。

[h1]自定义建造的乐趣[/h1]
游戏最有趣的部分就是无人机的自定义设计的过程了，发挥自己的创意，将推进装置、战斗武器、能源储存装置、护盾生成器、温度控制器、采集设备、资源存储设备、抓取装置等等不同作用的部件拼接在核心上。在蓝图上拼接，为每个部件设定操控的按键，在反复地试错和调整后，一架完全由自己组件的飞船就完成了。
接下来你就将在各种不同的关卡中面临实际的考验。通过关卡后可以获得更多的零件，来更新优化自己的飞船设计，使得飞船能够胜任更多更复杂的星球和关卡目标。在这个过程中，你对于飞船设计的理解也会越来越深入，改进出的飞船也会越来越好。
游戏中还开放了逻辑部件，通过搭配检测部件可以达到自动化操控飞船的效果。自动化前进；自动稳定速度和温度；自动寻找目标；自动攻击敌人等等。但想要实现这些效果非常困难，其中所需的逻辑设计非常复杂，只能说是设计的了这些官方插件支持极小部分的高阶玩家尝试了。

[h1]不同的星球环境与任务目标[/h1]
 在游戏过程中，玩家需要操控飞船穿越星系前往目标地点，在路途中有各种环境的星球。选择星球停留，释放无人机前去完成任务和收集资源，才能获取支撑前进的资源和升级无人机的部件。
不同的星球构造；不同的环境温度；星球上有敌方飞船的或是外星生物的威胁；有不同的矿物或飞船残骸可以回收；有回收目标或是消灭目标。
你可以选择将各种应对不同威胁的部件一起装备上，用一架飞船应对各种不同的挑战，但维护费用和飞船体积就会变大；也可以应对不同的目标设计更加专业精细的飞船，针对性解决问题。
制作组在这方面设计了许多不同的环境因素来考验玩家的飞船，也维持了玩家在持续游玩中的新鲜感。但总的来说设计的不够深，游戏内容大概能维持10小时左右的趣味，作为一个小体量的游戏这样也算可以了。

[h1]与核心玩法相性不合的rougelike生存框架[/h1]
游戏的生存模式模式采用了rougelike的框架：开始时可以选择不同的船长携带不同的天赋和无人机部件开局，如果战舰本体血量值归零或没有资源生产无人机了，在失败条件的威胁下抉择星球路线和无人机耗材平衡就有意义了。

但其实rougelike的框架和游戏核心玩法的自定义建造不符合：
rougelike框架的特点是：每局时间短，玩家可以通过一些随机获得的战斗力加成装备快速提升战斗力，在短小的单局内就能很快地达到战斗力最高的程度，并用关底Boss考验玩家最终的战斗力。在此基础上，每局重新开始、大量差异明显的装备能够提供重复游玩的不一样体验，玩家会根据随机掉落来调整自己的搭配方向以保证最终的战斗力足够，随机性影响玩家决策的同时也让可能性变得更多。

[b]①核心玩法让关卡节奏变慢的同时还带来了“损失厌恶”[/b]
此游戏核心玩法的自定义建造是一个战斗力提升比较缓慢的过程，这不仅在于资源获得的缓慢，也在于战斗力提升的生效过程中新增了一个环节——“建造组合”。在传统的rouguelike模式中，要么是随机掉落装备玩家选择用或不用，或者是同时有几个随机掉落装备玩家选择其中一个用，也就是说这个生效是选择后就即刻生效的。而反观自定义建造的玩法下，在获得装备后还有一个“建造组合”的过程——玩家需要根据无人机具体的设计情况进行搭配，有时甚至需要大幅度调整无人机结构来兼容新的组件，这个时间和决策成本会拖慢整局的节奏，并且会让重新来一局时玩家内心产生“损失原有设计”的“损失厌恶”。你能想象在需要反复重开的游戏中，玩家每次重开都需要体验一下“损失厌恶”吗？

[b]②核心玩法导致单局关卡时间过长[/b]
出于探索各式各样的星球和应对不同任务目标的玩法策略，游戏将很大一部分的资源产出放在了这一块上，是过关要求也是奖励在此表现优异的玩家——游戏内玩家必须通过采集来弥补航行中的消耗，仅仅依靠任务目标的回报是肯定不能支撑游戏继续的。所以玩家需要在每个星球上仔细探索，完成目标的同时还要反复将采集到的资源运送回战舰才行。如果将这个游戏内的一个星球视作传统rouglike中的一个房间的话，此游戏的关卡耗时是5-10倍。一般rouguelike游戏会将一次通关时长控制在1-2小时，而此游戏我通关第一遍至少花了10小时。此游戏生存模式正常难度通关的成就达成率仅在3.2%，这一般是一个游戏最终通关成就的达成率级别，绝不是一个rouglike一局通关的达成率。

[b]③核心玩法不会在随机框架下带来不一样的体验[/b]
整体飞船的设计思路并不会因为新一局的随机而出现巨大的差异：飞船好的标准是比较统一的，具有稳定性、功能性、战斗能力的飞船设计是有一个较为清晰的思路了，并且为了能够自定义建造，每个组件都是独立分开的，组件的先后顺序不影响整体升级，组件之间没有组合搭配这一策略。自定义建造在没有策略构建的需求和随机性差异的情况下，是不能够带来rougelike模式中最重要的“每局的差异性和构建乐趣”。此游戏每局之间的别也就仅在随机的星球和任务目标了，而如上所说，设计的不够深。

或许是制作组已经意识到这个问题了，生存难度很低。游戏虽然很像rouglike的开局并且标签内还有“类Rogue”，但其实普通难度下也生存下去不困难，一次不死通关也是可以的。[u]如果没有失败，上述问题也就不会影响到游玩；但如果一旦失败，就是像是那些“硬核模式”一样，死亡就等于从头再来。[/u]

[h1]总而言之[/h1]
虽然游戏在外部框架上做的非常奇怪，但好在一般不会产生较大负面影响，而且游戏在飞船自定义建造的核心玩法上设计出彩。不过相比起价格，游戏的内容量有些可怜了。[u]仅推荐给喜欢飞船自定义建造的玩家在打折时入手。[/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198076900306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1675725944}
review:
Do you want to play a challenging roguelike game where you have fun building and driving drones?
You'll get just that, except for the fun part. Don't get me wrong, the game can be fun at times, sometimes, maybe.
You see, when you play this game, it's as if you had put together a puzzle, you see that it is complete, but still you can't shake off the feeling that there are pieces missing.
All of the pieces do form to a game, which you can play. But you will get no satisfaction from this activity, as everything is implemented in a way that does not make things challenging to figure out or pull off, but simply to do. The drone constructor is missing huge quality of life features and basic tools to manipulate portions of your drone in an easy manner. The tool tips are missing on certain ship parts. The game tutorial does not explain much apart from making you do the same task with slight variation, on paper this sounds good, but in practice it is annoying and unhelpful in the end. Pretty much everything in this game is made annoying. The "survival" mechanics, the mission failures, the travelling, the droid design, everything is limited in the least fun way possible. It's like playing a game in an excel sheet, and even that might be better thanks to novelty.
Maybe the multiplayer is better? If you have friends to play games with, go play a board game. The fun with your friends will not be improved by this functional demo disguised as a full game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199063306476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 901, 'last_played': 1675530666}
review: This is an amazing game, and has so much potential, but hasn't had an update in almost 2 years. This wouldn't be a problem if the game was mostly complete but it is mostly still barebones with entire tabs of items in sandbox only having 4 or even 3 items and the main story apparently has an ending but just feels like it is just randomly generated.
developer_response:
Hi bobofbillys

Thanks for liking the game :)

I'm not sure if I understand what you mean by "the parts are barebones", as we have 84 different drone parts, which even include logic parts which allow you to create your own mini computers (people have built simple calculators with it). The philosophy was that we provide basic parts from which you can make very complex machinery by yourself. We intentionally did not make tons of "fully featured" parts which do lots of things by themselves.

The game has reached v1.0, and has gotten a few updates afterwards. We consider the game done, so that's why it does not have more updates all this time :)

Yes, the campaign is procedurally generated, so you can replay it several times and have a different experience. We also have different "captains" with different traits which make the campaign feel very different. Especially Programmer vs Researcher vs. the others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077339888', 'num_games_owned': 642, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1670016792}
review:
I really like this game, the building system is fun and intuitive while still allowing for complexity, great game mechanics, I like the art style, and it overall is just a solid game. As a space roguelike, it did give me Faster then Light vibes minus the ship combat, and I really recommend it despite its flaws.

There are a few things holding the game back in my opinion:
Campaign too easy. I won on my first run, and halfway through I had a drone build that I didn't need to change for the rest of the game. Although in the first half it was quite fun iterating drones to fix issues I encountered when doing missions.
Only has a few music tracks.
Missions/Levels/Events are repetitive and too few.

The biggest disappointment was that there are no enemies like the player, as in they are not made of physic-simulated parts you can shoot off and such, but rather they are singular entities. Also a lack of space battles was a disappointment as well.

Despite this, I still do recommend the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027638961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1664595552}
review:
+I enjoyed building drones and doing the little missions but 
-The gameplay felt repetitive over time. (I am still addicted anyway xD)
-After a few hours the music gets repetitive and gets in your head in a bad way.
-Building drones is counter intuitive at first, and even after experienced in it the part selection and re-linking parts is really annoying, particularly when I tried to zoom and had a part selected as the scroll wheel is both used for zooming the view and rotating parts. (Little quirks like these in the building and menu navigation feels unpolished as hell, this game feels like it came out of Early Access before it was polished properly)

The game was still fun for me personally as I like games exactly like this. Haven't beaten it nor tried the hard programmer pilot mode yet.
-I believe most people will have fun but drop the game in just a few hours after the novelty wears off, label it a 2d kerbal space program and never touch this game again. 
My positive recommendation is for builders out there looking for their niche gem.

review: I'd really like to recommend this game on concept, but unless your *only* interested in the the sandbox mode I can't recommend it at this time. There are some interesting mechanics in the building system for sure, like the logic gates and hinges/pistons. But the campaign missions seem to punish you for building large ships, especially if your piloting/controls are poor. This, coupled with a very bare bones in game tutorial and several nonsensical design decisions, makes the campaign an rng slug-fest between you and a game that always seems to have one more "gotcha" mechanic to end your run before you even understand what's happened to you. Has potential, but it's not for me.

review: This game is fantastic, the amount of freedom is unmatched in any other construction game i have ever played, the building is easy enough to get the hang of, and the tutorials are very helpful, the campaign is very short and comparable to sandbox except you find the corp planet and steal back your warp drive, for me this happened in galaxy 4, which i got to in a few hours, and thats all the story you get, other than that its identical to sandbox, except sandbox can have its settings changed and planets edited, unless you change the settings there is no threat of the nimbatus getting blown up and having to restart, and needing to find weopons, and pay to launch drones, you can also get upgrades for free, to make weopons in sandbox you need to go to the workshop, there are also online modes where you fight other players drones. Overall i highly recommend this game to anyone who likes expansive sandbox games and making creative vehicles!

review: I had several gos at it and never lasted very long. What I hoped for and "saw" in the trailers was something akin to Kerbal Space Program. What I found was a builder that seems very finicky (not to be confused with "flexible" or "detailed"), with drones that are ever so annoying to configure and fly. The campaign style, too, simply does not appeal to me. I generally dislike time limits but accept them when the overall gameplay works. But the combination of the campaign, the rewards and builder just doesn't fit together at all. The campaign is forcing you to move forward, the builder stops you from building any momentum - no pun intended. Meanwhile, alll that happens on missions is that... time elapses. You pick up some kit. You pick up some resources. You wipe out space bees, whose only crime was to do as space bees apparently do. Chances are I haven't managed to stick with it for long enough for interesting things to happen, but ... well, that's ultimatley the problem and I'd like to blame the game for that at least a little bit. :) Oh, also, design failures in KSP tended to be much more fun and spectacular than they are here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062538153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1438, 'last_played': 1656297504}
review:
Regretfully, this game could have been so good.

I purchased this during the steam summer sale, because I had been interested in the idea for a while. From the trailers I assumed that it was about going from planet to planet, and lazering through planets to build ever larger drones.

What I got was small drones, and conflicts of interest. I will describe how the campaign gameplay works.
Story: You are the pilot of a self sufficient spaceship that can produce drones. (Sure.)
You get your warp engine stolen by a supposedly evil space corporation and now cant return home (Okay)
You now must do nigh irrelevant tasks on various planets to jump between solar systems so that you can reach wormholes to travel between galaxies to get your warp drive back (What?).

Gameplay: 
I found the gameplay to be frustrating. What I wanted to do was build a drone that would laser through planets while automatically fending off periodic attacks from drones. I expected to collect various resources to fuel the growth of my drone to mine better or faster, or fight better enemies. 

What the game was, was, kill these things, mission accomplished. Or, do this menial task, collect this thing, mission accomplished. At first I just thought I needed to have a drone to kill things, then a drone to bore out the planet for resources but no. Every time you launch a drone to a planet, the planet has reset (except for the valuable resources). I probably wouldn't mind if the structure of the planet reset, but the physical enemies reappearing meant that every drone had to be able to defend itself sufficiently. Therefore all of my drones had the ability to mine resources, and the ability to fight enemies. Once I had that, nothing changed. My weapons got slightly more powerful, I made two variations based on if I needed to be able to cool down the drone or heat it up based on the temperature of the planet, but that was it, I had won. All that was left was inefficiently fighting enemies, and inefficiently removing minerals from the planet. 

Then, there was a 'Destroy the snake eggs' planet. I assumed it was another, 'go here, kill things' then mine away. No, it was kill an egg, run away from a giant space snake that FLIES through land and sky at 100mph. Oh okay, well maybe I can kill it? No. Invincible, fast, flying enemies that deal damage on contact and chase you for 30s after every egg you kill. There is no point to mining, because you cant mine that fast. There is no point in a fancy weapon system since you cant kill it.  You have to have a small, fast ship with like,  one gun so you can hit and run the eggs. But! some of the eggs are underground! 
Anyways I ended up cheesing it by using a component I got that allowed me to just make mini drones that would bore through the planet to eggs and burn them while I ran away.  That wasn't fun.

Oh and on resource collection, all those fancy fukin lazers you see in the trailers? They destroy the resources you try to collect. To harvest resources you have to mine to them, slowly vaccume them up until special material storage components are full, then drive back to your drop ship and unload. Rinse and repeat until you have all the resources because why wouldn't you. "Oh but cant I automate something like that?" you might ask. Nope. It would be incredibly difficult to make a system that automates resource moving from a random point on the map to a designated point. (Not impossible, but not worth the time)

Drone Building:
Pretty reasonable on the small scale. I found it a bit difficult to go beyond 30 or so components. Each component (Thruster, blaster, shielding, mining device, logic gate) is based on keyboard inputs (or 'virtual inputs' but there is no description of how to use those, just that they exist). I found 'driving' the ship around the planet with wasd reasonable. 

Testing drones is pretty difficult. You can basically test it in a void to make sure your driving controls work. But if you are attempting to automate a mission or do something related to thoroughly testing your device its basically impossible. There is a test 'planet' but it cannot be configured to 'simulate' the various types of goals, sizes, or hardnesses. It doesn't have a place to drop off resources, it doesnt even have resources to mine. All you can do is toggle between gravities and air resistances and optionally have a bunch of enemies spawn. During the campaign this means that you have to 'test' by sending drones to the planet, which take resources.

--------------

Anyways:
Graphics: 7/10
Campaign: 4 / 10
Controls / accessibility: 3/10
Multiplayer? Idk maybe I read that there are some exploits, so people probably use those.

author: {'steamid': '76561198960415217', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1709916956}
review:
This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.
developer_response:

For a developer, the biggest compliment and achievement we can get is when our game touches the people and helps them in their lives.

For telling us that Nimbatus helped you this way touches our heart. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

Kind regards,
everyone from the Nimbatus Dev Team

author: {'steamid': '76561198032643719', 'num_games_owned': 1210, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1686, 'last_played': 1649812663}
review:
[code]NIE BÓJMY SIĘ CZYTANIA! DBAJMY O NASZ JĘZYK![/code]

Z radością przyznaję, że gdyby nie ogromna paczka gier dostępna na stronie Humble Bundle, której zakup wspierał finansowo ukraińską stronę w wywołanym przez Rosję konflikcie militarnym, nigdy nie dowiedziałbym się o Nimbatusie.
W ten sposób nie tylko wsparłem sprawę, w którą wierzę, ale również dałem sobie szansę na poznanie kilku growych perełek.

Nimbatus jest jedną z takich perełek i przyciągnął moje zainteresowanie już w pierwszych sekundach przedstawionego mi zwiastuna.

Na czym właściwie polega ta gra?
Zniecierpliwiony tytuł produkcji pospiesznie odpowiada na to pytanie.
Naszym zadaniem jest konstrukcja kosmicznego drona w taki sposób, aby podołał on zadaniom stawianym nam przez grę.

Na starcie decydujemy, w którym z trzech trybów chcemy się bawić.
Jeden z nich, czyli tryb swobodny, daje nam możliwość takiej konstrukcji drona, która jest nieograniczona przez liczbę dostępnych części. Gra wieloosobowa zaś, to rywalizacja pomiędzy graczami, która polega na bezpośredniej walce zbrojnej; na dosłownym przepychaniu się na arenie lub na wyścigach.

Bardziej złożonym i według mnie głównym daniem, jest drugi z głównych trybów, czyli kampania.
W skrócie - wielka, wszechobecna Korporacja, tym razem dobra, bo to my jesteśmy tymi złymi, próbuje zniszczyć nas, kosmicznych piratów, by powstrzymać nasze doszczętne eksploatowanie i niszczenie planet.
Na starcie gry pozbawieni jesteśmy modułu pozwalającego na... zaginanie czasoprzestrzeni? Na skutek tego poruszamy się dość wolno, jak na kosmiczne warunki. W celu odzyskania modułu tworzymy drona, którego wysyłamy do walki i pozyskiwania surowców. Rośniemy w siłę aż do momentu ostatecznego starcia.

Sposób w jaki twórcy zaimplementowali tworzenie dronów jest naprawdę godny podziwu i szerszego opisania.
Do głównego rdzenia doczepiamy kolejne elementy, dbając o jego stabilność.
Musimy wziąć pod uwagę środek ciężkości, ponieważ źle rozłożony, może negatywnie lub krytycznie wpłynąć na sterowność.
Jeżeli chodzi o sterowanie dronem, zależy ono wyłącznie od nas. Każdy silnik przyczepiamy osobno, ukierunkowujemy go w dowolną stronę i przypisujemy pod dowolny przycisk. Nauka latania trochę zajmuje i jest to na starcie całkiem spore wyzwanie. Rodzajów silników jest mnóstwo, bo występują takie o zasilaniu stałym, skokowym, lub odpalanym na zawołanie. I każdy z nich występuje w różnej wersji i posiada zmienne natężenie.
I teraz na podstawie opisu silników, wyobraźcie sobie liczbę możliwych kombinacji, gdy weźmiemy pod uwagę, że doczepiane elementy spełniają funkcje mobilne, zbrojeniowe, zaopatrzeniowe, stabilizacyjne, nawigacyjne, wydobywcze czy obronne.
Silniki, chwytające haki, obciążniki, wyrzutnie rakiet, lasery, miotacze ognia, karabiny plazmowe, wyrzutnie granatów, paralizatory, piły tarczowe, ładunki wybuchowe, karabinki szturmowe, zasobniki z amunicją lub z paliwem, pochłaniacze zasobów, wiertła do podłoża, magnesy, pojemniki na zasoby, powielacze elementów, żyroskopy, wskaźniki prędkości, temperatury i wysokości, radary, ochładzacze lub ogrzewacze systemów czy pola siłowe.
I to gracz decyduje o miejscu ulokowania każdego z elementów, o jego natężeniu i przyciskach, pod które zostanie przypisany.
A uwierzcie mi, że powyżej wypisałem tylko ich pewną część.
Niektóre przedmioty miały tak skomplikowane zastosowanie, że odpuszczałem ich zrozumienie. Mowa tutaj przede wszystkich o konstruowaniu dronów zdalnych, nie wymagających ingerencji gracza. To naprawdę podchodzi pod programowanie.

Jeżeli chodzi o pozostałą treść, Nimbatus potrafi miło zaskoczyć, gdyż planety, wraz z ich florą i fauną, mają swój urok, a paleta jaskrawych kolorów, towarzyszących nam w kosmicznych podbojach dopełnia zachwytu. Gra jest ładna, a po opanowaniu tajników pilotażu i obsługi, potrafi nawet relaksować.

Nimbatus jest grą godną polecenia, lecz większość graczy odbije się od niego, ze względu na wysoki próg wejścia i ogromne zapotrzebowanie na cierpliwość i planowanie działań. Ci jednak, którzy zostaną, będą zachwyceni niepowtarzalnością doświadczeń i wolnością w konstruowaniu.

- Bunshiin.

review:
[b]Nimbatus - хороший косморогалик[/b], навевающий воспоминания о FasterThanLight (и еще с десяток подобных проектов), и просто [b]шикарная песочница[/b] техногаджетов, именуемых дронами.

Относительно рогалика говорить особо нечего: 
летаем по планетам, выполняем миссии, получая в награду компоненты, технологии и ресурсы. Попутно убегаем от корпоратов, жаждущих разобрать ваш Nimbatus на винтики. Миссии довольно разнообразны, планеты (астероиды) генерируются случайным образом (но по шаблону). Дефицит ресурсов в начале и незнание механик смело хоронит первые три-четыре прохождения. Потом становится проще.

Конструктор дронов же - восхитителен. 
Куча компонентов, вариаций, игра с физикой и программированием. Можно создать танк, предающий пеплу любой объект, оказавшийся на его пути. Можно забацать хитрого и быстрого дрона, метко выносящего оппонентов в мир иной с расстояния, либо терминатора, выполняющего задание по тем лекалам, которые вы ему прописали с помощью кучи датчиков и сенсоров. Вариантов множество. 

[i]Сам процесс создания дрона, тестов, ожиданий возлагаемых на него в малознакомом мире Nimbatus пробуждает дух первооткрывательства, а первые неудачи на холодных/горячих планетах разочаровывают по настоящему сильно.[/i]

Несмотря на минусы, я совершенно не пожалел о покупке. Рекомендую хотя бы попробовать.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284731206', 'num_games_owned': 1607, 'num_reviews': 505, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1652684890}
review:
[h1]Nimbatus: The Space Pain Simulator...[/h1]
I play games for enjoyment and fun... not for headaches and ball pain... The gameplay video on the store page looks super fun and it looks like you can zip around the galaxy on your massive death-machine just sucking up resources everywhere you go and handing out large cans of whoop-a$s while you do it... the truth however is that before you get to that stage, you have to do dozens and dozens of hours of grinding and farming. The game is also extremely punishing. There's enemies that you CAN'T destroy or damage, but they can destroy you... the physics in the game is also turned up to 11, when it really doesn't need to be. The devs could have left the physics at a nice 7 or 8 outa 10, but NO, they wanted to turn it to 11 so that the game is even MORE punishing than what it already is. I thought that this was going to be a nice little game where you explore the universe with a tiny ship, gathering resources and building up your ship as you go.... but instead it turned out that it's a game where for the first 5hours of the game, your tiny ship is constantly tea-bagged by bigger enemies and you have to skulk around doing gorilla-tactics to scrounge together enough resources just to afford your next measly upgrade... and if you do that for 30hours or so only THEN you can start doing the stuff they show in the gameplay videos... I honestly wanted to like the game, but it's far too punishing to be enjoyable and far to grindy to be viable (unless you got a spare 50hours lying around... which unfortunately, I don't). Not recommended unless you're the kind of person who actually enjoys games like Dark Souls and Elden Ring.

For more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/
For my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

author: {'steamid': '76561198018680691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 46, 'playtime_at_review': 3964, 'last_played': 1711839168}
review: I want to recommend this game, I really do, but I just can't. It's a fun game, but it has a huge flaw. I got this game for my son and I to play together. We both enjoy very much the drone building aspect of the game. He loves to show me what he's building and talk about different ways to build a drone. I've been focusing more on completing the campaign mode of the game, and had almost completed the second galaxy when I ran into the huge flaw I mentioned this game has...Permadeath. I had no idea this was an aspect of the game. I'd put over 50+ hours into this game so far, and when I died I just assumed I could reload my save and try again. Nope! It was gone. Deleted from the game, along with all of my drone creations. All of my progress and effort wasted. For me as an adult who is somewhat used to this sort of thing it is still really discouraging, but I'm really worried for my son who is just a kid. If his save file gets deleted the way mine was, he is going to be devastated. I'm going to have to try and get him interested in a different game before that happens. Which is a real shame.

review:
I had a really unpleasant time playing this game.  It seems like it would be fun, and ticks all the boxes of games I enjoy.  But when I actually started playing it, it just felt really stressful and unrewarding.

It seems like you are supposed to learn by experimenting and trying things out, but the game punishes you for experimenting and trying things out by having negative consequences for failing.  So maybe instead you are supposed to spend a lot of time planning and testing your build so when it goes live it won't muck up, and guess what the level will have in it?  I'm sure there's a balance of planning and charging in head first that makes it enjoyable to play while you are learning, but I couldn't find it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064101302', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 1022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1648621224}
review:
В Nimbatus - The Space Drone Constructor используется не хитрая механика перемещения по галактикам с небольшой погоней. Задания между галактиками тоже не блещут новизной, что-то притащи, в что-то постреляй. Разработчики пытались сделать акцент на возможности собирать свое НЛО из модулей, но выглядит это как создание сверхсовременного космического молотка для забивания гвоздей (особо продвинутые модели даже сами ищут гвозди), на мой взгляд, разработчикам стоило делать игру более похожую на [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/252470/Space_Pirates_And_Zombies_2/]SPAZ 2[/url]. Думаю, большинству игроков игра наскучит даже быстрей, чем они пройдут её хотя бы раз.

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
— Можно строить всякую дичь
— Интересная механика перегрева и обледенения 
— Можно играть в окне
— Карточки
— Достижения

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
— Геймплей быстро надоедает
— Успешность и комфортность прохождения сильно зависит от того как сгенерируются награды
— Если задержаться надолго в режиме редактирования, есть шанс словить неприятные глюки размещения модулей

review:
this game could be so great but the campaign just has a bunch of mechanics that punish you for not playing perfectly, a threat meter that makes you insta fail if you take 4 too many jumps per system the meter even increses for trying out a new drone on a planet or just having to reset your drone to do keybinding management, this feels like it could have a ton of cool exploration but your punished at it for every turn, and on top of that an integral part of the game forces you to pick one starting class to have access too. not to mention that the campaign punishes you for building more complex of specalized drones too

also co-op campaign with both players being able to choose a unique class would be the best

i am aware that this focuses purly on the campaign, that is bacause creative and competive garbage isnt fun

author: {'steamid': '76561197982818767', 'num_games_owned': 1203, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1628806127}
review:
The main problem I have with this game is its control system ... gravity is generally towards the centre of the map (the planet) while the vehicle you build's orientation to that field changes rather rapidly.  This isn't like the gradual or subtle gravity fields of games like Star Control, where it's easy to orient yourself to the field and your relative (often inverted) movement ... but here it's too sharp.

You will get stuck, jammed into the rock, a lot.  Or find it impossible to escape as you've burrowed too deeply into the rock and now can't get out.

It has a fun video promoting it, but that doesn't reflect the moment to moment gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974715662', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1646074676}
review:
Ah dammit, so close but so far!!!

The drone designer is brilliant, but the missions are stingy, slow, and the campaign relies way too heavily on coin-toss-live-or-die RNG.  (No unobtainium on this planet?  Forget it).  The missions can be fun, but most just feel painfully slow.  Oh, and the videos on the store page?  They're mostly creative, you won't get to build anything that interesting in the campaign.

[i] and it didn't need to be that way.[/i].  A slightly more generous and well flesh out campaign could easily have turned this into a 95% review game, but I guess the devs said 'meh, close enough, release it'.  Alternatively a more "open world" approach would have made more sense (who's paying me for these missions, anyway?!)

Avorion does RNG and spaceship building, and it does it WAY better than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994828332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 524, 'last_played': 1645882466}
review:
In theory it's a nice game but the annoyances outweigh the fun. I say in theory because I didn't progress very far into the game because the UI is abysmal:

- No blueprints, no DRY. You can neither save parts of your design nor copy/paste them into new/other designs. So you're going to  have to repeat yourself a lot and forking doesn't really help with merging some parts of one design into another.

- Zoom and free camera mode are not remembered between missions or different instances of the same mission. Maybe this is a non issue for every pilot but programmer. But I don't play those.

- Annoying warnings about missing key binds even though tags are set (and the fact that you don't have manual control with a programmer pilot)

- The test flight mode is next to useless. You can toggle enemies, gravity and borders but there are no mission targets or containers that you could place yourself. The planet test mode is worse than a real mission but switching to it is just as slow as loading the mission (with almost as many clicks). This really slows down iteration speed. This wouldn't be as bad if there was a manual, but

- There's no manual and descriptions of parts are really bad.
For instance there's the "Impulse Giver" and the "Long Impulse Giver" with the exact same tool tip - the difference is that the former does 10 sec max, whereas the latter does 60 sec. This should be obvious at first glance.
Tool tips for labels that would describe in more than 1 word what it means would suffice but for best immersion I'd like to see a manual in the form of a data sheet.

- Seriously, it's cheap as frack not to include proper documentation and to outsource that labor to the paying customer who's required to scrape together every bit of information on the internet. This is a huge thumbs down in my book.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007498482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1626644741}
review:
Nimbatus is a decent singleplayer game. There's a good framework here. It's pretty neat. I have to say I enjoyed it, then I got bored and uninstalled.

The problem is that this game is not worth $20 unless it is specifically the game you are looking for. It wasn't particularly accessible, nor was it particularly interesting- which is a problem, because the gameplay loop isn't actually good enough to hold itself up on its own unless you find that type of problem solving content interesting. This doesn't scratch the part of my brain that I want my strategy games to scratch, so it did nothing for me. It's unfortunate because there's actually a pretty solid foundation here for a game that has its sights set much higher. That game, sadly, is not Nimbatus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010734079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1642098153}
review:
Do [b]NOT[/b] buy this for the "campaign".

If you have ANY notion of picking this game up for the so-called campaign: don't bother.
It's very short, it has very limited options for what to build, it's very repetitive, it's got some questionable mechanics (for instance: a "heat" system where the big bad INVULNERABLE enemy comes closer to finding you the longer you play), it has next to zero replay value, and it's overall not very rewarding.

IF, on the other hand, you just want to screw around in a bot building sandbox or take part in "drone races", then knock yourself out, you'll have a blast. (probably still get it on sale though, kind of a mile wide-inch deep scenario)

Wish I'd just listened to the other reviews that said the campaign was garbage and skipped this, honestly.

review:
里面需要探索的东西很多，很需要动动脑子（如果要弄自动化的话）。然后就是无脑开山做任务了，竞技那一边感觉一般般吧。
我感觉如果可能会更新的话，可以更新出来以下几个方面：1.更多的任务种类、更长一些的主线（这主线好短啊啊啊）、更多的生物。2.武器种类可以更加丰富一点。3.本人比较希望可以联机刷刷任务，叫上朋友一起开山打怪。4.行星地图可以做大一点，行星地上东西丰富一点，让人有一点探索的欲望。5.渲染可以稍微再优化一下，感觉还比较吃配置（有亿点点发热现象）。6.感觉可以弄个矿物系统，这样游戏会丰富很多。
如果不能更新的话，那上面就是我认为的缺点了。
优点的话，这个游戏还是比较自由的，比如说武器系统，还有可以自己组装飞行器，内容可以说的上丰富......

author: {'steamid': '76561198134270486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 788, 'last_played': 1642124076}
review:
Could have been a good game and nearly is.

I played one game of 'Survival', the campaign mode, on hard, as a Miner. I got bored and stopped. Maybe the Sandbox and Battle modes have more to offer, if that's your kind of thing.

There is some fun gameplay with emergent problem solving somewhat along the lines of the trailer, although I never got anywhere near the scale or complexity shown there. Mostly the missions are very grindy, with very patchy difficulty and loot.

UI is also pretty decent, drones are easy enough to put together and test.

As per the consensus here the story is completely forgettable. The campaign structure and encounters are an extremely minimal ripoff of FTL, without any of the good writing.

Overall it just doesn't really hang together as a game.

review:
This is probably a game that gets really good later on, but the degree of how stingy they are with parts vital to being able to play when you start really removes the enjoyment. It's really hard to like a game when they just refuse to give you the tools you absolutely need to even play. 

On top of which, if you're going to make a game where you have very little agency on getting the pieces you need, you can't dump a player with no health and basic pea-shooter guns into a warzone. Specially not when you increase the difficulty by 20% every time you attempt to play. Having over a 3000% difficulty is extremely unfair, and it's not a shock that it becomes unenjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008966329', 'num_games_owned': 1265, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1638563022}
review:
As of right now in my playthrough, I will have to give this a "not recommended". It has fun sandbox elements, but as a game, it is simply not great.

First of all the positives: The engine is very solid, and it is definitely very possible to build large, over-the-top ships. While this is generally not viable in the actual game, it is welcome as I can see many putting hours and hours of time into the sandbox ship building. The music is also nice, if not a bit repetitive, but the few tracks I have heard didn't get old and I enjoyed the Mass Effecty space synth feel. Mining is fun and bringing back (way too many) ressources is satisfying.

Now the negatives: It is not enough of a game. The balance is completely inexistant with mining and salvaging being so absolutely overpowered that I could buy all the ship upgrades within the first 2 wormholes. Now obviously, the drone parts haven't all been revealed to me just yet, but I have come to the conclusion that this game doesn't have any actual standalone good game design implemented.

All the responsibility is on the player to make the game fun for themselves in the way they build the ship or else the entire game seems to basically boil down to "run away while shooting back". One obvious example is those narwal-looking things. There could have been fun there where the player dodges around them to shoot while it charges forward, but no. They basically just have a constant speed boost and will lock on you completely destroying any chance for you to move around them; you just have to run and shoot back. It wouldn't be so much of a problem if the game introduced literally anything to you prior to experiencing them (by either dying or finding out you don't have the proper equipement) yourself.

Everything is a bullet sponge. It simply takes too long to kill anything from the very beginning. In some cases the enemies are so tanky and spawn so fast that you will be stuck on a planet for half an hour trying to get something done. This mixed with the paragraph above and some stuff you can only shoot at the maximum turret range turns an otherwise lightly boring experience of running and shooting into a mixed bag between very boring and outright obnoxious.

Damage is not shown AT ALL on your ship. How the heck is the player supposed to know when to be careful with, let's say, main thrusters when damage simply doesn't show? Does it repair over time out of combat? We will never know. This means there is not way to know what you are risking. There are no damage numbers so you couldn't even GUESS. So what do you do? You run and shoot back making sure to not get hit at all.

A smaller thing is the cursor just gets lost in the samey backgrounds easily, causing you to miss a lot and instead rely on the shots themselves to adjust your shooting, which is far from perfect due to stuff like gravity and limited range. Why are there not path lines to help with aiming? Isn't that so incredibly obvious? Again, responsibility is on the player to have fun.

There are a slew of other smaller problems like shields being seemingly useless for most enemies, and the lack of pacing and actual difficulty that isn't waiting for something to die since there is no difficulty in the meta-progression

In other words, this "game" is a sandbox. There is not enough of a game here to accompany it. They made all the sandbox elements and then slapped some objectives and a completely broken FTL-like """roguelite""" system on top.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011960908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1638510769}
review:
It's kinda fine. And the price is ok, for what it is.

It has some glaring problems with its drone construction. Especially the sensors, that are WAY to big and clunky. 
Example: You want to make one of your weapons to act on it's own. For this you need at least 5 fields worth of sensors (A weapon needs a 1x1 field) AND you need a motorized hinge for the Weapon to turn, because SOMEHOW the weapon can turn on its own, when its set to aim where your mouse is, but losses this ability as soon, as you want to automate it ...

And this Problem keeps escalating... With more complex autonomous drones, needing ever more sensors, for which you need space, which makes the drone clunky, for which you need more boosters .. and now your drone is pretty big and you need to put armor around it, which makes it even clunkier ...

But i STILL would recommend it, because it's a cheap and fun little game. But don't expect it to be a creative drone builder. Especially not for autonomous drones.

review:

스타바운드 하면서 우주여행하는 맛이 있었는데, 나름 우주여행 하는 맛이 있음.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979579620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1637298717}
review:
I've barely scratched the surface in my few hours but this appears to be a game with great depth, huge replay value, and a really interesting take on multiplayer. 

The ship building is pretty fun at its base but with the interesting upgrade system and even just the half dozen weapons I've seen so far, I can imagine some really awesome, crazy possibilities and I'm sure there are loads that haven't crossed my mind (plus all the weapons I haven't seen yet).

There are also 6 characters (at least, at the time of writing) which all have a unique starting load-out and a unique playstyle based on what's equivalent to a trait or passive in most games. Not sure what they call it here. It actually influences gameplay pretty dramatically too - you're not pigeon-holed into any single thing when choosing, but it really benefits you to play a certain style (like a scientist probably won't have the same priorities as a soldier, and you can feel it in the gameplay)

Anyway like I said I've only played a few hours, haven't even looked at automation yet, but I can already tell this game is really well made and has loads of interesting content to be enjoyed, especially for the low price tag.

That said, while I doubt many would expect a huge narrative, there isn't much of a plot, so there's that to consider - the IS a campaign of sorts in the Survival mode, which really gives me Faster Than Light vibes, and there ARE some random events like in FTL where you can choose one of multiple options (only seen binary choices so far, maybe some events have more) and I think that alone is worth the asking price. There's also a sandbox mode and multiplayer, but I won't talk about those because I haven't played them yet.

Would highly recommend if you like building stuff (simple enough for people who don't usually play that type of game like myself, but it feels like there's enough to use / combine to satisfy more experienced players - not the most complex I've seen, but with ship automation quite a bit of depth and interesting possibilities), and/or if you like 2D space combat with ship parts having individual HP instead of one "hull" HP and thats it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960610419', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 4298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4298, 'last_played': 1595781964}
review:
Sadly Nimbatus has been [b]abandoned[/b]. 
There is no activty on the forums on their site about 1.2. The subreddit seems to be heavily moderated and doesn't allow posts about updates or activity.

You can really enjoy the game how it is, but after 20 hours you've seen everything. After that you can play around with the game engine and break things for fun.

Today Stray Fawn Studio send an newsletter, about their history and how great "The Wandering Village" (their new game) is. Also they merged all their newsletters into one. I unsubscribed, since I don't expect to hear anything about a Nimbatus update and I don't care about "The Wandering Village".

author: {'steamid': '76561198029101373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1635166908}
review:
This game has potential, but it's constantly thwarting itself with terrible game design choices, and as updates have stopped that'll never be fixed.

Logic parts are necessary for building anything interesting. But they'll make a drone vastly bulkier and more expensive, because all parts cost the same to deploy and for some reason a single logic gate is twice as big as most parts.
Even just optimising a drone's steering to use pivoting thruster blocks required 6 logic gates, which added a huge amount of bulk to what would be a neat, sleek design.

You can't build anything cool when you start the campaign, because you're given the bare minimum.
Also, for some reason the campaign rushes you along unnecessarily, it's pretty much the same exploration rules as FTL but very badly misapplied.

The gameplay loop is so boring that I wanted to stop after just a couple of missions that were only a few minutes long (almost all of my time played is in the editor), the missions you're given are very boring and also you're encouraged to spend ages mining since it's a roguelite, and one thing that's always true about roguelites is that if you don't get as many resources as possible early on you're gonna have compounding issues later on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066340898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1627526027}
review:
The actual drone-building is fairly neat- It's complex enough to allow for some pretty cool designs, but simple enough to actually let you build stuff without being an engineer.

Unfortunately the game (as a game and not a drone designer) is a little lacking in content. It's not terrible, and there are definitely worse things you could spend your money on, but there's not as much as I'd hoped to actually do with your drones. The main mode of the game is a roguelike with randomly-generated missions from a selection of possibilities, and randomly generated planets. The long-term gameplay is reminiscent of FTL, but simply not as fun. Like I said, it's not terrible, but I honestly would have preferred a selection of hand-crafted missions to test my problem-solving-drone-construction skills.

As mentioned, the main mode is a roguelike, which is somewhat disappointing compared to the alternative, but also quite frustrating for another reason- You restart the game when you die, as per roguelike standards. While this normally isn't an inherent issue, it is here. You lose three major things when you die:
1. Your progress. Not really a problem. This isn't notably different here than it is in most roguelikes.
2. Your parts. Irritating, and very problematic for reasons tied in with #3.
3. If you didn't export them, your drone schematics. (As in the ones you designed in the drone editor.) This is extremely frustrating for anyone who isn't really interested in repeatedly creating schematics from ever-changing random assortments of parts. Each new game erases your drone designs (or if you did export them, "only" renders them useless unless you happen to collect the same parts again), meaning that the time and effort spent on those designs goes down the drain. (Unless you want to use them in the creative mode, but I'm not really sure why you'd use designs based on limited parts there.) There are skills to learn when it comes to drone design, sure, but I found designing slightly different drones for the same purposes each new run to be just tedious.

As I see it, the game could have been a lot better if it had been designed as a series of challenges rather than a roguelike. Given the downsides that the roguelike core design introduces in a game about building things, I'm somewhat confused as how to this was the core design that was decided upon.

While I wouldn't recommend the game overall, it isn't without its merits. As stated, the designer itself is good, and the campaign is not offensively bad, generally disappointing at worst, and not without some fun moments. There are also, of course, modes to freely design drones as you wish, and an option to avoid losing your drone plans upon dying in the campaign. I do appreciate this option, but the loss of those plans is unpleasant enough that I don't understand why it's the default for the game and not some sort of "hardcore" option, if not entirely removed.

If you're still interested in the game after reading this, you might as well give it a shot. It's definitely flawed, but perhaps if you like the concept enough you'll get more out of it than I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086846794', 'num_games_owned': 1190, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1634077259}
review:
Feels pretty unique. While the 'survival mode' is reminiscent of FTL, gameplay is quite different since the focus is on building specialized drones to complete a variety of different mission types. And while you normally control the drone yourself in a way somewhat similar to Asteroids, it's also possible to play using automated drones that follow a set of predefined rules. Quite fascinating really.

The destructive terrain and the elemental weapon types also reminded me a bit of Noita. There appears to be a similar amount of stuff to try and experiment with.

The only negatives are that it's not always easy to figure out how ship components work or what they actually do. That, and random missions that are almost impossible to beat because you're missing some vital component, but that's rogue-like games for you.

review:
There's a lot I do like about this game, and I think it's worth a few hours of fun, maybe get it on sale.

I think the issue that really holds it back for me is the imbalance between the two main resources in the game. Tritium is abundant and nearly useless. Unobtanium is rare, used for everything, and a few random events can have you frustratingly treading water, unable to upgrade while you spend all your resources to repair.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228980436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6413, 'last_played': 1632710024}
review:
Nimbatus is amazing! But beware, you need to heat up your brain to think of ways of improving your drones with what you get along the way, the resources available, the mission, your capability of control and so on!

The best thing about this game is the rewarding sensation of "a-ha" when you mange to build something more efficient/stronger/faster/smart, and you feel like your creative effort is paying off. 

It get's quite scary depending on the captain you choose and your ship integrity is getting awfully low xD but if you play carefully and plan ahead what you are doing with your resources, you will get better and better. In the end you will end up having dedicated drones for each type of mission. 

Also, it's awesome when you start unlocking the logic circuits.. it adds a whole new dimension of complexity and opportunities to enhance the control of your drone and do things more automatically.

On top of everything, there's the multiplayer tournament modes, which are incredibly fun! After finishing the 'story' mode I found myself challenged by the interesting tournaments. Other players are very smart with their drones and you learn a lot just by competing over and over!

Great job developers! If I were to improve something in the game though I would add more variety to the planets in the story mode, after a while it can get a bit repetitive, and only because we can keep improving our drones it didn't get boring. Another thing that I found cumbersome at times was not being able to save the weapon upgrades choice PER DRONE to avoid let's say changing back and forth every laser from digging-focused to pulling-focused. 

Overall: 9.5/10. Definitely worth buying if you like creating stuff and controlling it

author: {'steamid': '76561199072070318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 7084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4846, 'last_played': 1688616027}
review:
工程师船长-完成生存模式，居然只有1.2%的玩家获得，请留言大家是怎么通关的？
留一下通关心得，无线传输-用分离器带2个以上矿箱速度快＋燃料和电池+逻辑控制，全扔进黄色回收箱。
1、固定方向左右收集器两个，固定向前收集器两个，共4个（安在飞行器前进方向的两角处）。一个开关控制。
2、飞行器的移动方向上，看重心，严格遵守杠杆原理-“给我一个支点我能撬动飞船”。前进，对称即可.(前进手动和开关同时控制）。
3、火力只需力大出奇迹，具体：分单发和连射两种。单发，求精准，鼠标左键，推荐：我是装了16把狙击，200乘以16=3200，大部分一刀切：连射，求范围，攻速，鼠标右键，推荐：8把动能枪，8把榴弹炮，加上一个开关，右键开启。（这里说一下榴弹炮，要比火箭弹，和喷射器都好用，使用时候要从上向下攻击，榴弹炮伤害最高适合持续攻击，火箭弹-命中低-速度慢-近距离开火不实用，榴弹炮还有就是挖掘效果优秀-挖的干净，喷射器和激光有时有小碎块）
4、最后-生存模式重要一点，开局优先150红水晶直接买，，，星球小地图，小地图，小地图，能看见星球矿脉位置。
工程师优点在于，不用往复运矿到回收箱，无线，（当遇到500+红水晶的时候，拉）。飞船轻。
以上的所有，所有，都是我疼痛总结！
祝大家玩的愉快。

author: {'steamid': '76561198254037773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1688039983}
review:
Pros:
·Nice gameplay once you get to understand some physics involved in it.
(i've seen streamers play the game without using any logic and thus having a bad experience when playing with their drones...why would you even stream that?)
·(Subjective) Very nice music that puts the game to another level of inmertion!
·Procedurally generated universe with different rewards on different planets with differents ammounts of resources even on story mode (It seems that the tier of the rewards still depends on the different stage you have reached in the game,tho...)
·You get to see the difference in your progress with each new part you get to add to your drone even mid game when you just got another of the same part you had already,it still gives you quite an improvement,especially thrusters.
·Even if its very slow paced,especially in the first or second group of stars,its not grindy but rather satisfying to play and advance to the next mission or group of stars.
·It requieres knowledge and logic,not just a "take this ship,buy this upgrades,go destroy NPCs" type of game you normally encounter but rather,you create your own with each individual part and their upgraded versions.

Cons:
·About the physics involved in the game that i mentioned in the pros,while the gameplay its nice,they get some concepts quite wrong and while this might be ok since its a videogame,there are quite a few of those concepts that botters me a lot:
1.Fuel in fuel tanks regenerate on its own from nothing,i think you should have to go to the mothership and get more fuel after you run out of it and/or mine it from the planet you're at or use energy from batteries instead of fuel with other types of movement parts alongside the different types of thrusters.
2.Speaking of batteries...they regenerate electricity from nothing just like fuel tanks regenerate fuel...it would make more sense to have power generators for the batteries or solar panels or whatever...
3.It costs nothing to move from a planet,star or group of stars to another but it costs a set ammount of one of the two currencies in the game to deploy your drone depending on the number of parts the drone has(the other currency is for buying parts and upgrades,as well as repair the hull of the mothership)...so it costs nothing to get to another planet and orbit around it but it costs you something for deploying the drone from orbit to the actual planet.
·Well,in reality it costs you something to move around in the universe,kind of...there is "threat" wich goes from 0 to 100%;each time you travel it increases and the closer you are to 100% is more probable that "the corporation" finds you and destroy 1/5 of the hull of your spaceship...but then they let you go withouth even trying to destroy you even if that seems to be their objective O_O (you lose like 20% threat).And it happens again when you get close to 100%
Damn,those guys from "the corporation" are bad at chasing you but when they do they make sure to destroy just 1/5 of your hull max durability -_-
·You can't have icemantas as pets following you around;that can only be archieved on an ice planet and you could accidentally kill them when dealing with other enemies.
·Some missions require you to kill icemantas or other type of mantas with the overpopulation excuse...

author: {'steamid': '76561198171882882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 2012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1630330693}
review:
Negative review because trying to program a bloody drone AI is hard enough as it is using only freakin logic gates, but when combined with the increase in size, weight and wobble, the fact that you can't test anything in TEST FLIGHT because it spawns a horde of enemies, is missing things you only find on planets, most of the sensors are either badly implemented, useless or complete garbage ... and logic gates don't even function as logic gates... for example, a XOR gate only functions if it's connected to both inputs... as in ... it has to receive !input1 and input2 ... if input1 is missing entirely, it doesn't work.

Drone programming in space engineers is less of a pain in the ass ... and that's saying a lot.
developer_response:
Hi Evernight

Thank you for your feedback. Some of the things you mentioned are intentionally designed this way (the logic blocks physically in the world, bigger drones = more difficult to build/control / logic being a bit flimsy and can be destroyed for unexpected behavior). I'm sorry that those hinder you to have fun or are annoying.

Other things which are you mentioned have a solution ingame. If those aren't signaled clearly enough ingame, we have to improve that. I hope those tips help you out a bit:

- In the Test-drive you can turn off "spawning enemies" with a button at the top
- As the programmer captain you don't have deploy cost, so you can infinitely "test-drive" on the planet directly. It has longer load time than the test-drive, but that's a technical limitation we can't change.
- Logic parts are per default "wireless" or "global". This means you can detach all logic-parts from your drone and your logic still works. This way you can have complex logic without having to carry it around with your drone. During this time it is defenseless, so you have to either add shields or put them into your container or on top of the Nimbatus :) Or add self-aiming weaponry.

The XOR *should* work in a way, that if you don't bind a signal/key to an Input, it should just permanently input "0". If that's not the case then it's a bug. I'll post it on our investigate list. Thanks for mentioning it.

I hope those tips help you a bit with the things you mentioned in your review. Let me know if those helped or if you have some suggestions on how we can improve the game.

Thank you and cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198149729328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1630080704}
review:
Okay, I basically started this game 15 times by now even though I've only got an effective playtime of 28 Minutes.
Every time I am inside this damn Drone Creation Menu and go into a test flight, I try to exit and get back to the editor by pressing Alt+F4.... I know.... I can't seem to learn it anytime soon.

My excuse for this is as follows: I am a programmer. Whenever I edit something and debug/test it, I exit with Alt+F4. As the Drone-Editing Menu is reminding me of that, I intuitively try to get back to editing the drone the same way as I do when programming....

It's really annoying, but completely my fault........

Edit: After 7,5 Hours I learned it! I can now peacefully edit Drones without restarting my games!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009788028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1629497841}
review: Ispirato ad Atari's Lunar Lander, e vabbè solo per questo meriterebbe attenzione. Modalità sopravvivenza e sandbox procedurali, ogni partita è diversa dalle altre, ha un tutorial abbastanza semplice (almeno per me lo è stato). Il gioco è semplice: raccogli risorse facendo missioni o raccogliendole materialmente, dovremmo costruirci una navicella che aggiorneremo ad ogni missione mettendo e togliendo pezzi, aggiorniamo sia abilità che equipaggiamento, e per far questo dovremmo esplorare sitemi solari su sistemi solari in cerca di risorse. Forse alla lunga risulta un po' ripetitivo (un po' come tutti i sandbox); le missioni si somigliano un po' troppo tra loro. Difficoltà ben bilanciata, si riesce a proseguire con la storia forse con qualche difficoltà al principio, ma dopo averci preso un po' di mano la difficoltà sembra aumentare in maniera graduale. La parte giocata, cioè quando controlliamo la navicella, somiglia moltissimo ad Atari's Lunar Lander. Fisica arcade ma comunque piacevole. Voto 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198043135631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2248, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1629225597}
review:
This game is mostly great, but it's a little boring.
Constructing various drones is truly a lot of fun.
Beating various missions is also very enjoyable.
The amount of unique missions is simply small.
And so: Eventually it gets a bit repetitive sadly.
Upon beating the story mode: It's kind of meh.
You can replay it with a harder difficulty, yeah.
But there's not much of a reason for doing so.
It's a lot more fun to just jump into free mode.
The main aspect of this game is the creativity.
You can just build some truly amazing drones.
Automated stuff is a bit confusing to get into.
But overall: It's truly a really well made game.
I gained almost ten or so hours of fun from it.
That's why I am gonna give a positive review.
It definitely isn't great for everybody, though.
A huge chunk of people will likely dislike this.

author: {'steamid': '76561199191944958', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1629273802}
review: 很有潜力的游戏，新手教程非常简略，以至于新手造无人机时看到密密麻麻的逻辑门和部件会比较头疼，这是比较劝退的一点。但对于拥有探索精神，创造力，一定的和逻辑思维，知识量的玩家来说，这款游戏能被你玩出花来。在款游戏里，除了经典的探索，制造，对战，你还可以用LED屏来制作像素动画，演奏音乐，制造乐器，制造简单的计算器甚至制作解谜游戏，对战游戏等。总之，撑过前期一无所知的阶段，慢慢探索各部件的妙用，你能发现这款游戏的无限可能。

review: Cud, miód i orzeszki. Jedyna w swoim rodzaju gra w której budujemy kosmiczne drony. Co istotne, ich konstruowanie i programowanie jest proste i intuicyjne. Gra posiada kampanię, ale największą atrakcją jest tryb, w którym wystawiamy zaprojektowane przez nas drony do walki lub zapasów w turnieju przeciw tworom innych graczy. Drony są autonomiczne, ich ruchy oparte są wyłącznie na danych z czujników zbliżeniowych i prostych bramek logicznych. Starcia tych maszyn są chaotyczne, ale też emocjonujące, zwłaszcza jeśli uda się zaprojektować drona skutecznego przeciw wielu różnym taktykom.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073390340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 2804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2804, 'last_played': 1628981105}
review: I really enjoyed this game. It's fun to make drones, watch them explode because you attached too many parts to something, and then go back and do it again and again. Once you get logic gates and sensors is where the real game begins though, being able to make little drones that you can launch from your main drone that self-seek enemies or other things is really neat. Or using the factory part to build torpedos that detonate when they get near something, it's pretty fun and great. You'll easily get a solid 40 hours out of learning how to use different parts and getting closer and closer to reaching the final planet in the 4th galaxy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998910233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1628794737}
review:
Pretty fun game, but one big problem that I can't believe hasn't been fixed. You can't zoom out in this game. At first I thought the zoom was fine. But when you get better weapons that have more range (there are even "sniper weapons.") You need to be able to see farther to be able to use them as sniper weapons instead of a general I will shoot in that direction and hope it hits because they were last seen in that direction kind of thing. 
It goes beyond sniper weapons though, say you want to build a ship that goes really fast, but you want to see far enough ahead to be able to turn properly. How would you do this with such a zoomed in camera? You can't without just slowing down instead...

But! Once that whole camera zoom being too close thing is fixed, I will change my review!
