author: {'steamid': '76561198090176036', 'num_games_owned': 3658, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1628451523}
review:
Так и хочется сравнить эту игру с другой под названием "Reassembly". 
По сравнению с Reassembly тут:
- Неудобное управление кораблём.
- Намного хуже реализовано строительство.
- Убогая боевая система (минимум движухи).
- Неудобная миникарта по которой трудно ориентироваться. 

Не хватает описание к деталям (для чего нужна та или иная делать - угадай сам).
Местами нечитабельный мелкий текст.
Больше всего в игре борешься не с противником, а с гравитацией, постоянным застреванием в земле, проблемами когда отстрелят нужную часть корабля.

★☆☆☆☆ (1/5)

author: {'steamid': '76561197979792028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1628250823}
review:
My first ten minutes involved trying and failing to figure out how to attach all the thrusters I needed without having my drone spin wildly in place. I dont see this game paying dividends on learning how the systems work. The graphics are a mixed affair, with some of the designs looking quite crisp and cartoon like, while others look like cheap flash animation with too-clean lines and simple geometric shapes. 

I love the premise, but I dont think the tutorial does a great job of explaining how to design your drone. I wish it was more like Banjo Nuts and Bolts, where any old garbage you make still ends up working. This game has very clear definitions of what will fly, and what will just spin around in a circle before crashing. Not my cup of tea

author: {'steamid': '76561197997973214', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1697978099}
review:
Bought this game expecting a Reassembly clone to some extent... I was right but I was also VERY wrong.

This has some awesome game modes that set it apart from Reassembly. Although I have to say I miss the open environment of Reassembly. The campaign plays sort of like Besiege, crossed with FTL. Which is pretty fun. There is a neat captain selection that offers up unique challenges for varying play-styles. 

The building is quite different than that of Reassembly, providing a bit more depth and freedom without the different factions, parts don't have to be touching but instead connections are formed between bodies using struts. Plus there is a whole other layer of creation to dive into: Automation. You can also alter the appearance model of each part you choose (with some fine-tuning), although I'd just like to change the colours like in Reassembly..

This game gets a HUGE thumbs up for the automatic drone racing/battles competitive building game mode. It's something truly unique and makes me feel like a kid again. I just loved tweaking my designs and watching them tear around the race track. So cool. (To get started in this mode I suggest watching the advanced tutorials) Although I would like to see implemented: different "weight classes", matching drones roughly based on number of parts--as sometimes you get put up against some absolute monsters which are in a league of their own really.

I got Nimbatus on sale but wouldn't be complaining if I played full price. 

8/10 
-I find myself wishing the campaign environments we're a little more realistic/detailed and thoughtfully implemented
-I'd like to see more of a focus on the space-combat in the campaign

If you like this game you should absolutely play Reassembly, and vice versa, if you like Reassembly, you're going to enjoy this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970761123', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 904, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1651995017}
review:
This game is currently in the Humble Bundle for July 2021. If you are interested in the game and it's before August 3rd, 2021, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

This is a creative game where players can create and pilot drones to complete different tasks.  Add in an FTL-style race across the galaxy and a series of missions where players will be tasked to do different things and you have a really interesting game. 

The game starts with players having to create and try out different drones to complete various tasks, and there’s a lot of different ways players can build their drones, and a few ways that will break them apart, but there seems to be a lot of potential in the design aspects of the game.

But there’s also a threatening enemy that constantly will be chasing the player’s ship and trying to damage them, as well as a couple of resources that players will need to balance to pay for repairs and upgrades.  There are also multiple starting classes, with unique loadouts, gear, and abilities.  I’m particularly tempted to return to try out the programmer class which requires autonomous drones only, which the player can’t manually control. 

Pick this up if you like the idea of creating drones and completing missions.  It’ll help if you’re a fan of rogue-lites but might not be fully necessary.  There is still a lot of replayability here.   If you just want to skip the design phase you might have issues here as a big part of this game appears to be building your drone fleet for your current task and then piloting them. 

If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my youtube channel: https://youtu.be/UqdMreTnUns

review: This game is not at all what I expected. The store page makes it look like a fun engineering sim where you can gradually build up your drone library with better parts, and progress through a series of interesting challenges. Instead, it's actually a permadeath roguelike that deletes your save on death. The drone building and control system is actually really clever, but there's no way I could enjoy the game knowing one small mistake could erase all my progress. I wish it was more like Kerbal Space Program and less like FTL.
developer_response:
Hi Knockout Mouse

Thank you for the feedback. I see what you mean by disliking the FTL / Rogue-like aspect of the Survival-Mode.

The thing you wished for actually exists in the game, but it's unfortunately hidden away in the sandbox-mode. I'm sorry for this convoluted UI. I made a screenshot of how to setup the Sandbox mode to get the following:

- Get a limited set of parts to start with
- Unlock new parts over time by solving missions
- Gather resources and use them to buy new upgrades and parts
- Play infinitely without anything killing your progress (try and experiment as much as you want)

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2108436858

I hope this mode is exactly what you described / wished for. I would love to hear back from you if this is more fun, so I get data that we can put this mode more in front of players.

Thank you for your help and cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198013400402', 'num_games_owned': 443, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1626029757}
review: This game is too repetitive for me to keep.  It was frustrating to me with the heavy amounts of gravity/physics to where its mostly a trial and error building game.  While I enjoy building games, I didn't like that there isn't a mirror mode in the drone builder.  Personally when I see a game like this and see the word 'drone' I feel that there should be some automation to the game.  While there is, its states in red that its for advanced players.  I was completely mistaken in thinking this game had the ability to create and operate more then a single drone.
developer_response:
Hi timmy,

Thank you very much for your feedback. I see what you mean by being repetitive. In new galaxies there are more missions and new biomes, but the gameplay loop stays the same.

There's a lot of automation in Nimbatus. But in Survival-Mode, as you said, it's recommended that you use the "programmer captain" for it. The reason we say "Warning: advanced players only" is that we had a lot of players trying that captain and then were negatively surprised that you *had* to automate and couldn't control your drone with the keyboard/mouse. If you want to automate *and* control your drone, you should either choose the "engineer captain" or play in Sandbox-Mode.

Seeing that you like builder games in general and are an experienced player, I think the sandbox mode might be right up your alley. You can build crazy stuff right from the start (you have all parts available from the start and no part limits). In this mode you can also automate however you want, build drones which automatically solve the mission for you, and, if you want, you can control certain parts of the drone yourself.

About more than one drone: You can have several drones in a mission if you want. The normal way to do it is add a "decoupler part" and have your "sub-drone" attached to that. If you detach the decoupler, you have a unique drone you can control independently. Or you can also use the "factory part", which is like a 3d printer which prints all parts again, which have been attached to it. So you can create infinitely many sub-drones if you want.

I'm sure we could do a much better job at explaining the charm and endless possibilities of Nimbatus in-game, especially to players like you who are experienced construction-game players.

I hope this answer gave you a bit more info and tips, if you wanted to give the game another try.

Thanky again for your feedback and cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198122670166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1626930202}
review:
It's a little light on content (especially for the roguelike singleplayer mode) but the construction, logic and mission gameplay is rock solid.

Needs real multiplayer though, not asynchronous leaderboard stuff.

3.5/5

Nice things:
- Building is very freeform compared to similar games in the genre: Free placement (excluding intersections and with a range limit, but you can chain blocks) and physics-enabled parts (wheels, springs, pistons, etc.)
- Procedural destruction: Planets are fully excavatable and your drones are destroyed block-by-block. Seeing a drone malfunction after taking some hits to the logic gates is entertaining. (e.g. Self-immolating drone caused by a heater connected to a stuck NOT gate after the thermometer is destroyed).
- Logic blocks have a 'tag' system which allows you to create non-key signals with meaningful names (essentially variables).
- The logic system in general is solid: loads of sensors and logic gates allow for significant automation. There's enough to be turing complete and then some: You could theoretically build a processor and display (using the LEDs) that takes keyboard input directly.
- Freeform difficulty customization, incl. sandbox mode
- Roguelike mode works well, allowing you to retry missions but placing an upper limit on how slowly you can go via limited resources and an accumulating mothership risk/damage stat.
- No hard limit on drone size: A small number of blocks are free, then each block after that costs a small bit of resources.

Not nice things:
- Drones tend to flip out with certain weight configurations. (Always a problem with physics engines, but could be handled more gracefully)
- When mining with lasers, it's easy to get stuck on 1px bits of terrain.

Balance woes:
- All blocks have exactly the same cost: a single logic gate costs the same as a large battery which costs the same as a small battery which costs the same as *a small indicator light*. Somewhat justified since you only have so many of each part, but gets annoying when trying to do moderately complex logic.
- Factory is absolutely broken (but hilarious to play with). It clones any attached blocks for free, including rare blocks like large batteries and supercapacitors (which spawn fully charged too). Making it use up tritium from your total supply would work much better (at a reduced rate, e.g. 1/4 as much as normal drone parts cost but without the initial 10-25 free parts).
- Mortars *suck* to fight against, they'll impact on your shields but the AoE goes through them to take out some of your more vulnerable blocks. Relatively easy to dodge entirely though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268639419', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1624839946}
review:
This game makes drones randomly thrash around and explode even under the parts attached to one piece limit, which gives me the feeling that its actually just a bug and these guys are trying to pretend otherwise by trying to make it seem like a high skill ceiling, and instead just making a construction game be less fun in my opinion. Whatever maybe I'm just bad but i don't really care enough to want to change that.
Whenever it happens ingame (whether or not it should) it always feels incredibly janky, not to mention larger drones having very floppy bones from what I could tell as my small compact drone would just randomly wiggle.
Even aside from that the story was uninteresting: you have been chosen to take this amazing drone ship that's better than everything else yet made by man, out into space for no reaso- I mean because science, and you have now been shot by a spaceship better and bigger than yours, now go to some tiny planets and do some boring missions with boring drones until you refund the game.

Even in the freebuilding mode it was still just dull and janky, I think the only way to enjoy this game is to play little else and force yourself to learn every single thing about it so you can possibly have fun if you enjoy spending eternities on things?
Although, I will admit the weapons customisation tree was very cool and gave me something enjoyable for five minutes (lots of explosions), but not enough to carry this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089009671', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1624045345}
review:
One of the few games I enjoyed so much that I wrote a review immediately after my first session. At first I had my doubts because the game looked extremely complex with the manual keybindings and all the statistics and such. So I thought, [i]"hey its just $20, I'll grab it, try it for 2 hours, and then I can refund it if I don't like it."[/i] 2 hours later, I cannot recommend this game more!

Theres so many different drone parts to make the perfect drone for any given scenario, the progression is solid, interesting rpg-ish travel mechanics where you get random encounters that can help or hinder you based on your choices, enemies are all very unique [b](and I've only seen 4-5 different enemies so that's saying alot),[/b] and its just super fun.

My only single complaint is that for the most part alot of the weapon parts I've found are extremely weak compared to the default gun. So beyond elemental abilities such as the plasma shotgun for fire puzzles I don't see myself using any of these since they're just mildly unique and don't achieve anything the default gun can't.

If you love to nerd out over space physics and micromanaging resources, I'd highly recommend giving Nibatus a spin! If you don't like it you can always refund it, so at least try the tutorials and the first portion of the campaign.

review: I liked this less than I was expecting. author: {'steamid': '76561198051427115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1925, 'last_played': 1622771535}
review:
I really, really wanted to like this... but I can't.

It's buggy. Not the buggiest, but buggy. I experienced instantaneous crashes to desktop multiple times while routinely editing my drones. The UI is a bit finicky and unpolished, too.

The short-term gameplay isn't great. Combat is either trivial (if you have enough speed, weapons, and/or shields) or impossible (if you don't.) Digging through the ground to get to your enemies is a neat option to have, but it tends to be really slow and can leave you helpless if you get the positioning wrong, especially since they can detect you right through the ground beneath them anyway. Enemies tend to have gobs of HP, so the best way to kill them usually involves finding a good camping position and hitting them with long-range weapons over the course of about 10-60 seconds (depending on the enemy.) Short-range weapons, in contrast, are almost useless, except maybe for digging.

Also, some of the first enemies you'll come across are bees, which are the kind of enemy that you swat at over and over again, typically while saying "getoffme getoffme getoffme" louder and louder. Not a good choice.

The long-term gameplay isn't great, either. Most of it involves finding the route through the galaxy that results in the fewest increases to the Roguelite Timer. Grabbing new parts is fun, but not actually all that helpful; you can make a drone at the very start that can handle about 70% of the game on its own. The worst part is that, because every drone you launch costs you in-game resources (with a higher cost for more complex drones, mind you) AND an increase to the Roguelite Timer, the game discourages experimentation when the opposite should be true. If any game suffers from being a roguelite, it's this one.

The game doesn't tell you things you'll really wish you'd known. When you see a new enemy, you will, naturally, be unsure how to react to it. Then it'll shoot you with a cannonball that destroys half your drone, or it'll charge at you and destroy half your drone, or it'll just set your drone on fire...

Even the drone building gets old pretty quickly. After a bit of trial-and-error, you'll probably figure out an intuitive place to put your thrusters, and you won't have many interesting decisions to make after that. Weapon locations? If you have enough range for the weapons to be effective at all, you can usually put them anywhere. Fuel tanks? Batteries? Put them anywhere - all that matters is how many you have. Detachable sub-drones? What a lovely idea... but there's no reason to complicate things, assuming you can kill enemies without them.

The music and graphics are functional, but nothing special. The story is a waste of time.

In short, this game is disappointing on all counts. And that hurts to say. I think a few tweaks here and there could make this into something really awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978640311', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 1273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1623448931}
review:
not a lot of variety,
stupid roadblocks, 
permadeath - one little mistake and you've wasted 20 hours, 
boring and annoying grinding for resources in the beginning as engineer, other classes probably much worse,
terrible way of setting up controls (and logic parts are too huge),
CONSTANTLY getting stuck on terrain pixels,
in sandbox, deployment costs are not configurable (can't really play engineer here..) and it seems like the universe is also different from the campaign
kinda frustrating, so i play with a savegame editor now...
but the developer is very friendly and responds to feedback
and the drone parts are kinda cool
not recommended because probably noone will use AHK to fix their game.
with AHK (and maybe save editor) its okay
my AHK script looks like this:
SetKeyDelay 0

global bindings := {a: {Numpad1: -1, Numpad3: 1, Numpad7: 1},s: {Numpad7: 1, Numpad8: 1, Numpad9: 1},d: {Numpad1: 1, Numpad3: -1, Numpad9: 1},w: {Numpad1: 1, Numpad2: 1, Numpad3: 1}}

*a::goto KeyDown
*a UP::goto KeyUp
*s::goto KeyDown
*s UP::goto KeyUp
*d::goto KeyDown
*d UP::goto KeyUp
*w::goto KeyDown
*w UP::goto KeyUp

global inputonce :={}
global outputmulti :={}

changekeystate(key,mode)
{
	if mode>0
	{
		if !outputmulti[key]
			outputmulti[key]:=0
		++outputmulti[key]
	}
	else
	{
		if !outputmulti[key]
			outputmulti[key]:=0
		--outputmulti[key]
	}
	if outputmulti[key] >0
		Send {%key% down}
	else
		Send {%key% up}
}

KeyDown:
		hk := StrReplace(A_ThisHotkey, "*", "")
		
		if inputonce[hk] = 1
			return
		inputonce[hk] := 1
		for key, mode in bindings[hk]
		{
			changekeystate(key,mode)
		}
		
	return
	
KeyUp:
		hk := StrReplace(A_ThisHotkey, " UP", "")
		hk := StrReplace(hk, "*", "")
		if inputonce[hk] != 1
			return
		inputonce[hk] := 0
		for key, mode in bindings[hk]
		{
			changekeystate(key,mode*-1)
		}
	return

author: {'steamid': '76561199109553579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1621147273}
review: 玩着是不错，但是到后面就显现出了一个很离谱的弊端，你部件越多，他结构就越血马不稳定，为什么不稳定呢，因为所有部件实际上都是一根破杆子链接的你一多，或者杆子一长，你出去飞他就晃悠，你那些武器啊钻头啥的要是没多连几个“固定位”好家伙，你飞行过程中就能乱窜，乱窜你破细杆子连的部件就开始乱飞，没有任何办法，因为这个批游戏根本没有加固部件也没有啥用来稳定的支撑，想是啥一个部件同时连两个的那种？都没有他这个玩意只能【部件←部件←部件←】【部件→部件→部件→】不能【部件←部件→部件】也不能【部件→部件←部件】，他只能一条路走到死，然后你做任务飞他就开始晃荡，因为所有玩意都是 一根线 连 起来 的，就nm离谱，唯一补偿稳定性的办法，那就是这游戏里唯一的，中空方框，唯一能拿来补强稳定性的，中空方块有1格和两格的大小，里面有一格和两格的小方块空隙，这个空隙正好能塞迷你方块，然后你就懂了把，把别的部件连一个迷你方块伸进中空方块里，到时候飞的时候他俩约等于在一起了，就比原来噶油噶油那种晃晃荡荡的能强不少，武器部件同理，多连一个迷你也塞中空里，这么做稳定是稳定点了，然后重量就血ma大了，所以不能全用这个“混凝土“那后面的想是啥采矿容器还有啥电池油箱，那就只能使用祖传的交叉折叠让他们不能来回晃悠，不过还是太nm累了，建议赶紧出个连接杆，求求你力

author: {'steamid': '76561198001437005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1866, 'last_played': 1619819427}
review:
It's a shame that this game isn't better. It is SO CLOSE to being a classic that I would put hundreds or thousands of hours into. Unfortunately, the solid core gameplay is betrayed by the boring and repetitive quests, the small scale of the world design, and the lack of any difficult longterm goals. It's doubly damning considering the core gameplay was more or less lifted straight from Captain Forever, but then put into a smaller world, taking away the joy of discovery and exploration that was a key part of Captain Forever. 

This should have been an open world game. Period. Planets should have been just one environment in a vast universe awaiting you if you fire your thrusters long enough. Instead, they tried to put Captain Forever into a really weak, watered down version of FTL, and the game really suffers for it.

If you're really into building, the sandbox mode may make this game worth it for you, but don't expect to play the main game for very long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345014242', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1486, 'last_played': 1674145154}
review:
好久以前买的了，这两天重温发现了多人模式真香，这可比单人故事有趣多了。
单人有点rougelike的感觉，但是还是有点单调，但多人的模式花样很多，目前主攻还是自动赛事，手残，但是自动的话更加考验设计了，微调一个小时然后推翻直接提升3秒的成绩可太有造大桥的感觉了。
然后有几点建议，比如可以自定义油箱消耗的先后，这样可以做火箭的分级，当让主要还是赛事里面的助推会更加方便等，再或者，可以出可编程逻辑模块，数字电路有时候还是有些困难，而且实现功能越复杂，需要的元件越多，实在是有些难受。
总体来说是好游戏，虽有瑕疵，但是瑕不掩瑜。

author: {'steamid': '76561198145483815', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1621637703}
review:
This game is great in terms of creating robots, but the issue with it, is that it lacks a goal and this is why I will give it a bad review.
You have to create a goal yourself with repetitive objectives that are always or almost always the same, and there's a moment where you hit the point of "your robot does everything", this means: Why creating a robot with complex mechanics when your shitty bot does the job without any problems ?

Slap a few weapons on it, eventually make a robot that has a magnet or drills with storage for mining and boom you're basically done. I've tried unlocking a few items that can make things a bit more funny logic gates and pistons and blocks that drop a missile and shit like that but the issue is that you finish the campain too fast and too easily with only a few chances to find those blocks that can help you make cooler bots that do different things. And like I said: you can have a correct bot that does everything in a few quests by unlocking stronger weapons that literally destroy the world.

And even worse than that, even if you get the opportunity to use those blocks and logic gates, I'm pretty sure that you will probably be better off using the typical weapons and drills bots than some massive bot with crazy stuff on it.

I discovered this game thanks to Lathland, and back then I remember the campain being way more interesting, I believe they changed it to ... this but why ?

The online modes in Nimbatus only work with programmed drones. You are not able to control them manually. If you need help with programming drones, come join our discord where other players can give you tips: https://discord.com/invite/nimbatus

I hope this helps!

Cheers,
Micha

Markus

review:
Félicitations à l'équipe - c'est le meilleur jeu auquel j'ai joué depuis longtemps. Bien entendu, il ne faut pas vous attendre à un jeu de gestion hyper sophistiqué, mais la mécanique de créer votre drone puis de faire de petites missions est sympathique.

Ce que j'apprécie le plus est le la simulation de la physique, il faut réfléchir un peu avant de poser les propulseurs, les armes...

Bref, un très bon jeu pour un petit studio indépendant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995382211', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1141, 'last_played': 1606991167}
review:
I'm usually a wordy idiot, so let me try to keep it short here.

There are two parts to this game:  1) Designing your drones 2) Using your drones to complete missions.  The first part (1) is super fun, well-developed, sensible, and in my opinion a wonderful idea on which to base a game of this type.  The second (2) part is lame, repetitive, frustrating, narrow, frustrating, not fun, and frustrating.  That's just my opinion.  Also, it feels weird to down-vote the entire game just based on the weakness of that part of the campaign,  but since that's the bulk of the gameplay you're paying for when you purchase Nimbatus on Steam, I am forced to argue that it's actually that important.  Feelsbadman.

Yes, part of my displeasure with the game does amount to a whiny bit of "Game too hard, WAAAH!!!"  I realize that sort of thing isn't a super compelling argument to many of you tRuE gAmErS, and so be it.  All I'm saying is that once my drone left the hangar, I stopped having fun.  Imagine me saying that with a non-committal shrug of the shoulders, and all the feigned indifference of a tabby cat who just got hit with a squirt bottle.  Like, whatever man.  :(

There are definitely some of you reading this review who should ignore my criticism and buy it anyway.  For one thing, the single-player campaign is not all there is on offer from Nimbatus.  For another thing, some of you have more patience for this shit than I do, and there's a decent chance you will still have a lot of fun building, testing, rebuilding, and repeating.  That's fine.  We all have different tolerances for certain things.  Honestly, the shit I've put up with from other games in my time.  Some of those games were not as well-designed as Nimbatus, either, but I have hundreds of hours on them and left them a positive review.  Idk, this one just doesn't do it for me.  It's, like, just whatever, okay?

7/, like, 10  ...or whatever.

review:
玩了一段时间，将简单模式通关后，感觉有几个不是很好的地方：
首先是关卡，太少了，很快就通关了
然后是里面的一些设定，每次发射飞船如果超过零件就要钱，这个有点烦，因为不能造很大的飞船，太大了会让钱流失太快，升级也有限度。另外对飞船零件的获取很随机，有时候很难弄到想要的
建议
多增加一些关卡，以及个别星球再大一点，对星球和任务的描述多一点
还有飞船零件，希望从商店里可以获得更多种类零件
然后是对飞船的升级，能升的次数太少了，建议可以升到10多级这样最好
最后是飞船太丑了，怎么造都太丑了，就不能多给点其他形状的方块吗，然后得到的方块可以调整大小这样，我看dlc好像是有皮肤的，但是好贵，这个游戏不打折买我都感觉很亏
这个游戏总体还行吧，虽然有一些不合理的地方，玩法很新颖，不过总体设计感觉不如重组好。

review:
Nimbatus is the kind of game for everyone that loves to resolves problems in a creative way...

...or blowing up things with a spaceship because it's f*cking epic.

What's interesting is that you don't need a lot of experience to build a good spaceship, but if you have the BEEG BRAIN of a tech teacher on crack, you can actually make some very complex and interesting spaceships that can even be fully automatic.

It even got a multiplayer mode so you can flex on your friends on how destructive is your giant fully self-thrusting mecha-peen that you just build in-game this morning while questionning your life choices.

So do i recommand it? Yes.
Will you waste some good time on it? If you are dedicated to building stuff, Yes.
Will you make mechanical horrors that will give you PTSD flashbacks of an dark era that you were never in? Absolutly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198397817718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1368, 'last_played': 1629293463}
review:
So in first place i was never interested in buying or aknowledging this game, i've got it as a gift from friend who wanted me to check it out, thus i did and heres what i can make out of experience :
•
Game concept is quite actually nice, you build drones whatever sort u want them to be and then u get to do missions game offers you, its really nice on the creativity side as game offers you a whole lot of physics and logic based tools where if you try hard enough you could make a calculator, great for a brain excercise as to how well you can deal with logic.
•
Now for the some of worst bits of game, amount of types and sorts of missions is quite little, although some of them are really creative, from carrying a thing from point A to point B to actual boss battles.
Amount of content other than tools to program and do physics and mechanics based interactions is really really little, you have literally only about 10 or less building shapes which is spheres and boxes without a single thing to smoothen out your rough drone build.
One of game aspects that make drones look acceptable is skins which is almost a bane of game as they require player to do some actually challenging actions as building a drone that can compete with infinitely expanding difficulty of player made machines that been fighting for these skins for quite a while and got to know almost exploit type of knowledge as to how to win. For example my friend who actually bought me this game also got a copy for himself, and spent over 16 hours trying to achieve victory, even as this review is being released he did not get any close to winning.
One another quite sad detail about the gameplay is that developers involve really a lot of grind into this game, for example in campaign mode you would do insane amount of missions and would still have a chance of not winning cause of sheer luck on your grind.
In fact a whole too much is dependant on your luck, your playthrough, your drone, your wins
•
Now that you've read all these downsides and flaws of game being told out through this guide you might be thinking, why would you want to buy this game under any circumstances ? The thing is, game have active community, and maybe you could become one of main steps in order to get game to its glory by bying it, becoming part of its community and giving open minded developers ideas that might make Nimbatus a same hit of a game as Besiege, hope you will choose whether or not to give this game a chance and maybe turn this ugly duckling into one more beautiful swan !
--------
Изначально я не планировал приобретать или вообще наделять эту игру каким либо вниманием, я получил её от друга как подарок, чтобы я её оценил, и вот это случилось, вот то что мне удалось о ней узнать из моего опыта :
•
Концепт игры очень даже интересный, здесь можно построить своего дрона любого типа и вида, и пойти покорять миссии которые игра предлагает вам. Игра очень хороша на креативной стороне так как игроку даётся хороший набор логических деталей и деталей для механического воздействия. Логических частей так много что практически при должном усердии можно собрать калькулятор. Эта игра отлично развивает логику.
•
А теперь о грустных аспектах игры, количество миссий и их типов довольно скудное, хотя некоторые довольно изобретательные, от простого принести из точки А в точку Б до полноценных битв с боссами.
Объём контента отличный от логических деталей и механических запчастей не велик. Для декорирования и обустройства дрона в арсенале не более 10 деталей которые являют собой различные кружки и квадраты.
Один из аспектов игры который помогает с декорированием это скины, которые в той же мере являются заклятием игры так как для их получения игроку необходимо провести действительно сложные действия для их получения так как необходимо построить дрона который сможет сразить дроны других игроков которые бесконечно совершенствовались чтобы получить эти скины, обладая чуть ли не знаниями о багах и хитростях самого движка игры. К примеру мой друг который и приобрёл мне игру взял копию и себе, после установки он пытался 16 часов подряд пройти один из соревновательных режимов, даже на момент написания этого обзора он не приблизился к победе.
Ещё одна печальная нота этой игры это то что разработчики вложили очень много фарма в эту игру, к примеру в режиме компании для того чтобы получить нужную деталь надо пройти неимоверное количество миссий и всё равно будет шанс не получить что хочется из-за простой удачи в этом фарме.
В этой игре вообще много чего держится на чистой удаче, слишком много, ваше прохождение, ваш дрон, ваши победы.
•
Теперь когда вы прочитали всё это вы верно думаете а зачем вам надо при каких либо обстоятельствах приобретать эту игру ? У неё есть активное сообщество, и возможно вы станете ключом к тому чтобы игра стала лучше, купив её, став участником её сообщества и давая разработчикам Nimbatus идеи которые действительно могут спасти игру и превратить её в хит не хуже Besiege, надеюсь вы сможете выбрать дать этой игре шанс и возможно превратить этого гадкого утёнка в красивого лебедя !

author: {'steamid': '76561197986443961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1609989337}
review:
Players:

Cool idea, so-so execution. Horrific design with regards to pacing, discoverability, the intuitiveness and consistency of gameplay rules/interactions, and teaching players about new game mechanics. I'm frustrated that such an awesome concept with so many neat features wasn't designed with a more thoughtful vision of the core loop and comprehensive experience. I have the sense that this game does not value or respect my time.

Developers: 

Plunking standalone tutorials into the main menu is not a substitute for introducing mechanics in a way that elegantly teaches the player how they work. And skimping on that leads to a lot of frustration. Players build a mental model of the interactions your game allows. It's bad game design to structure those building blocks in a way that is internally inconsistent and incoherent. It's also bad game design to present players with a problem that results in unavoidable failure before giving access to (or even hinting at) potential solutions. Usually I look into a game's wiki out of curiosity and anticipation of things to come. In Nimbatus, I look to the wiki in order to figure out what the hell is going on and understand fundamental mechanics. Often the answer was something counter-intuitive, or worse, simply "the only viable solution is something you haven't encountered yet."

A quick list:

1. How mining works (equip two parts that magically work together and then deposit materials into a massive storage bin [again magically, just by entering it while holding resources] that exists near the spawn point but is not labelled, introduced, demonstrated, or explained). Prior to discovering this, every action my ship could take was explicitly associated with a part and mapped to a button.

2. How collecting fossils works. You'd think it was like mining, but it's actually a magnet. Why are fossils magnetic? Why couldn't you call the magnet something more generic like "attractor"?  Who knows! Also, prior to this mission I had no idea that I might have to use my ship to physically move a game object, rather than just sucking resources into a container and then dropping them off in a bin.

3. How surviving freezing effects works. You'd think it involved heating yourself with flame weapons, which comprise the only heat/cold mechanic the player is exposed to prior to that level. But that doesn't work, despite the fact that heat weapons heat up enemies and environment objects, and that explosive weapons you detonate near your own craft will act on the player's drone and destroy its parts. Instead, the solution is apparently a "heater" part that I've yet to encounter, and/or a way of modifying plating to be cold-resistant that is buried in the drone construction interface and never mentioned or explained. And/or using heat weapons mounted on your ship to heat up OTHER THINGS, which then can heat the player's drone by proxy, for some reason. I think even just running plasma weapons for too long will heat up nearby components on your drone. Why is my drone magically immune to the direct effects of its own heat weapons, but not to explosive ones? I still don't know. I blasted my drone with two continuous streams of flaming plasma and watched it become engulfed in crippling ice anyway. Welcome to the arbitrary punishment of Nimbatus.

4. How mines work and how big their explosions are. Spoiler: their blast radius is large enough to cause massive chain reactions which can bloom across the entire screen destroy you instantly. For me, they were introduced during a "you get one try and if you fail you can't try again, sucks for you" mission, which was also timed. A chain reaction of mines was triggered by the second mine I exploded, and I did so carefully, from maximum range with a "sniper" weapon to be "safe." Awesome! Thanks for that. If you hadn't guessed, I failed and missed out on important resources.

I'm sure I'll continue encountering these frustrating moments every 30-60 minutes if I keep playing. I get that elegant design and tutorialization is hard, but in the meantime, it'd be less frustrating if the game had some kind of reference manual, tool tips, or at least warned at the presence and implications of new mechanics on a given planet's mission description, or listed recommended components. But it doesn't even attempt to. Without that information, the strategic decisions of whether to visit planets and in what order are frequently foisted on players who are unprepared to make them.

Unless you're going to nail the way you introduce players to new mechanics, you shouldn't marry the experimentation and failure of a roguelite with the pressure and resource management of a survival game when your core loop requires 15-20 minutes for each step in the journey. The result is that failure is frequent, often arbitrary, always painful, and often doesn't even teach the player anything. 

Worse still, because of the resource management aspect, early failures due to the player's ignorance and the game's terrible tutorialization don't immediately ruin a run, but instead will slowly compound and suffocate a playthrough over the course of hours. So you've kind of achieved the inverse of roguelite, where instead of making incremental progress as they learn the ropes, players gradually undermine themselves and erode their resources over time. My experience building and playing with ships in Nimbatus was great, but playing the survival mode can best be described as "it's like if FTL had bad UI, no progress preserved between runs, and a single run took as long as a Civ game."

That said, I do love the drone building, and the core gameplay is a lot of fun when decoupled from the frustration and wasted time that accompanies most new mechanics' introductions. At this point I'm downloading a cheat engine to edit my save file for more resources and learn at my own pace, with the wiki as a first step to anything remotely new or different. Also considering putting the game down for a while and checking back in a year or so.

P.S. You should also let people assign multiple key bindings to a single drone component. It would make steering and navigation much more flexible and efficient.

EDIT: 

So I encountered another new mechanic, again introduced in a "you get one try and if you fail you can't try again, sucks for you" mission, which was (again) also timed. This one featured a planetoid made entirely of resources that could be mined, with the red (good) ones all the way in the middle. Sounds great so far!

However, the timer was strict enough that I could realistically make one good dive to the middle of the planet, which I planned to do using a specially constructed mining drone with +200% mining plasma lasers that I created and tested specifically for this purpose. Sadly, my arbitrary limit of one resource container meant that I could only really collect 50 of the hundreds of red resources at the planetoid's center, making the best-case scenario for this special planet not much (if at all) better than any other planet where I encountered red resources. But whatever, the concept was interesting and could be practice for some future version of the same challenge when I'd be able to outfit drones with more resource container parts, right?

So I'm digging along very successfully until I'm just outside of the planetoid's juicy red core. Then, at the middle of the planet, surrounding the good resources, I discovered a ring of NEVER BEFORE ENCOUNTERED, EXTRA DENSE AND PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE TO MINE THROUGH ROCK. So I spent about half of my time getting to the core of the planet, and the other half digging through most of the extra-hard rock doughnut barrier between me and the good resources. And then the timer ran out. 

Another run failed with no recourse thanks to a surprise mechanic, despite ample preparation on my part! So that's it for me. I'm officially putting this game down for at least a few updates, and maybe forever.

review:
I didn't finish the campaign because of how repetetive it is. As I went further and further, the only difference wes number of things I had to collect or destroy, but the objectives remained the same. It didn't help that I purchased all of the hull upgrades early into the game (played as a miner and collected all red stuff on every planet).

Game concept in itself is great and execution of drone mechanics is polished, but singleplayer experience is way too tedious. I also wish flying a drone was funnier. It never felt smooth, and so the combat and navigation is very sloggish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025360119', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1601157554}
review: Much content is added to cover up how unpolished the main gameplay loop and balance actually is. Sensors and weapons are very limited and janky unless they're just straight up op. Everything being in gravity narrows what you can do and makes certain builds that exploit it op. A lot of gameplay is trial and error of messing with these janky mechanics. I don't even know what the point of a giant skill tree of minor stat increases and weapon variants is when everything is so unbalanced. Feels like a hacking together of the mechanics and adding of common gameplay elements. Maybe you'll still like it if you find those mechanics really exciting though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115942746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2050, 'last_played': 1609804528}
review:
Don't get me wrong when I say that I don't recommend, because I did have some fun with it and would rather give it a "neutral." However, it's kind of a short game, and the difficulty curve is somewhat steep until you acquire all the upgrades for your mothership, have all the parts you need, and are basically rolling in cash.

The major problem I have is that, simply put, there has to be a better way to unlock the other skins besides winning the pseudo-multiplayer tournaments. As petty as it may sound ("git gud" and all that), the tourneys are so full of overpowered, cookie-cutter and/or exploit-y builds that it's nigh impossible to win a single match on skill alone, let alone 10.

I give this one a 6/10. Overall not worth the full price of $20, best to wait for a sale. Decent fun playing alone, but may the gods of luck be with you if you try the tournaments.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023716890', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 1685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1582, 'last_played': 1625697243}
review:
So, it turns out that the game is rather, limited. It was fun in single player for a while, but gets kind of repetitive. It requires you to know how to hook up a lot of logic circuits and automate your drone for no input at all, for any type of multiplayer and almost all the multiplayer modes are heavily exploited.

If you ask for help with stuff to figure out how to do things in single player, people generally just tell you to use the many exploits in the game to cheat your way to an easy victory. Most notably the factory block which the devs left in as a special cheat block and any time anyone suggests rebalancing the block, everyone else foams at the mouth.

Survival mode, feels a bit, weak. It should have had more to it, it might have been more fun that way. It was fun for a while though till I got that Factory Block and found out that its just a huge cheat tool. I tried to get assistance designing an automated drone yesterday and people were all like "Why? Just create a spring string exploit and mine the entire map lazily!", so I never got any help with creating the drone I wanted to create.

I'd say there's a good 3-5 hours of gameplay if you don't want to join the heavily exploited automated PVP modes. if you impose rules on yourself to not cheat and exploit like these guys tell you to do, you'll have some decent challenges. The end game mission was disappointingly easy though. Hell, the pirate base I came across was harder.

This game was gifted to me by a friend, I am a little saddened by the fact that I had to give the game a negative review. Hopefully, the developers see this, and consider making some changes. The community has some fierce defenders of the game though, who insulted me for not playing their way, making me decide to go ahead and write this review sooner rather than later. So the Nimbatus devs, can thank their fanboys for making me feel even more disappointed in the game.

review:
You, yes you, person reading this review. Do you like space? Do you like drones? Do you like big ships? Do you like big ships controlling drones on smaller planets in space? If you answered yes to any of those questions this game is for you!

We've got it all, drones, space, evil corporations, giant space snakes, explosions, circuits and logic. Anything you want and anything you need is here! (getting everything you want not guaranteed.)

You want to waste nights away by creating a drone to completely autonomous? You can do it!
You want to make a drone capable of wiping a planet off the face of existence? You can do it!
You want to clear your student debt and get a profitable job? Think a little more realistic, like getting a dragon for Christmas. 
You want to stop be sad? Play this game! (Happiness not guaranteed.)
You want to relax and play a game stress free? Play this game (relaxation and stress free game-play not guaranteed.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030158185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 3710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3167, 'last_played': 1694825215}
review:
TBH its a fun game, the core gameplay loop (entire playthrough) is about an hour or two. Anything past this point is highly repetitive. It's a great concept, but in its current state, it is not worth even 10$ IMO. A great deal of work needs to be put into gameplay mechanics, improving replayability, increasing buildable blocks and expanding the "story". The "story" seemed like a tutorial, almost as if the devs gave up on the game early on, my thoughts upon completion were : "awesome tutorial, I wonder what the core game is like...." but that WAS the game... *sigh*

Update post "release" : Game officially given up on, devs trying to cash-in-quick with sales on release etc. Studios entirety on sale. This game is a failed venture, I wont be purchasing from stray-fawn at all in the future (if they are still alive). Including ventures of both Micha and Philomena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168882266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1604909638}
review:
面白いゲームだけど全体的に不親切な部分が多いゲーム
まずゲームモードの「サバイバル」がすでに上級者向けなので最初に選んでしまうと「なんだこの作業ゲームは！！」という悪い評価になってしまう。
ゲームに慣れるまでは「サンドボックス」でオプションを
・惑星はカスタマイズ可能→なし
・銀河マップを自由に探索可能→有
・武器のアップグレードを無料→なし
・無料の母船のアップグレード→なし
・ドローンパーツのアンロック→有
・Nimbatusの船体と脅威→なし
・ドローン起動コスト→なし
で始めてみよう
自作ドローンのトライ＆エラーを繰り返しながらちょっとずつパーツを手に入れる楽しみが両立できる！サバイバルはやり直しできない部分が多いのでこのオプションで慣れてから挑戦するのが良いです！

（追記）
「燃料・エネルギー・資源のワイヤレス転送」の使い方
分離機で資源タンク・バッテリー・燃料タンクを切り離して使うのが基本的な使い方！
（母船の下にある）コンテナ内に切り離して置いておくと資源回収機を作動させるだけで採取完了！！
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2281867934

author: {'steamid': '76561198070709807', 'num_games_owned': 1138, 'num_reviews': 460, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1604789309}
review:
[code]Written By Hidden Gems Review : https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38624426/[/code]

Review: Nimbatus - The Space Drone Constructor is an original roguelike ship building.

You can build any type of ship you want then travel to the planets and complete missions  for get resources for unlock more new types of  weapons, engines ect...

Where it shines the most it's in the building part and the workshop because you can download constructions of other players or create your own.

The constructions of this ships can be amazing big and powerfull, mine it's the oposite, just a normally ship tryng to survive to the planets, also if you build larger ships the resources for deploy the ship are bigger.

The visual aspect also it's great, can be so shinny even with a little ship like mine.

You can see my Gameplay here : https://youtu.be/WcuL73Mb4_U

review:
面白くなるのに時間がかかるゲーム。
序盤さえ乗り切れば楽しいと思います。

最初は何もない状態から船を作れ！から始まりますし説明のないまま○○を回収しろ（専用装備必須）はよくありますし○○を倒せ！どれだよとかユーザーフレンドリーは皆無です。
ですが序盤さえ乗り切ればパーツも増え出来ることも増え楽しくなってくる感じです。
ただミッションの種類が少ないのは気になります。
まだ序盤っていう差し引いても代わり映えが…

author: {'steamid': '76561198191697210', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 8551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1013, 'last_played': 1639873807}
review:
[strike]新添加的推进器会自动加上弱智的按键设置，比如我放个朝前的推进器却给我设置个W的按键！！！！
一个推进器只能设置一个按键，我想用3~4个推进器实现前进后退转向却无法做到，必须加上逻辑电路才能做到！
程序员过取回跳跃驱动器这一关让我感受到了游戏作者对于程序员的深深的恶意。
一个基础的逻辑电路的体积居然等于两个炮塔，现实中指甲盖大小的体积上都可以放上百亿个晶体管了。
要造一个可以全自动打爆发电器然后进入星球中间取回跳跃驱动器的无人机，可能要上百个逻辑电路。这一关敌人的基地有很多不能破坏的墙壁，中间的路不是很宽，要进去需要飞船体积不能太大，而且还要有个导航方法，加上武器，燃料，推进器，电池，最后要造一个巨大的飞船难以飞进敌人的基地内部。进去之后不光要消灭敌人，还要吧驱动器取回来，这要求也太苛刻了。
飞船的零件不能和相邻的零件互相连接固定，飞船造大了就会变的像弹簧一样松软。
有十分严重的BUG，如果你选了程序员，那打科尔公司的实验室的任务将无法完成！因为传感器选择任务目标的时候经常会跳过最后一个必要的目标而直接去打最后的实验室，导致实验室的防护罩没有消除无法攻击它。而程序员模式你又不能操作无人机，最终这一关卡关无法通关！


又玩了下其他的职业，觉得还可以吧。现在问题还很多，感觉游戏像是还没有开发完成。和其之前玩过的一个叫reassembly的游戏很像，但是有很大的改进。
有一些严重的问题应该改善：
1，界面和操作方式。这类游戏似乎有一个通病，就是没有一个很舒适的操作方式。一个手动操作的飞船，玩家要时刻注意调整飞船的方向避免坠地或者使正确的方向对准敌人，同时还要操作防护罩，磁铁，加热降温等等，人类的手指是有限的！！要同时作出这么多操难度太高，让人玩得很累很累。一个好的游戏应该能让玩家把注意力都放在真正的重点上。
2，玩家的视野范围太小太小，经常受到视野范围外的敌人攻击，比如那个炮台，隔着十万八千里就可以打你，你经常要摸黑打你视野外看不到的敌人，这样又会导致你失手打到了视野外的任务怪导致任务失败！这个设计非常非常不好！！！
3，运气成份太重要，或者说随机获得部件这个设定不太好。某些部件如果没有及时获得，游戏就会变得很困难，比如钻头，加热冷却，逻辑电路之类的。
4，游戏的指引也太少了，教程内容很有限，还有很多部件没有任何说明，该怎么用玩家只能靠猜！写一句话告诉玩家它的功能会死吗？会死吗？会死吗？这难道是个解谜游戏？！


由上面第1条说的，游戏急需设计一个合理的操作方式！
建议新放置的推进器不自动设置按键，而是留空提示玩家设置按键，点击屏幕上方的提示可以自动定位到没设置按键的部件上
建议增加一个视角模式，玩家的无人机固定在屏幕中央正面朝上不动，背景和其他物体随着玩家的动作移动。
建议一个部件可以设置多个按键和tag。
继续添加教程内容介绍每一个部件的用法，或者在游戏内添加一个wiki，不要让玩家频繁切出游戏去看youtube！
逻辑电路的尺寸和质量能不能缩小一些？不如改成CPU，内部可以自行添加若干条逻辑判断。

游戏还有一些巨大的坑！
温度传感器不能告诉你温度是高了还是低了，寒冷的星球上你需要带上加热器防止被冻结，但是有一种敌人的攻击却会让你温度升高！！而你却无法自动判断需要加热还是降温！！！[/strike]

程序员职业有非常非常多的问题！！然而其他职业又完全没有挑战性。
0，nimbatus飞船和接收容器的位置时高时低在不同的星球会有很大变化！玩程序员模式每到一个星球都要专门为接收容器调整一些设置。接收容器经常离星球太近，甚至陷入地形中，经常挡住我的无人机，而且下面喷火会对我造成伤害，要设计很多东西来绕过去。另外星球的半径是数值，而高度计又是以百分比而不是高度值来调整，再加上接收容器的高度总是在随机变化而不是固定在一个高度百分比上，这根本就是刻意在给程序员玩家制造困难！
1，逻辑电路目前设计得很糟糕！体积巨大不说，当你有成百上千个逻辑电路的时候，如果要进行一系列修改真是太太太麻烦了！要一个个点开才知道里面写的是什么！
2，所有的零件只能设置一个tag和一个按键，当你想增加控制方式或者输出的时候必须用到逻辑电路，这带来了一点点不便。
3，飞船如果做得很大，会变得像布丁一样松软有很大弹性，这让我的推进器，武器，传感器不能对准我预期的方向，应该提供一种方法把零件全部固定在一起！
4，雷达上我方单位和地形的颜色也太接近了，难以辨别，这是故意的吗？感觉有些恶意。
5，方向传感器不能定位资源，导致程序员要挖矿只有把整个星球都挖没。这通常要花很长很长时间，这太不程序员了，完全不优雅！
6，距离传感器和接近度传感器辨别的选项太少了，能够被摧毁和不能被摧毁的障碍物区分不了！！还有接近度传感器的判断距离太短太短，如果无人机速度较快可能会撞上目标或者错过目标，难以在目标与你距离不同的时候采取不同的行动，如果做捕获虹鱼的任务很容易丢失目标！！！！
7，距离传感器和接近度传感器如果用来检测前方的我的无人机（为了避免相撞），就必须放在最前方并且没有被自己的零件遮挡，这样一来如果还需要挖掘地形，钻头就很难布置了！
8，无人机似乎没有办法检查自身的完整性，当你受到攻击或者碰撞失去一些零件之后没有办法继续正常运转时，没有一个好的办法自救。我的办法是放一些炸弹在无人机上，一旦炸弹爆炸就会将无人机完全摧毁，然后制造工厂会制造一个新的出来，但是这个方法经常会失灵。应该出一个完整性检测工具或者出个可以修复失去的零件的工具。
9，游戏的引导也太少了，很多东西没有任何说明！游戏内应该给予说明，不要让玩家切出去google或者youtube，这给人的感觉像是游戏被打断了一样。
10，建议界面上显示星球最高点的半径，高度计可以按照数值或者百分比设置，还有在一个星球上经过的时间，鼠标指针或者某个无人机所在的高度。
11,有一些只能尝试一次的地图即使是创造模式也不能反复尝试，完全没有办法试错！基本上等于说程序员玩家不配玩这些地图！这对程序员玩家的歧视太严重！
作者真的有好好玩过程序员舰长吗？！
2020/11/16新发现了重大的BUG，方向传感器的目标如果选择收集容器，那么它指向的位置不是收集容器的中心，而是在收集容器上方大约半个身位的位置！！这导致你如果要全自动将物品放入收集容器里，无人机将总是呆在容器上方转圈而无法把物品送入收集容器内！
developer_response: 感谢您对游戏的意见与建议，我们将会对此情况进行核查与修复，如果您还有对游戏的任何问题，也随时欢迎提出！

review: The game flat out would not work for me.  Could do the tutorials no problem but I couldn't edit drones
developer_response:
Hi kozaa66,

Thank you for your message. I would love to help / solve your problem (also for future reference, so I can help other players as well).

Were you able to start a new Survival or Sandbox game? Did the Multiplayer part work? (=able to start a game with a new drone)?

Not being able to edit drones might be because you subscribed/ "downloaded" a drone from the workshop. Before being able to edit a drone from the workshop, you have to click "import".
We added this additional step because normally when you subscribe to a drone, if the creator edits his creation, it get automatically updated on your PC as well. If you could/would edit the downloaded drone, then the updates from the creator could not merge with your updates easily.

Therefore, to be able to edit drones from the workshop, you have to subscribe/download them first, and then import them to your "own drones" list. From there you can edit them freely. (while still being able to access the original workshop drone in the "downloaded" section.

I hope it was this problem. Please let me know if this fixed it. Otherwise I can see what else might be the problem.

Thank you and cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198032249196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1409, 'last_played': 1604614365}
review:
Nimbatus is fun little game where you build drones to accomplish various objectives. In the singeplayer survival mode you progress from planet to planet and aquire new parts as you go. You can mine resources and upgrade your mothership, and there's generally a good amount of variation in the missions.
The best part is, of course, coming up with new & creative designs of which the game makes you think there's almost endless variety.

There's not, though. The game has enough variety to keep you occupied for a good chunk of time, but frankly despite all the stuff you can build and add to your drones, the game does get kinda samey after a while. The survival campaign is also very short, though you are encouraged to replay it with different captains (that provide different starting loadouts and perks) which extends the fun at least a bit.

The graphics are, to put it mildly, simple. Everything is very flat and mspaint-cartoony, but not "bad" per se. I would've liked at least some depth and shading to make the world come alive a bit more, though.

For the pricetag, its decent value. If you're the creative type and enjoy games that emply visual programming logic, then give it a shot.
Honestly, i'd want to see the devs make a sequel that takes the concepts explored here to make something more polished and shiny. Like i said, it's not bad, it just fell a bit short of my expectations.

Oh, and don't bother with the MP stuff. It's all unfun meta & glitched designs. Stick with singleplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066314968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1601686092}
review:
[h1]影片介紹[/h1]
我有為此遊戲做影片介紹，有興趣的可以看看
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JqMn6Vhm9gU

-----------------
[h1]✔️優點[/h1]

1.超高自由度的組裝玩法。

[h1]❌缺點[/h1]

1.上下限很高的樂趣，你若有辦法組出一台很屌的太空船，那你應該會感受到樂趣，但相反的，你什麼鬼都組不出來，你就幾乎無法從中獲得樂趣了。

[h1]心得[/h1]
遊戲當初在看預告片，駕駛的太空船很酷很帥，所以二話不說就買下來玩了，但沒想到裡邊的系統卻是如此的硬派，讓我以為我在學電機系工程學了...我很努力地想要從中獲得一絲樂趣，但勉強通過簡單的生存模式之後，花了1個多小時，拼湊出一艘自認為看起來很屌的太空船，但實際在星球上行駛，根本就是一坨屎之後，我就徹底茫茫然了，我想我不是玩這款遊戲的料QAQ，好險，遊戲裡可以去工作坊下載別人做好的太空船，各種超屌的太空船，真的顛覆我的想像，也讓我瞠目結舌這到底怎麼做出來的，再次讓我感嘆，果然，我不是玩這款遊戲的料QAQ，如果各位想玩這款遊戲的人，得要再三考慮，你的邏輯能力，工程學方面如果沒有些許造詣的話，不然我是建議你不要玩的，遊戲非常硬派喔。

author: {'steamid': '76561197996817247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1598826746}
review:
I like the promise and building bots are fun, but the gameplay loop itself is done quite poorly in my opinion. Why a tinkering/building game needs a rouge-like mechanics? Not only it is unnecessary, but it is also actively interfering with the most fun part of the game - building and testing bots. Having a deploy cost means that instead of coming up with crazy designs and sending them into a mission to test and have fun, I have to create deliberately functionally and boring designs and tediously creep though the mission trying to avoid any risks. 

Also, the balancing is quite bad, at my first campaign the second mission I took was nearly impossible for the drones I could build from the parts available, so after sending drone after drone and spending all the resources I almost lost the campaign (on the second mission) and had to abandon it.

To summarise: a cool fighting bots building mechanics, but unfortunately without a good game to back it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997715158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 462, 'playtime_forever': 8164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7906, 'last_played': 1706839818}
review:
Хотел сначала хорошенько поиграть в эту игрушку, прежде чем делать какие-либо выводы. И могу сказать что не жалею об этом, игра - просто топчик. Стала одной из моих любимых за первые пару часов страданий, ошибок и плохой инжинерии.

Понравится как и любителям FTL, так и любителям песочниц/конструкторов. Суть в кратце, состоит в том что у вас экспериментальный космический корабль, с фабрикатором дронов внутри. Выбираете вышего капитана и... Валите на исследование рандомно сгенерированных галактик. А планеты/астеройды и прочие интересные объекты, исследуются дронами. 

Делается это примерно так: У вас есть режим мастерской, а так-же, запчасти и материалы для первого дрона... Потом, дрон печатается на 3д принтере и запускается на исследование поверхности (Миссии и места бывают довольно разные)... Ну и, нужно собрать потихоньку нашего дрона. Можете глянуть туториалы на ютубе или разобраться самостоятельно, методом научного тыка (Или скачать один из моих готовых чертежей). Постепенно, вы будете находить больше запчастей, что можно получить в награду за разные задания на планетах/астеройдах и иногда, купить у торговцев или даже выиграть в казино. 

Но долго не торчите на одной точке, ибо... За вами погоня.

Игра мне понравилась тем, что она не требовательна к железу и идёт даже на моём старом тостере... На нормальном компьютере, даже выглядит очень красиво и ярко, но мне это пока не дано. Очень большой выбор запчастей, гаджетов, сенсоров и ОГРОМНЫЙ ассортимент случайного оружия. Эффективность ваших дронов ограничивает лишь ваш креатив, ваша удача и ассортимент запчастей что вы собрали по закаулкам вселенной... И до финальной точки, путь очень долгий, но даже после прохождения основного задания игры, можно играть дальше, хоть бесконечно, если вы пожелаете. Так-же, стоит отметить что разработчики продолжают добавлять в игру новые возможности и запчасти. И ещё один плюс... 

Нормально сделан перевод на русский язык.

В общем, вкратце... Игра шикарная и я всем её советую. Отличный космический 2д конструктор.

10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994722238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1596082070}
review:
Wonderful premise marred by completely uninspiring missions. The missions are all very same-y and for the most part are without any pressure, so you can beat the whole game with like a 20-part ship that maybe you slap a heating or cooling part on sometimes. The enemies are very bland and usually simply able to be kited without danger (even without shields), and they have pretty abysmal AI and detection.

You CAN build behemoths like in the trailer, which is cool and respectable, but there isn't any reason to aside from just doing it to do it. The eventual flying them around isn't very engaging, and it's completely unnecessary or inefficient. Maybe the game would be better if all missions were timed, to give more reason to create monstrous, planet-chewing drones, but as it is, you can plink away with basically the same drone you built for the first mission and call it good.

Not to mention "variables" are basically keyboard inputs. ie, A-key is used to store boolean true or false. Same for every other key on the keyboard. That might be okay, but it's impossible to see which key "variables" are already used throughout the ship.
Lastly, the ship logic being actual physics blocks in space is kind of silly. Why is an XOR gate destroyable? Sensors, I can understand. But logic gates with mass connected by joints? Madness.

I will spend some more time with it... but if you are a programmer/coder, don't expect to have fun doing the programmer mode.

review:
Nice game with no limits for a reasonable price.

It's really easy to built your first simple drone. Once you understood the mechanics and the goals of the missions you can go crazy with building your drone. There are so many different ways of playing the game - you can built a drone for each kind of mission or a drone that is able to complete every mission.
There are many different kind drone parts you can attach to you drone and for experts there even are parts that can be automated. So if you'd like to learn and try new stuff in the game, you simply can try to built a new drone with parts you haven't used yet. That way the game never gets boring.

It's a cool game for in between. I absolutely can recommend the game, keep it up :)

review:
Nimbatus is a great game. The campaign is fun and just long enough, and there's enough in the game to play many more hours once you've finished the campaign. However, there are a few problems with it. I would want to see more deterministic physics, as testing can give wildly different results from the actual planets (or other game modes.) Also, the game only seems to work for smaller designs. Once you try building big like they show in the trailers, everything gets really floppy and unpredictable.

 I'd also want to see a better logic system than just simple logic gates, but that's just a personal preference. Overall still a good game and I can't wait to see what happens in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188714328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 3626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1528, 'last_played': 1696204370}
review:
Amazing game if you enjoy any kind of building game. The progression stays interesting with a modular weapon system; the combination of base weapons, elements, and weapon upgrades makes finding new weapons exciting! Alternate captains to play as who have their own unique strengths. Overall, this game is very enjoyable.

The only downside I see to this game is the limited mission types. It's really not that much of a downside, but the main missions you will do are variations of destroy missions or recover missions. For me the ability to create new things to complete the missions in different ways negates the lack of variety. There are some more unique ones here and there, but it would be cool to see some new objectives. Also this is a super minor complaint, but I really enjoy playing as programmer, and I wish there were just a little bit more logic parts to work with. There is probably a way to achieve any logic through the parts provided, but it would be nice if there were some simpler ways. For example, a logic piece where it is given several inputs at different priorities, and will only allow the highest priority input to output to the rest of the system. That would make it much easier to program cameras that focus on just the important ships rather than having a camera that flies everywhere cause you have too many drones doing too many things. I might be able to come up with more logic pieces, but that one was just one that came to mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112620307', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1080, 'last_played': 1622202310}
review:
The game in its current state is in my opinion not worth the asking price. 

Main issues are:
Clunky building limitations, for example the logic parts take large amounts of space, and there is no fuel tank priority. that means you have no control over which tanks are used, which is incredibly annoying in races when you might want certain tanks to deplete before others.

The singleplayer is completely mindless. Every level is just one of a few different types where taking as slow and careful approach as possible is encouraged because of harsh penalties for failing.

There are no good custom games, where you could accurately test flight. For example making all multiplayer maps available in offline so you could test workshop drones in them

review: Game is great. Except for survival mode which is probably the mode most people buying this game are going to start in. The progression in survival mode is terrible. You clear the first 2 sets of solar systems, you managed to get a drone that works pretty well. You then keep that drone for the next 3 Sets of Solar systems giving small upgrades because some weapon looked cool. Then they go have you get your warp-drive that was stolen. Suddenly the games difficulty just skyrocketed with that mission. Everything up to that mission was relatively easy with exceptions of some missions which are just stupid hard (giant earth snake). They need to force the player to progress more to where they are actually equipped for that mission. If the progression was better, Id recommend this game entirely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028003552', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3459, 'last_played': 1693855366}
review:
I'd buy it again, but the game seems more focused to the sandbox mode.  There are a lot of parts, and a ton of options to play with in the tech tree... however...

The singleplayer campaign gets repetitious.  There's the mission to...
- gather 5 barrels
- gather 5 mantas
- destroy the beacon
- kill some sprites
- destroy the nests
- destroy the eggs of the giant snake monster
- and destroy the giant snake.

These repeat themselves over and over through the maps.  Initially, the reason for doing the missions is the reward for repairing your ship, or acquiring new build parts.  Some missions require things you don't have initially (such as a magnet to tow things into cargo, or using fire to light torches).  This limiting factor pushes you to build new ship designs (which is great).  However, after playing with two of the "captains", I find that you can beat the missions with relatively simple designs.  You end up with thousands of unused Tritium (the currency for building vessels greater than your part limit) and one multi-purpose vessel that does everything.  I expected that there'd be missions that forced me to change that up, or required me to create massive vessels (as depicted in the trailer), but that wasn't the case.  They also give you an amazing array of "logic" parts that seems to allow for automated drones, however, no mission presents itself where this is needed.

Put simply, the author of this game has created a lot of really cool parts for creating ships, but hasn't polished out a story/campaign that matches it.

It is fun, if a little disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013055491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1594475587}
review:
Nimbatus is a glorious mix between a 2D mining/fighting space game, and a drone construction simulator (think like a mix between SPAZ and Cargo!).
It is simple enough to take in hand but seem (so far) hard to master, having to understand each parts behaviour and its RPG/Roguelite elements (lots like F.T.L.) in order to progress efficiently in the campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561198426179265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 2830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2830, 'last_played': 1592430560}
review:
我終於把程序員模式破關了！謝謝開發者給我的遊戲體驗。
優點：燒腦，組合自己的自動化飛船好玩，然後看著飛船跑有成就感
缺點：
１沒有可自由設定的變數，我簡直把鍵盤上的按鍵都用完了
２每次過關危險指數增加，然後有機率被強制減少生命值，這點太不友善了，給個技巧性迴避方法好嗎？
３零組件提示太少（教學過少），我有一半的時間都花在熟悉怎麼用，沒自己去百度貼吧找用法根本不會
４遊戲流程單調，就是去下個星系解任務，然後解任務，自由度太低了吧
總結：有特色，好玩，但不友善

review:
It's fun in the beginning and then you realize all the missions are very similar. then there are weird design choices. For instance many enemies are hard to get close to, since they explode or overheat your shit. Problem is  long range weapons are super rare, so you have a bunch of close range weapons. If your ok with 8-10 hours of fun and then a rapid fall into monotony and frustration then go ahead otherwise I say skip this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961099711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1625310909}
review:
I wanted to like this and want to see it succeed. The core parts seem to all be there and I love the idea of building drones to solve problems. I was interested in the survival game mode mainly, but was not impressed. 

The drone building UI has room for improvement. Sometimes, drones I made would just spaz out in defiance of physics and need to be redesigned. Parts are too scarce to be creative with problem solving and drone design, and you'll spend too much time picking up essentials like batteries and regular engines over cooler toys. Missions are bland enough that a single superdrone can complete all the missions, and experimenting with optimized drones for specific missions is punished by the game. The missions themselves aren't terrible but you're also expected to scour the map for minerals, and that's not only super tedious, but means every drone you make needs to be able to collect minerals. 

Despite that, this game does feel very close to being a gem, with a bit more polish I hope it can shine.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969363716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 4607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3715, 'last_played': 1679175818}
review:
Nimbatus is a delightful physics sandbox disguised as a top-down shooter. Your enjoyment of it will be greatly determined by how much you enjoy puzzle solving, instead of how good you are at pewpew combat.

As a puzzle game for builders and programmers, Nimbatus has plenty to offer. You can dive right into the single player story as multiple classes, all of which have perks that drastically alter their playstyle. Or you can dive right into asynchronous multiplayer and upload autonomous drones to compete with other players.

Players looking to pilot their drones manually will find plenty of different loadouts to choose from, while players that want to treat the game as one giant puzzle game can dive right into the Programmer class and have nearly unrestricted building -- at the cost of requiring their drones to be fully autonomous. The cost of failure for most missions tends to be fairly minimal and forgiving, encouraging the player to step up their game and keep perfecting their designs instead of trying to grind through simpler tasks.

Folks looking to build their own personal Gradius and dive into challenging space combat will likely be greatly disappointed by this game. Combat falls very much on the easy side with the right drone layouts, with certain quirks of the physics engine making most missions relatively straightforward to solve with simple targeting and movement logic (even with basic components). There are a few interesting minibosses and certain harder missions awaiting you as you progress, giving these players something to chew on, but the game for the most part leans heavily on its sandbox experience instead of providing a structured combat experience.

The multiplayer modes of the game deserve special note, because they're probably the most fun certain players will have in this game. At this writing, five modes are available: Timed Race, Sumo, Race, Brawl, and Catch. All modes require autonomous drone designs uploaded by other players, which are then matchmade and downloaded asynchronously.

Each of these demands different strategies to achieve even your first win. Completing a tournament (which, except for Timed Race, is single elimination against 10 randomly matched opponents in a row) can be considered a major accomplishment. For example, I'd personally been working on my Sumo design since the earliest early access builds, and only completed my first tournament successfully in the past week.

Winning, however, is not the only point of these competitive modes. You can also create wildly bizarre or hilarious designs and just see how they do. Several of my designs featuring magnets and spinners have provided hours of entertainment just watching how they handle an opposing bot, playing out similarly to competitive TV shows like Robot Wars. Needless to say, this is good for a game that leans heavily on its physics sandbox and open-ended building system.

All this is to say, buy this game while it's on sale. It's come a long way since early access, and it's enough of a strong recommend as a builder and puzzle title to not be skipped.

review:
自律化されたドローンが作成可能というアイディアは魅力的なので悪いゲームではないのだろうと思うのだが、やってみると、ドローンを壊さぬようチマチマとした操作をしながら資源を回収するというステージが面倒になってしまい、イマイチハマらないまま積んでいる。

グローバル実績データでも0%の実績が幾つか並ぶくらい、プレイヤーの実績取得率がとても低い（最初のドローンを作成出来たプレイヤーが40%、チュートリアル終了プレイヤーが8.8%）ので、自分と同じく最初の方で投げ出すプレイヤーが多いのだろうと思う。買ったゲームの実績はなるべく100%を目指したい自分としては早めに見切りをつけて返金すればよかったと後悔している一作。

author: {'steamid': '76561198048128018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2491, 'last_played': 1616840936}
review:
Nimbatus really hits all the right notes with a builder game living inside a physics-based world. Your ship's mass, thrusters and turning/handling all work together with your ship build in a believable but more importantly "fun" way.  It won't take long to realize having side thrusters away from the ship offers great handling at the cost of some stability. Moving thrusters to the front and back of the ship just feels right and different in the handling. 

This is a very well-polished professional game. The UI is attractive, clear in intent and easy to use. Questionable ship design decisions are highlighted and explained. There is an entire test flight area to not only try out your ships before entering a mission, but with options inside the simulator to mimic the mission environment you're about to embark on.

The "planets" are destructible terrain so your poorly designed ship with no reverse won't truly get stuck too often. I'm not deep into the game yet but looking forward to more. I do hope there's a mechanic / ship part to easily bump my ship off of a stuck terrain position moving forward.

Often these types of games land me in a play-level where my ship creation is working in "platformer" display mode dealing with a ground-line below me. Although this is enjoyable, it always feels a bit off to me personally. I would love to see Nimbatus be THAT game that adds a new mission "type" that's wholly top-down. Old-school spaceship or flight game bombing run missions against enemy bases, yo. Remove gravity from that mission type's gameplay and focus on air resistance against the mass of the ship. You could have top-down bombing missions, sleek racing runs, resource grabs, etc. This would effectively double the considerations in making your ship designs. 

A racing run with my ship design relying on my major thrusters in the back and just enough side-thrusters to lean turns without slamming me into an oncoming mountain with too many enemies to handle snipping at my backside while I try to drop the bomb at just the right . . .

author: {'steamid': '76561198334407215', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1345, 'last_played': 1589877405}
review:
这是我第一个给差评的游戏
对于喜欢沙盒类游戏的我来说，这游戏并没有想象中那么好
游戏有三种模式：冒险模式，沙盒模式，联机模式
      0宣传片里的无人机也只是中看不中用罢了，实际游戏中你需要考虑的因素太多，那样的无人机太笨重，转向不灵活，受到一些生物攻击时完全没有办法
      1冒险模式下你根本不会做出像宣传片中那样华丽的无人机，原因是发射无人机会根据组件的数量花费元素，而完成一次任务所给的元素很少，你完全可以使用更简单的无人机完成任务。
      2其次程序员人物太鸡肋，你不可能做出能够同时完成任务、搜集资源、躲避大型生物、不需要操控的无人机，甚至有时候连单纯的完成任务都不可能。
      3沙盒模式，沙盒模式基本上是用来测试无人机的，像是宣传片里的无人机也只能在沙盒模式下完成了，我想要的是在正常的游戏流程中一步步升级自己的无人机，逐渐建造成豪华的无人机，你却说我只能在沙盒里造着玩，这有什么意思

author: {'steamid': '76561198844247957', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1589638931}
review:
说实话我并不会推荐这个游戏。我以前做过一点虚拟机器人项目，打开这游戏进入新手教程的时候满心以为可以做出各种各样适应不同任务的无人机。结果游戏呈现给我的是相当受限制的配件和让人感觉别扭的操作方式。虽然这都是你自己配置的引擎触发键位，但是结构上的限制显然过于多了。在有限的配件里，你的想象力实际上并不能发挥出更多。

而且游戏里有一个危险水平，你每一次执行任务都会增加该水平。水平高了你的母船就会被攻击，多了就gameover。这给了玩家一种压迫感和在有限关卡内搜集更多资源的驱动力。这个设计没有问题，但是数值上我觉得过于高了。

比如说有些任务显然你是不想只走一趟的。比如消灭虫子完以后你可能会想去采矿，这时候可能需要不同的无人机。但是你每一次部署都会使水平上涨。如果你造了一个很大的全能的可以执行各种任务的无人机，那你的资源消耗速度会高的离谱。

后来我又开了无限部署资源的职业，满怀着随意发挥建造想象力的希望，结果发现这游戏给的自由度并没有那么高。指令传递的自由度小得离谱，在这个游戏里指令是靠输出指定键位的信号实现的。为了实现一个多部件的协同功能我需要记住看各种各样的键位。设计时也没有整体的事件触发流程图，简直就是一种折磨。

最后一点，这个游戏的关卡重复度实在太高了。前期你过不去完全是因为不了解打法，到后来简直就是不停地重复偷蛋、杀虫、采矿、吸化石，无非是增加了一些地图难度而已。

总之还是比较失望的。在大更新（希望有吧）之前我是不会碰这游戏了。
