author: {'steamid': '76561197971948490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 1049, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1589503742}
review:
Read the full review here: https://saveorquit.com/2020/05/15/review-nimbatus-the-space-drone-constructor/

As someone rather fond of free-form construction games, Nimbatus is an interesting game, although it doesn't quite achieve all I would like.  The screenshots show off extremely complex drones like giant snakes that go off the screen like you could build those, but in practice, you have to pay a premium to field a drone larger than a relatively small number of parts. (Starting at just 20.)  Hence, you generally just want to go with the same bare minimum drones at all times unless forced to do otherwise.  You [i]can[/i] program your own drones, but most of the time, that makes them more complicated while adding nothing, so unless you want to go for making the game more difficult on yourself for no reason, it's always better to take the simpler self-piloted drones that are much less interesting to play.

The "main" mode is Survival Mode, which is effectively a roguelite where you have to acquire parts through doing missions while every action you take on the systems map raises "Threat" that is a % chance of your main ship taking damage.  Run out of hull points, and you lose with permadeath.  Changing planets raises Threat, and every time you send a drone out, there's more Threat and chances for hull damage.  Everything else is randomized, however.

"Multiplayer" of a sort exists, however, aside from time trial races, what you do is create fully programmed drones that you upload to Steam and then download your competitor's drone to have them duke it out completely based upon their prior programming.  Hence, you don't ever need to be online with another person to be competing. 

This works out fine in theory, but there's a problem in the application, as you really don't have the kind of complete creative freedom that some other creation games give you in practice when there's a glaringly obvious superior way to do things that is often simpler.  Sure, you could make a massive, expensive drone, but a simple one is generally better.  You could make a programmed drone, but unless they force you to program the drone for the specific mode you're in, it's simpler, cheaper, and much, much faster to just pilot it yourself so you feel like an idiot for going the extra mile to program a drone you didn't have to instead of feeling clever for solving a hard puzzle that way.  Even among programmed drones, you could make a drone that has large thrusters and steers towards a target and avoids hazards along the way, but all the time and effort you spent on that is wasted in competitive mode because the drone that just uses vector thrusters and blindly plows through hazards will beat you four races out of five (the fifth being if it actually is destroyed in a hazard), anyway, making you look like an idiot again just for trying to play the game the way it was promised to let you play.  

In general, there are also problems with the game communicating itself to the player properly.  Many parts have one sentence tooltips that read out sentences like, “Logic Connector: Provides wireless connection to the main part. Key events will be forwarded.” There are also several mission types whose requirements are utterly impossible to infer from the mission description.  For example, if you're told to recover an artifact from behind a force field, you need a flamethrower because the way to get through the field is to light braziers.  (Note that weapon drops are random, so you have no guarantee of getting any fire weapons.)  Basically, you have to read the wiki to understand what you're supposed to be doing, because the game doesn't tell you.

Further, survival mode is largely just the same set of randomized missions over and over again.  This would incentivize experimentation if the threat meter didn't overtly punish any failure and force you to stick to tested, "safe" methods as much as possible.  In short, once you have a working drone for a specific mission, you shouldn't ever change it except to make it bigger and more of whatever it is, and never ever get creative in this creativity game... It overtly rewards playing the game in the most boring, grindy way possible.

This also extends to drone construction and programming being fairly clunky.  Every thruster defaults to the "W" key (or hwatever you set up to be forward) to activate, even when you're trying to set them up as turning thrusters, so remember to program each one.  You can't program more than one key to a given thruster, either.  This gets worse with programmed drones, however, as every single input or output of a sensor, logic gate (which [b]EVERY BOOLEAN OPERATION REQUIRES ITS OWN SEPARATE PART AND CAN BE SEPARATELY DESTROYED[/b]), or operational part like thrusters or weapons requires their own separate key coded to it (even if you aren't pressing these keys), and they don't allow shift-key instructions.  There's an achievement for having over 100 gates in a ship, but there's only 101 keys on a qwerty keyboard...  What this game desperately needs is some kind of flowchart that lets you track what all of these keys are, because this is a programming game where you have to click each individual part to track down what inputs and outputs they have if you didn't perfectly plot out your extremely complex programmed drone.

All of this isn't to say that this game can't be fun, or that the problems are structural and can't be patched into a better shape, as I'm obviously giving it a positive review even as I criticize it.  (I especially hope there are changes to Catch, since the whole purpose of that mode is to make you evade the obstacles, and the obstacles are too weaksauce to make anyone bother, rendering the whole mode much stupider.)  The problem lies more in that this is a game that has a very steep learning curve and throws you in the deep end competing with the Kickstarter backers that have been all-in since before this game popped up on Steam, so anyone hearing about this game now has a long climb to catch up, and the game isn't designed to make that journey any easier. I have hope that this game will make me revise this review and be much more glowing about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988050129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1589908335}
review:
Игра прикольная. Но баланс никакой, хотел даже дизу поставить, но всё же больше плюсов.

Минусы которые затронули меня:
1) Ресурсов очень мало на планетах, какой смысл в вариации дрона, когда ты его нормально снарядить не можешь. 
2) Забыл назначить кнопку на деталь дрона, обратно в ангар и снова плати за вылет. Хотя-бы сделали если все детали дрона целы, то в ангар он бесплатно может вернуться. 
3) Постоянные и не как не зависящие от игрока атаки головного корабля во время перелётов, прям бесят и так ресурсов нет, так ещё и это, никакой отпор дать ни можешь и повлиять вообще, только пиратам заплатить. Ну реально какой смысл в этом? Какая интрига? 
4) Застреваешь за мелкий не видимый глазу кусочек земли. Можно задать минимальный размер оторванной частице.
5) При подготовке дрона на планету, не понятно как сильно его нужно будет снаряжать. Процент угрозы ни о чём не говорит. Хоть бы шкала была, ну типо "вы слишком много тратите на эту планету".

author: {'steamid': '76561198440310790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1590583616}
review:
我要把好评改成差评，这个游戏的生存模式显然还是个半成品。

这个游戏的主体应该是生存模式，但生存模式并不是那么平衡。

生存模式简直就是硬核Rogue，而且对一周目新手非常不友好。红石的数量少得可怜，船体越修越贵，且价格上升幅度实在过大，修一次就上升20，你们知不知道有的星球连10个石头都没有？我Normal研究员一上来导航点满，从没爆过机，精打细算玩到4#都快破产了，你让我Hard怎么玩？

就更不用说有很多很不合理的设定：
完成任务很容易就会点到屏幕边缘一秒回家资源全丢；
资源星球限制时间不说居然还有必须要用钻头才能采的坚硬内核，还只能采一次，读档回来就没了；
视角过窄导致被屏幕外的槌头鱼直接狙击断身；
玩家能把无人机修成灭星机器，却无法在Nimbatus上装点自卫武器；
被Nimbatus伤害后危机度居然不归零而是掉到60%，而80%以上的危机就可能会被再次伤害，这剩下的20%，你指望玩家跳一次星球就攒够100多红石？你在开玩笑吧？

以上这种设定严格限制了玩家的自由度，越到后期就要屯越多的红石，经常是走错一步就会破产，明明是长期游戏，居然还没有搭载单独存档功能，玩家强退SaveLoad无用，我就问问，我就玩一个建造养成突突突的游戏，有必要冒着20多个小时这么大的风险精打细算吗？

官方似乎要发布1.1版本了，如果以上问题不改直接退坑，差评就永久保留。

author: {'steamid': '76561198018101673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1378, 'last_played': 1650154374}
review:
Nimbatus takes something quite a few other games have done before, ship building, and offers it in the confines of a survival mode somewhat reminiscent, yet different, from that of Faster Than Light. Collect parts, balance speed, weaponry, and fuel, and annihilate planets using flamethrowers, missiles, or beams, or just every weapon you can staple on to the front of your ship.

One of the strongest moments of Nimbatus isn't when your ship goes right, but when your ship goes wrong. Seeing how your ship fails, or having part of it get blasted off, can change the context of your mission dramatically. Losing thrusters on one side of your ship may mean you cannot turn left for the entire rest of that mission, so you might struggle to awkwardly clamber your way through the last couple points of your objective with two thirds of a burning pile of rubble.

Missions in Nimbatus are quite varied, and although individual missions can be fairly simple, you may have to keep updating, upgrading, and manipulating your ship when you get to certain planets or you're given certain objectives.

I look forward to whatever else the developers may add to Nimbatus, but as it is it's a great, fully fledged game that I hope to play a lot more of.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128004692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1226, 'last_played': 1652326298}
review:
This is a game whose progress I have been following for quite a while. I first saw some of the physics demos on imgur a few years ago and I have to say I was and am Thouroughly impressed. 

The building system for drones is simple yet complex, with a lot of variation in weapons and damage effects. I have not gotten into the logic parts as of yet but from what I can its quite an expansive set of blocks. 

The missions in campaign mode are quite challenging and the pacing is similar to FTL.

My only criticism is that there could be a little better guidance on some of the missions, and after a couple of restarts of campaign mode, the component rewards are pretty random and you occasionally end up not having something you need.

Despite my criticisms I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes sandboxy building games like Minecraft, Teraria, Space Engineers, etc. 

13/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197973259758', 'num_games_owned': 678, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1589851649}
review:
Nimbatus is a game that I really should have enjoyed. Creating and piloting drones to perform a variety of tasks is right up my alley. Unfortunately, the game pushed back really hard on my anticipation. I'll focus on two aspects of the game that produced the biggest problems.

First, the mission objectives are rarely that interesting, but I would have preferred a small variety of combat encounters over the tasks I was actually given, which were frequently boring or even frustrating. Destroy 3 bee hives? You'll get swarmed if you get too close, so take them out at a distance. Need to fetch something on an ice planet? The ice blocks will freeze you if you get too close, so... take them out at a distance. Destroy three Boombugs? They'll explode and destroy you if you get too close, so... you get the idea.

Or, you may have to fight the Boombug Queen. It can't be damaged on the front, so you have to shoot it for about 5 seconds until it turns around and flees, exposing its weak backside. Keep your distance so you don't get hit and instantly killed, but if you strayed too far, then you won't be able to catch up and hit it in the back for very long before it turns back around and becomes invincible again. Even if you do everything optimally, you can only kill the queen after about 4 of these cycles. And the first time I killed it, the on-death explosion was a lot larger than I had anticipated, so I had to respawn and do it again. It wasn't fun the first time. It wasn't fun the second time.

On another mission, I had to retrieve 3 ice mantas. To put it in very simple terms, this is a below-average escort mission (yes, even by escort mission standards). You fly near the creature, and it follows you back to your carrier... at about a third of your normal speed. If a shot from you or an enemy should happen to hit it, then it spawns ice flies which can freeze and disable parts of your ship, such as your thrusters. This means an already slow and frustrating escort mission has a decent chance of becoming even more slow and frustrating.

In addition, you can mine and collect resources from some planets. This is as boring as it gets. Vacuum up some space rocks until your container is full., drop them off at the carrier, repeat. Obviously, you have the option of just skipping the hassle, but this game is a roguelike. Leaving resources on the table is a surefire way to hinder your progress one, two, or three hours in the future. No game should ever force its players to choose between effectiveness and fun.

On that note, my second problem with the game is the weapons. The kinetic blaster every ship starts with is ideal for the beginning of a run: It's effective, versatile, and boring. And yes, I actually think that last one is ideal for a weapon at the start of a game. Give the player something that works well, but is less interesting than the upcoming weapons. That way, getting something new is both exciting and an improvement!

Unfortunately, after about 4 hours of play, I have not encountered a single weapon that could match the damage output of the basic blaster. I've probably accumulated over 20 flame throwers, ice throwers, lasers and shotguns. They do a good job of encouraging alternate playstyles... for those cases I should ever feel like being less effective in combat. I do have the option of just supplementing my existing weapon set with more guns (quantity over quality). However, this runs into two major problems: First, you have a limited amount of weapon energy, so more guns means you just drain it faster. Second, you are charged a flat rate per item every time you launch a drone, so you are encouraged to launch only with what you need, rather than loading up with everything you find every chance you get. Again, I'm being asked to compromise between effectiveness and fun.

This all culminated in a moment that exposed a serious flaw in the weapon design. A moment that really broke me.

I took a mission on a challenging side area, on the promise of receiving an epic level weapon. It's the most powerful a weapon can get. It has THREE upgrades. This HAS to be an improvement. It's gonna be GOOD.

My objective is to take out three shield generators, exposing the enemy bunker to destruction. I get one of the generators,  then happen to pass by the bunker. It's still shielded, but I decide to eliminate some of the enemy drones flying around while I'm in the neighborhood. One of bunker's turrets fires a tractor beam, sucking me in. It pulls me right up to the impenetrable shield, leaving me exposed to the other turrets inside. They keep shooting at me, and there's nothing I can do in response. The tractor beam never lets me go, and I can't fly away or shoot back at my attackers. I die.

But I'm gonna give it another shot. I have an epic weapon to win. It's gonna be GOOD.

My second run goes fine. I know that I'm not supposed to go anywhere near those tractor beams, so I fire at them from a distance (remember that?). I destroy the bunker. Mission accomplished. My reward? An arc thrower with freezing bolts. It has three upgrades: First, increase digging speed, so I can burrow through rock more quickly. That's not really helpful most of the time, but... okay. Second, an increase in range... so I can get in some more of those super fun long-distance shots. And the third upgrade: Finally, something that modifies my damage output significantly! Damage output -100%.

Minus one hundred percent damage. ZERO damage. This weapon CANNOT hurt enemies. This is the third UPGRADE on this thing. Why is this even a possibility? I felt like the game kicked me in the shin. And it's not the first time I've received something completely ineffective. One of the lesser weapons I received had -100% velocity. Pressing the fire button would produce a round that would literally not move. Call me old-fashioned, but I prefer my projectiles to actually project towards the enemy.

Ultimately, none of my time with the game felt even a little bit satisfying. The missions are more disheartening than they are challenging, and the rewards for completing them will clutter your inventory more than they will enrich your experience. At no point did I get the beating-the-Dark-Souls-boss thrill. Instead, I continually felt like I had just finished my business at the DMV. And when that's over with, the last thing I want to do is go back inside and repeat the encounter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980122566', 'num_games_owned': 1801, 'num_reviews': 713, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1593257613}
review:
Оценка игры: 45/50.
Это первый взгляд на игру. Делюсь с вами моим первым впечатлением не имея более глобального опыта прохождения данного проекта.

Неожиданно, но это оказался очень продуманный и крайне играбельный продукт выполненный в таких жанрах, как конструктор и космический симулятор. Пиксельная графика тут как нельзя кстати и лишь подчеркивает, что не смотря на годы данный визуальный стиль не умрет никогда. Всеподавляющая разрушаемость мира, бесконечный простор для воображения, четкие и работающие физические законы. Игра предлагает нам взять на себя роль инженеров: думать, балансировать, созидать и экспериментировать. Однозначно рекомендую тем, кому нравятся такие игры, как Space Engineers, Crossout и т.п.

Подробнее об игре, её сильных и слабых сторонах можно узнать из моего стрима.
Подписывайся и присоединяйся к прямым эфирам!
https://youtu.be/cA3pNiL53Hk?t=552

review: 虽然很像市面上的其他创造类游戏，但我觉得尼姆巴图能让我一直玩着的一个原因就是足够简单容易上手，画面也没有那么让人容易累，不像有的游戏会用繁琐的机制和复杂的教程让我在1个小时内失去兴趣。但与此同时，简单易上手并不代表这款游戏就没什么可玩的，尼姆巴图的上下限是随着每个人的想象力不同而有所区别的。

review:
这是一个差评改过的好评，差评原因是频繁崩溃闪退。游戏非常好玩。

原因已找到，还真是360的锅。关了360啥毛病没有。

游戏是unity引擎开发，我也玩其他unity游戏，但是没有因为360导致的崩溃。

看了贴吧还有因为windows自带杀软崩溃的。。。

希望开发者找找问题，总不能因为玩一个游戏要关掉360或者windows defender吧。

一个游戏不能逼迫玩家改变电脑使用习惯是不是？

不过总算能玩了，还是好评推荐吧！因为的确好玩。

最后再重复一下，为了玩游戏而关闭其他习惯后台开着的软件，不管是不是360，不管360是不是垃圾，这都是不对的。

author: {'steamid': '76561198026040901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1589763381}
review:
Finished it in a few hours and after that seems like a pointless grind to no end goal

The good:
-Mechanics; Physics are great and the way the game its self operates is very well structured
-Customization; Easy to grasp custom building of drones, there is even logic parts to make things automated for advanced users
-Music; I like the overall feel the music gives the game
-Borrows from FTL on its core gameplay mechanic

The Bad:
-Music is limited on the amount of variety you will hear
-Drone building becomes a side feature after you build a drone that can "do all" 
-Playstyles are limited to what works effectively, such as playing as the miner you can easily upgrade the mothership to its full potential and have resources to spare. With other captains resource gathering is a chore until you unlock enough Gigadrills to make an effective mining drone or use lasers with digging upgrades but the RNG probably wont let that happen unless you play the researcher and get it manually.
-Very little challenge once you grasp how the game operates, missions are the same or very similar and the objectives tend to make things feel like a chore, such as just simply leading an Ice Manta back to your collector after you removed all threats from the planet
-Missions are redundant and lack a proper challenge once you know what to expect, there are some twists involved that you will occasionally run into on special locations off the main path but there's only one that was worth the time to go to and I wont mention due to spoilers.
-Weapons are have some variety but some are basically useless, Bio weapons are simply annoying and served little purpose to me and I tried to avoid them
-Rewards are just random blocks that have a possibility of being a part of a mission that you complete, they do give you a choice on what you get by being able to see the rewards for multiple missions and they don't properly scale. I can do a "hard" mission and get 3 thrusters and a small structural block and then go to the next sector with an "easy" mission and pick up 3 rare random weapons with 4 upgrade slots and a medium fuel tank
-The overall graphics are good but most of the animations and transitions are lacking in overall flair and feel, I can volley a giant wall of bullets against an enemy all at once only for the enemy to just "pop" and smoke away. Your ship flies to a planet and settles just above it and then suddenly your drone is deployed after you select it, little things like that when done properly and efficiently are what help make a game feel alive and this one is lacking.
-The random encounter system suffers the same issues with the rest of the content, it feels like there are a total of 5 things that can happen; 1. You get a distress signal for: A destroyed ship, B derelict ship, C pirate ship, D Nebula, E a shop, F 
a garage, or you can 2. You encounter a pirate, 3. You encounter the main antagonist and the last one I remember encountering was 4. A drone slams into your ship causing damage. That is it and if this game is going to go up against a game with massive RNG baseline such as FTL it seriously doesn't come close to FTL.
-The overall length of the game in survival mode feels short and can easily be blown through in a few hours if you know what you're doing and after that it just becomes a roguelike, the endgame mission is hardly complex and requires very little work at all. After the endgame mission is over it feels like there is zero reason to play again and each captain can be played nearly the same with the same end result minus the mastermind which is obvious.

Game has great potential but it desperately needs a face lift to inject some diversity of the game because its has a lot of repetition

author: {'steamid': '76561198122092726', 'num_games_owned': 3554, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 1650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1650, 'last_played': 1589813567}
review:
https://youtu.be/LBa48SR-s-s
[quote]
[h1]Więcej informacji w pełnej recenzji:[/h1]
http://hakimodo.pl/2020/05/19/r125-nimbatus-the-space-drone-constructor-recenzja-polaczenia-zabawy-w-budowanie-z-fizyka/
[/quote]

[h1]OCENA: POZYTYWNA = 8/10[/h1]
Tytuł ten mieszka w mojej bibliotece Steam już niemal dwa lata i przez ten czas nieco się zmienił. Z okazji wyjścia ze statusu Early Access postanowiłem go sobie znów odświeżyć. Wiele się w tej grze zmieniło – na plus. Gra już dawno temu była dopracowana a teraz została jeszcze przez autorów dopieszczona.

Myślę, że jest to dobry tytuł dla kogoś, kto lubi dłubać i bawić się wszelkimi ustawieniami. Mnie gra się spodobała – w szczególności to, że tworzony przez nas statek zależy od naszej wyobraźni. Możemy do niego dołożyć różne elementy i sprawić, że będzie latać lepiej… albo gorzej. To już trzeba sprawdzić na etapie prób samemu i nadać mu odpowiednią klawiszologię byśmy mogli bez problemu skręcać i walczyć z wrogiem.

Trzeba powiedzieć, że walki czasami są dosyć trudne i plansze dzielą się na bardzo proste gdzie musimy wyeliminować kilku wrogów lub coś zebrać, czy też nazbyt trudne, kiedy trzeba walczyć z licznymi przeciwnikami.

Najtrudniejsze były chyba poziomy z wężem gdzie po ubiciu jego jaj zaczyna on nas atakować – lub planety na których występuje płynne jądro i lawa oraz stworki, które nas rozgrzewają. Tam czasami zdarzało mi się paść…

Poziom trudności jakim jest NORMALNY jest dosyć zbalansowany. Nie jest jakiś łatwy ale nie jest też przesadnie trudny i jest do przejścia (ja przeszedłem). Kwintesencja gry tkwi właśnie w piaskownicy i możliwości zdefiniowania przez nas swojej własnej podróży.

Jeśli ktoś lubi takie budowanie z gotowych elementów to tytuł może mu się spodobać. Nimbatus jest jednym z ciekawszych tytułów i szczerze go Wam polecam.

Rozpoczynając grę możemy wybrać jednego z kapitanów, różniącego się parametrami. Najciekawsza gra będzie chyba w trybie programisty, gdy tworzymy takie autonomiczne drony, które poruszają się samodzielnie i nie sterujemy wtedy nimi ręcznie. Istnieją tu różne czynniki i tryb podążania za kursorem i wtedy można nieco sterować tym swoim statkiem ale cała zabawa polega na stworzeniu drona, który sam walczy. Powiem, że to jest dosyć ciężkie i będę jeszcze próbować opędzić ten tryb ponieważ jak na razie udało mi się wykonać jedynie część prostych misji ale ten mój dron nie do końca latał tak jak powinien. Ale jak sprawdzałem nagrania na YouTube to co niektórzy tworzyli nawet ciekawe drony.

Ciekawie wygląda także starcie robotów w trybie Sumo, gdy trzeba przeciwnika wypchać z areny. Interesująco wyglądają też wyścigi dronów autonomicznych. Jest to fajny kawałek gry w którym można się nieco pobawić w bycie konstruktorem. 
[list][h1]+++ PLUSY +++[/h1]
[*]ciekawy pomysł
[*]dużo możliwości konstrukcyjnych pojazdu
[*]prosta acz przyjemna dla oka grafika
[*]dosyć duże drzewo technologii do odkrycia
[/list]

[list][h1]— MINUSY —[h1]
[*]tryb wieloosobowy to tak naprawdę starcia z dronami wytworzonymi przez innych graczy a nie potyczka online.
[*]małe zróżnicowanie misji
[/list]

Gra umożliwia nam eksplorację proceduralnie generowanych systemów składających się z różnych planet. Na każdej z nich czekają na nas różnorakie zadania do realizacji różniące się poziomem trudności oraz samym celem misji. By temu sprostać gracz musi zbudować swój pojazd, który podoła postawionemu przed nami zadaniu.

Tytuł umożliwia rozgrywkę w trybie jednego gracza – realizując główny wątek gry – oraz w czymś na wzór trybu multiplayer w którym możemy zetrzeć się z maszynami stworzonymi przez innymi graczy w różnych odmianach wyścigów i potyczek.

W grze musimy stworzyć swój własny pojazd, którym będziemy realizować zlecone nam misje. Możemy stworzyć dowolną ilość takich pojazdów i wykorzystywać je w zależności od potrzeb i sytuacji. Możemy go zbudować za pomocą dostępnych części składowych, tj. silniki, pancerze i tak dalej – służy do tego specjalne okno konstrukcji.

Misje jakich będziemy mogli się podjąć są gatunku zniszczenia konkretnych budynków, gniazd zwierzęcych czy też eksterminacji konkretnych zwierząt. Prócz tego możemy mieć za cel zebranie oraz przetransportowanie niektórych przedmiotów znalezionych na planecie na nasz statek. Nie są nazbyt trudne o ile właściwie przygotujemy się na ich wykonanie i odpowiednio dobierzemy wyposażenie naszego statku. W trakcie rozgrywki wypełniając zlecone nam misje będziemy musieli ścierać się z wieloma przeciwnikami. Mogą być to owady rodzące się w gnieździe roju, działka znajdujące się na powierzchni planet czy też latające tu i ówdzie gromady wrogich dronów.

Prócz tego napotkamy różne utrudnienia w postaci zmiennych warunków pogodowych i środowiskowych. Planety mogą mieć różne rozmiary, cechować się odmienną grawitacją czy też siłą wiatru a także zakresem temperatur. Układy naszego statku mogą być narażone na zimno powodujące zmrożenie i blokadę lub nawet wyłączenie danych układów czy też palące ciepło powodujące rozgrzanie elementów i ich zniszczenie. Jeśli mowa o zimnie, to napotkane mrożące kryształy można zniszczyć i przestanie nas mrozić lecz lawa wypełniająca jądro planety i poszerzająca niekiedy swoją objętość to już problem przed którym trzeba będzie szybko uciekać…

Na planetach znajdziemy także czasami porozrzucane gromady surowców dwojakiego zastosowania. Żółty w postaci trytu jest niezbędny do ponoszenia kosztów przeciążenia rdzenia pojazdu jeśli użyjemy większej ilości komponentów niż dozwolone minimum. Czerwony w postaci Unobtanium służy do kupna komponentów czy też broni w odwiedzanych sporadycznie sklepikach oraz naprawy statku i zakupu doń ulepszeń w przypadku wizyt w garażu. O ile żółtego surowca jest w bród o tyle czerwone Unobtanium jest dosyć rzadkie i musimy się nieco napocić by je zebrać. Planety są generowane losowo więc różnią się pomiędzy sobą budową oraz występowaniem zagrożeń.


... pełna wersja recenzji dostępna jest na mojej stronie WWW (link na początku recenzji)

author: {'steamid': '76561198007484636', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1590372145}
review:
This is one of the most refreshingly original games I've played in a while! I definitely recommend it! 

Short description: 
- You use parts to build "drones" (mini-ships) to go on short missions on different planetary bodies. Different missions require different kinds of parts. 
- In survival mode, you are the captain of the Nimbatus spaceship, and are trying to evade the evil Corps spaceships that are looking for you to try to blow your ship up. Doing missions at the different worlds unlocks new or more parts for you to use in your drones, and they sometimes unlock other perks. 

What it feels like: 
- The overarching premise feels *very much* like "FTL: Faster Than Light", since you're hopping from system to system and trying to avoid evil ships. There is a fun variety of neutral shops, and there are pirates that can be paid off to help you evade the Corps. 
- Some robot-building game that's tucked away in the corner of my memory...familiar, but not quite. 

Awesome Things: 
- Drone-building is a fun idea, and it's rewarding/satisfying when I make a great ship for a mission. 
- There's a good variety of missions. They're usually intuitive enough. They're fun, too! 
- The controls are very unusual at first, but surprisingly satisfying once I became comfortable with them and built a drone chassis that worked for me. 
- You can choose to play one of 6 (?) different captains, which can really change the gameplay. Awesome idea! 
- Resource planets are an awesome and fun idea! It's kinda silly, but a fun mini-game that is very satisfying and appropriately balanced. 
- The weapon research tree (for the Researcher/Scientist captain) is AWESOME. I haven't played the other Captains yet, but it's hard to imagine them being better than this. 

Things that became awesome after time:
- Initially, I would have said maneuverability ought to be improved, but after several hours (and finding a basic layout that works for me), I think it's actually really good the way it is! It makes sense that early ships are slow and/or not maneuverable. You simply lack parts at that point. 

Bugs:
- The resource collector graphics are glitchy on my MacBook Pro (possibly related to sprites having the same z-offset/layer?). 
- I have not encountered any real gameplay bugs! 

Gameplay Tweaks / Wishlist:
- I'd love to see my ship -- or at least its outline -- while inside the resource collector. Otherwise, without seeing my ship's orientation, it's easy to get trapped in there. 
- I'd like to see some more tutorial about elemental damage. 
- Lava worlds seem to be way imbalanced in terms of resources. Most lava worlds I've seen have several hundred of each resource type. They're dangerous, but not *that* dangerous. 
- In spite of drone-building being a central element to the game, I don't find myself changing my drones THAT often. I have a basic design that I rarely improve upon. Sure, I'll put on a magnet, throw on a cryo or plasma weapon, or add a heater/cooler as appropriate, but otherwise it's all the same. Perhaps that's just because I found a ship design that is maneuverable, and it's hard to move away from that. 
- It wasn't always clear to me how to complete certain missions. For instance, I didn't realize that a fossil would be buried, since previous missions had always been on the surface. Also, I didn't realize what a magnet would be for. 
- Some more tips would be useful -- both for parts (what they are used for) and for missions (is a magnet required/recommended?).
-More mission types would be fun. The game has AWESOME potential, and delivers in a lot of ways. However, the mission variety is a little lower when compared to similar games like FTL -- at least in my experience. For example, there may be 2-3 planetary bodies in a given system that have the exact same mission. 
- I'd love for some of the perks of the different captains to be unlockable at mid/late game. For instance, if I were the Pilot, I'd love to be able to gain access to the Researcher's weapon tech tree. I'd love to be able to get a weaker version of the Engineer's drill, and ESPECIALLY the remote resource dropbox! 
- Another captain idea: an elemental specialist. Bonuses to all elemental damage, resistance to elements, and maybe even a unique elemental weapon that has the ability to do multiple elemental damage types (choose damage type while piloting via different keys).

review:
Fun game at the start but later gets more and more annoying, I don't think the missions are equivalent to the level you start with, good idea bad execution.

I couldn't reply to Dev response so i'm editing below this line.
To be hones it's very engaging and fun but the lack of crucial explanations makes it really confusing, for example the icemantas mission you have no idea what are those, is it the white crystal? is it a box that drops somewhere but when you go all the way to the very far end you finally realize it's an animal. 
Other vague issue is the items description, like the afterburner, even google didn't answer me and I had to go to discord and ask people there to finally realize it's something of no concern until later on when you can get higher speed. 
I don't mind not getting explanation for like movement and how to right click but also It would really help a lot to know how to get an objective in a mission or little more details on crucial items.

Thank you for the concern. 
I'll give it another shot, although scavenging for info is not my idea of fun I hope it will be worth it. :)

We also started a Wiki with all the elements we have in the game (drone parts, missions, enemies, etc.) and we have to check if we can somehow cross-reference that library in the game somehow. It will take some time as there are so many elements, but we'll get there eventually :)

https://nimbatus.fandom.com/wiki/Nimbatus_Wiki

(at point of writing this, the wiki is still in development, but I'll leave the link here for the future when it's more complete)

I'll write back here if we published the next update which addresses the things you have mentioned here :)

Thank you for your feedback, your support and cheers,
Markus :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970491058', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1589763658}
review:
Nimbatus is a modular spaceship builder that's all dressed up with nowhere to go. The core space ship construction engine has lots of interesting components and plenty of promise. Unfortunately, the procedurally generated survival "campaign" missions are dreadfully shallow, repetitive, and ultimately feel like work.

The game design in general suffers from a lot of flaws. For example, rather than encouraging drone design  experimentation, Nimbatus missions penalize failure for each mission attempt. Player progression in the campaign is primarily demarcated by unlocking drone parts, with which the game is exceptionally stingy. So much so, that I completed the campaign having unlocked only a handful of parts, and not enough to build anything with meaningful complexity.

I completed the campaign (including the tutorial) using the miner captain in about 6 hours. The campaign consisted of repeating the same 3 or 4 mission templates 15 or so times.  It also fails to push the player to evolve drone design much at all. I ended up using the same drone for everything, with minor upgrades as parts became available. The game promises different play style experiences with each of the other 4 captains, but the thought of yet another tedious mission to capture the same 3 ice mantas just leaves me devoid of any desire to try them out.

review:
ついに開発終了
日本語化されてます
ドローンを自分で操作しても良し
チップを使って自動化もよし
FTLみたいに惑星間をボスから逃げ進みながら資源回収していくゲームです

武器のバージョンアップは技術ツリーで開発した特性をそれぞれ貼り付けていくタイプ
超火力でオールキルにすると資源も全部吹っ飛んでしまうので特に自動化したドローンの場合
敵or資源or地面を判別して適切な武器を使わせる必要があります
ダメージ -100%の特性武器でも穴は掘れます
シールドはバッテリーを大量に使います
ノーマルブロックは超硬いですし素材を変更する事で高摩擦や無摩擦や耐熱や色々特性を持ちます
が総ブロック数が多くなればなるほど一回ごとの出費が跳ね上がっていきます
母艦の改良で軽減できますが

惑星毎のクリア目標毎に何パターンかのドローンを開発する方が効率がいいでしょう
欠点はセンサー類の説明がない

review:
I got this free as part of a developer stream key drop, and was in no way required to give a reviewer.

This is a fairly fun game so far.  It’s a bit of ftl with some ship design elements thrown in.  There is defiantly some polish to be made, I would like to see all the logic elements be placable on a separate layer from the normal parts. It is pretty annoying that a simple logic gate takes up the same space as weapons. I would also like to see a couple of alternate core shapes, all the designs feel a tad samy because all the basic shapes are the same. All in all it’s pretty good, defiantly grab on a sale, but consider full price if you love design games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142673728', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1589703259}
review:
The best way to progress in this game is to not have fun or convenience. Every time you deploy a drone you take damage (your threat level rises, which leads to loss of 25% health). The bigger your drone the more yellow crystals you pay. So in order to not waste resources (this is a roquelike) you have should only take the bare minimum. Fewer thrusters for turning, lower weapon count, little fuel etc. If you are damaged and can only crawl, just continue slower.

Imagine a game like Skyrim or Witcher 3, but using a horse or fast traveling costs money, dodging and power attacks cost XP, get the idea? As long as you do everything as slow and boring as possible, you get better results, because the only resource in this game that is free is the players time.

I think the devs wanted to do something like risk leading to reward but ended up with boredom leads to reward. Just wait for a few months until they figure it out. Or wait for a few years for them to figure it out even better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971829221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 858, 'last_played': 1590281046}
review: This is actually a very cool casual game!  It is simple to pick up, with a low learning curve, but still has a lot of rich content.  The missions can be somewhat redundant, probably due to being in pre-release.  I like the weapon choices and build options that make the drone options virtually endless.  I also like that the various environments have hazards which force you to give some thought when redesigning your drone to maximize survivability for a particular mission, or as you find/unlock new technologies and components.  Will you choose mobility/agility, or build a tank, and go for maximum firepower?  Or will you try to strike a balance?  So far, the game has been glitch free and has a decent sound track.  Overall score:  A-, due to the aforementioned redundancy, still a strong 4.5 / 5 stars.  Hoping to see a little more planetary, hazard, enemy, and mission variety in the full release, but the game and premise hold up pretty well in it's current state.

review: Nimbatus is a solid game where you can build fairly complex drones to complete tasks, this will unlock new parts you can then use to make bigger and badder drones.  The real hidden gem here is the programmer mode, where you are forced to have your drones autonomous and not be manually controlled in any way!  I've been really enjoying the challenge of building a drone that completes the objectives all by itself, its an amazing feeling to get through a mission in this way!

review:
Gioco rogue decisamente carino.
Trama, abbastanza consueta: la propria astronave è braccata da pirati spaziali che vogliono farla a pezzi e per tornare sulla terra deve attraversare svariati sistemi solari ed evitare di finire risorse o di essere catturata dai pirati.
Per ogni sistema solare, bisogna costruire un drone / atronave adatto all'habitat del pianeta ed inviarlo a raccogliere risorse.
L'officina dei droni molto ben fatta, ricorda il minigioco con la "gummy ship" di Kingdom Hearts I. Svariati pezzi e combinazioni, è come costruire con i Lego.
Le missioni per ora sembrano un po' ripetitive ma di sicuro serviranno ore di gioco per trovare le giuste combinazioni e riuscire a tornare a casa.
Sicuramente ottimo rapporto qualità prezzo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991297606', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1785, 'last_played': 1589654492}
review:
Почти 30 часов, и всё же отрицательный отзыв. 

По порядку. 
Плюсы.
- Тут можно собирать разные интересные дроны. Довольно много модулей. Можно сделать огромный автоматизированный mothership, можно сделать маленький и быстрый дрон, в который просто никто не попадёт.
- Процедурный мир, воксельные (?) планеты, которые можно бурить как угодно, вплоть до полного уничтожения.
- Приятная, немного мультяшная, но аккуратная 2D-графика.

И как-то на этом плюсы лично для меня закончились. Потому что дальше начинаются минусы.
- Игра скучная.
- Потому что задания однообразные. Буквально весь спектр имеющихся миссий можно увидеть в рамках одной галактики, а их тут десять. Десять разных галактик с совершенно одинаковыми миссиями.
- Потому что планеты маленькие. Они больше напоминают какие-то астероиды, на которых непонятно почему есть атмосфера, гравитация, и какая-то живность.
- Сюжет. Спойлерну самое начало: наш корабль летит куда-то в далёкие края, но его атакует корабль вражеской корпорации, и нас выбрасывает в неизвестной галактике, которой нет на карте\никто о ней ничего не слышал. Через два задания - "Мы поймали сигнал от гражданского судна!". Откуда оно там, блин? И их десятки в игре. Откуда десятки каких-то судов в никому неизвестной галактике?
- Данные игрой возможности некуда использовать. Разрабы сделали действительно интересные инструменты: в игре есть пружины, магниты, роторы, логические детали, возможность автоматизировать, но это всё не нужно для прохождения игры. Игра проходится одним кораблём с кучей лазерных пушек, чтобы бурить землю и врагов. В некоторых заданиях понадобится магнит и охладители\нагреватели, но эти задания можно скипать, они не требуются для прохождения дальше. И это самое печальное в игре. Детали есть, использовать почти некуда.


Игра забавляет и затягивает часов на 5-10. Этого достаточно, чтобы насытиться однообразием, построить какой-нибудь здоровенный дрон, который будет сквозь планету не тормозя буриться лазерами, и устать от однотипных сцен между перелётами, от однотипных планет, однотипных заданий, однотипных галактик и сюжета, который придумал ребёнок уборщицы в офисе разработчиков.

author: {'steamid': '76561198813712059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1643901256}
review:
10/10. Coup de cœur. Excellent jeu, difficulté de l'histoire bien dosée (Le mode facile vous donnera du fil à retordre).
Côté gameplay, en oscille entre Mass Effect (exploration des systèmes, mining) et le mod Warships de Starcraft (construction de vaisseau pièce par pièce). On ne se lasse pas d'y jouer pendant des heures.
Optez pour l'ingénieur, qui grâce à un découpleur obtient un vaisseau sans carburant, ni batterie, ni sac de collecte. Votre vaisseau est donc plus petit donc plus maniable. Autre avantage : La base (carburants, batteries, 1x sac de collecte), une fois que vous la séparez au début de chaque monde, tombe d'elle-même dans le collecteur avec la gravité, ce qui fait que tout minerai que vous aspirez est directement collecté (crédité sur votre compte). Plus besoin de faire des allers retours. Votre sac de collecte est automatiquement vidé car directement tombé dans le collecteur. Cool ! Ensuite, n'hésitez pas à ajouter plus de 10 pièces de vaisseau et payer le surplus, car le minerai jaune sert exclusivement à ça, et il y en a foison. Visez 50 pièces de vaisseau et plus. Montez sur votre vaisseau toutes les armes que vous trouvez. Vous détruirez ainsi les ennemis avant qu'ils ne vous touchent. Même batteries vides, vos lasers fonctionnent toujours.
Dernier point fort, le prix. C'est cadeau.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996470324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 13604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 663, 'last_played': 1680189855}
review:
If you are looking for a programming/engineering game in the vein of the Zachatronics series or Kerbal Space Program, this is not it. 

I wanted to like this game, but as a programmer I'm disappointed. My expectations for a "space drone constructor" are to be able to leverage clever program logic and engineering to prevail. Except... you can't. Competitive designs in this game revolve primarily around exploiting the glitches in Unity's wonky physics with a minimal amount of logic for navigation. 

To break down why this is so:

- Drone components can only be attached to one other component. This makes it difficult to create stable structures intuitively since the stresses are always placed on the parent element, rather than distributed through multiple supports. This is incredibly frustrating from an engineering standpoint, as it is near impossible to build trusses.

- The Unity physics engine isn't deterministic. While an element of randomness in play is fine, in a bleeding edge design this often results in advanced designs either exploding or performing amazingly, depending on your luck. There's even variance in different modes; sometimes a design that works fine in Test will explode in Tournament, and vice-versa.

- Structural components aren't necessary in designs. Competitive tournament designs often consist of just engine and fuel pods lashed together in whichever configuration keeps them from sheering apart... most of the time.

- Logic parts are mostly rudimentary gate logic, count against your ship's mass/part total, are vulnerable to being destroyed, and have a propagation delay that is too long to be relevant in competition designs. I'd love to see a simple scripting language implementation that you often see in games like this, but it's not here.

Other issues: 

- [strike]The editor doesn't have an option to "Exit without Saving".[/strike] Fixed in 1.1.1.

- Survival Mode's threat levels punish experimentation with drones by increasing the "threat" level every time you deploy and charging you resources. This discourages tweaking designs, outside of Programmer mode, as you're penalized for pulling out of a mission early. This mode also penalizes you by charging you more resources for larger drones, discouraging more complicated, more fun designs.

The game isn't terrible, as it's entertaining to test racing drone designs while working in another window, but I'd vastly prefer a game that encouraged learning engineering concepts and programming techniques than exploiting glitches. If the game's more glaring exploits were resolved, and survival mode re-balanced to be more friendly, the game would be good.

That said, I uploaded a number of overpowered, glitch exploiting designs to the competitive pool to help encourage the problems to be fixed. :)

review: 8 Horas de juego, y me resulto bastante entretenido el echo de armar un dron, pq no es una nave espacial, es un ermoso dron, y ahi es donde realmente me atrapo el juego, en ir mejorando el dron, usando logica y pensando en cuan eficiente, y se puede probar este dron en el taller, un tipo de simulacion, y lo mejor, es que el dron se puede volver automata, lo unico negativo que veo, es como se trabaja con las puertas logicas siendo bloques del dron, siendo que estas en un juego siempre se representan con poco costo y tan diminutas que ocupan otro espacio, en este juego ocupan como un bloque mas, por ejemplo uno de propulsor, y es muy tedioso esto porque se necesita un gran costo economico para tener grandes circuitos logicos, y esto implica un dron grande, cuando incluso en la vida real, los circuitos logicos son chicos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017628220', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1590260100}
review:
Amazing game. Lots of options to play/build. 
I suggest playing all the tutorials available (around 30-60min). After that its a bit of trying around since the tutorial doesn't cover every part. No problem imo, since you can swap between editor and "testground" in a blink (rapid prototyping?).
Survival mode is relaxing but challenging, a new mission/planet feels like a puzzle you can solve with many solutions (I really didn't expect some things to work the way they did^^).
Multiplayer is fun too. At least the building part, watching can be a bit boring since you can only watch it in 1x (afaik).
Would be nice if you could speed it up. The brawl mode seems a little off, since a lot of matches (at least for me) result in a draw caused by running out of time (try me :D "sloth"). 
Runs smooth, looks nice, sounds good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084043270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1589575965}
review:
So far would recommend.

I like the way ships are built from parts, custom keys assigned to each part so i can tweak how left/right turning vs strafing works, if to use drills and all weapons together with main weapons or not (to conserve Engineers energy :)).

I'm always trying to fit in 0 deploy cost (so Storage upgrade first) - so far always worked, i don't think i've spent any of first currency yet :) but always need to pick right ship for mission.
Takes a bit of tweaking and test-flights, but it's amazing feeling when my ship (ehm drone) gets finally balanced properly, excelling at specific goal while mostly also bit of allrounder (who knows what expects down on the planet) - when it all clicks, it's fast enough and just crushes through the planet and whatever enemies while hoarding all resources found on the way.

So far i'm only bit worried about the Corp and threat % ... as a i'm of course attempting to visit (ehm *harvest*) all planets/spots possible (at least once), while the price of repairing single hulk point seems to be always more expensive, wondering how much it can get.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981616200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1589603582}
review:
There is a great idea of a game here. In my opinion a few things make the difference between seeing myself able to enjoy this for hundreds of hours and dropping it right now.

- Lack of polish: cutscenes, art, etc are laughable even by indie standards. Please hire an artist. YOu may think this is brutal, until you see the start a game
- Lack of incentive to continue playing: the 'game loop' is bad - even when playing singleplayer and unlocking items for a given run, you are never presented with instructions on how to use each part, or challenges that may utilize that part, etc

- THE BIGGEST THING: The soundtrack is incredibly repetitive and dark. What could have been a relaxing or fun atmosphere for creativity is subdued and hard to listen to after just a few minutes. You'll notice lots of streamers straight up mute the music when creating drones because of it. GIVE ME THE DAMN SONGS USED IN YOUR PROMOTIONAL VIDEOS.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012399365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1648906078}
review:
Early feelings what I've gathered so far is somewhat disappointing. The drone construction and collecting for more parts are both great aspects of the game, but the way missions are progressed is a bit concerning. Every time I'm presented with a new mission type it feels that I am blindfolded and slapped with cane before the mission starts as your threat level rises. If you don't understand how to solve the mission on your first run, you will increase the threat by every attempt you make. Thus preventing you to adventure and try more. Would be much more fun if you would only increase threat once every planet or when your drone is destroyed. Going back to hangar shouldn't be so penalizing.

***

After putting in more hours (and making sure I get my money's worth) the game doesn't feel that super horrible after initial shock. There are still missions I would like to see some kind of hint on how they are supposed to be done. Changed my opinion to thumbs up, but people should still wage carefully when purchasing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063618790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1589650979}
review:
It's good, and I want to give it a thumb up just because the drone constructing is great, however, I would have given the game a mixed review if I had the choice, as I do have a few issues.

Nimbatus really gets the construction part right. There is a whole lot to play with and if you put in the time, you can make some really cool stuff. If it wasn't for sandbox, I wouldn't leave a positive review, however. The survival mode isn't bad, but I just find the actual gameplay a bit boring and tedious. I was sort of hoping for the game to be more free, but you hop from planet to planet, each one very small, and do the objective. Some of the objectives can take literally 15 seconds, whilst others can take a while. None of them are particularly interesting, though. They consist of maybe blowing something up, or grabbing something, or shooting something, but the actual act of doing any of these things isn't very fun.

I think if the game would have allowed you to fully explore the universe it generates yourself, it would have been a lot more fun, but you are locked into this FTL (the game) styled survival mode just hopping from one planet to the next, without a whole lot of change, just so you can hop to the next one.

I think the game would have been better suited if you were dropped into a generated universe that is connected, and you start of with basic stuff to build drones, and then you need to explore to find better parts and upgrades, but the further out you go, the more difficult it becomes.

Sandbox is no different, but you have unlimited resources and parts so you can just go nuts, building whatever you want. 

It's good, and I would have preferred to leave a mixed review, but I don't want to give a thumbs down. The game doesn't deserve it, but it does need something more to keep me gripped.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157860887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1589717248}
review:
非常に自由度の高いドローンを作って惑星探査するゲーム。
惑星ごとのミッションをこなしつつ資材とパーツを集め、ドローンを進化させながら進む。
ゲーム自体は面白いが難点が多い。

まずは良い点。
ドローン作成はとても自由度が高く、接続先や入力トリガー、果ては回路を組んで完全自動化などまでできる。
重心や強度、熱や凍結、ドローンを組むための資材の多寡などの概念もあり、ステージを進む度にドローンを進化・効率化させる必要がある。

悪い点。
チュートリアルがあるが本当に基本中の基本しか教えてくれない。炎上や凍結などのシステムはどこにも書いていないので死んで覚えるしかない。
惑星は基本球状で、中心が下になるようにカメラが回転する。よって中心に近づくほどカメラがぐるんぐるん回転し、2Dなのにかなり酔う。
ドローンを作る資材は有限で、惑星ごとのミッション報酬だけでは到底足りない。ミッションだけこなしているとすぐドローンが作れなくなりゲームオーバーになる。よってすべての惑星で「すべての邪魔な敵の殲滅＆資材収集」をしなければならず、1つの惑星に対して拘束時間がかなり長くめんどくさい。
たまにパーツ同士が干渉しているのか謎の物理パワーが発生し、ブースターをふかしてないしオーバーヒートしているわけでもないのにドローンがぐるぐる回って制御不能になったりする。こうなると元に戻すことは困難で自爆させるしかない。

値段は安いし面白いが、同時に非常にストレスが溜まるのでオススメするかと言われると…。

author: {'steamid': '76561198019050918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1591134630}
review:
I've been thinking of getting a destructible-terrain game for awhile and saw this released. Figured it was a sign, and the pricepoint wasn't too crazy. For how much it costs, I think it delivers on every dollar. There's a couple rough spots, but they come with the expectation this isn't a $60+ AAA game from a long-time studio.
The drones absolutely facinating. I've barely gone through the singleplayer (only one about 3 of 10 galaxies, if I'm understanding things right), and I've already itereated through four major drone designs and my mind is blown once I got access to multiple Logic System parts to play with. Its interesting balancing a drone and making redundancies- sometimes I find myself making use of weird ways to travel if I mess up and say, lose everything on one side of my drone but I'm stubborn and still want to muddle through the mission. 

I would say some of the dings are that it doesn't communicate some details very well. For example, there was a mission to 'capture <monster> without killing' but I had no idea what it meant by that. I later figured out (by joking with some friends and doing just general silliness) I could aggro then lead them into the resource collector. Or that the Corp Shield Station mission, you have to destroy the beacons- even though your own shield items only block certain weapons; those weapons that didn't get blocked still wouldn't get through the corp shield. Those little nuances are the biggest stumbling blocks to the game which can be quite frustrating, but its not like you have a giant game-over.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034056331', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1589878129}
review: I want to thank the developers for giving codes to the wonderful people at Keymailer. I was sent this game to try out and it's a decent ship building/modular physics game. The tricky part is trying to manage your costs while still trying to create a bad ass ship. You have to look at what type of worlds your landing on and decide what is best for the situation. You're in a cold planet, bring heaters. You're on a hot planet, bring coolers. Same goes for weapon types. You really have to tweak your drones or you'll find yourself running out of resources fast. The game doesn't seem all that difficult in the Survival mode. Haven't played the MP yet. I recommend giving Nimatus a try for the sheer creative builder in you. You'll find most ship designs don't work the way you think they will. You'll get some good hours out of it to. I'm 12 hours in and still haven't scratched the surface of all the different parts you can get. Thank you again for the opportunity. If anyone wants to check out my stream on Twitch to see how it plays, please stop by. Thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005374652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1589852407}
review:
(Edit) Alright steep learning curve and absolutely lacking tutorials/tooltips aside I do have to change my recommendation for this game, lots of fun and very distinct play styles between the different captains and as I already said before the sandbox is just fun.  That said do still have to seriously warn about the steep initial learning curve and necessity of testing due to a serious lack of teaching game functions INSIDE the game and useless tooltips. (/Edit)

Amazing sandbox.  Awful survival mode before you learn to play - single player tutorial(s) don't cover 90% of the advanced things you should know for missions and ship design.  Also why in the name of god is there so little explanation/tooltips for things that are LITERALLY game making or breaking.  Having to test every single thing in the editor instead of just knowing what they do is a remarkably stupid/lazy/pointlessly difficult gameplay decision.

Pros:  
+Great builder game (Sandbox mode), can build damn near anything - but that's also because you have access to everything and don't start with just the basics.

Cons:  
- Awful single player campaign (Survival mode) - until you learn the basics survival mode is rough - the learning curve is ridiculously steep (Which honestly is almost entirely due to absolutely useless tooltips that tell you nothing and minimal tutorials)
- Game RNG as far as planets and missions can be absolutely broken - Your failed without you even having a chance depending on your starting planets/missions, it doesn't happen often but it is totally possible to get missions that are effectively impossible that early in the game without the needed supporting components or at least you get so far behind in your attempts to beat the initial missions that your crippled for the campaign which is the same difference.
- You will have to test in the editor every SINGLE little component except the basics (nevermind the finished designs) instead of being intuitive/having good tooltips

Watch some youtube vids of people playing - the tutorials don't tell you half of things you need to know/use and single player will quite literally never tell you how to use 90% of the systems and don't even think of tooltips, they effectively don't exist.  I really can't say enough how useless and frustrating the tooltips are in this game.  There are 90s internet based games that have more and better tooltips.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048485977', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1589646027}
review:
After playing for a couple of hours, i must say this game is really great BUT i have some critizism that i think the devs need to implement asap for the game to have long term sustainability:

*When i play as the "programmer" in the campain, i hate having to navigate that f*ing container when i start EVERY TIME. As soon as i've improved my drone enough to solve the tasks, i just have to go back to the drawingboard because for just RGN sake, that f*ing container THAT I OWN is in the way with my new solution, either physically or torching my drone. A way to "move" or "deactivate" or "control" the container would remove this and acctually make the challenges about the challenge and not just about avoiding your own starting area. This is crucial for me to have a way to avoid when i am a programmer, right now every mission is the same because of this and only this. Replace the container with a "tractor beam area" where the mothership draws the objects in would have the exact same effect as that stupid container but not be a nuisanse.

*In "tournaments" there needs to be weightclasses, otherwise every genre of competition is just going to be about who can put 100 parts in their ship. It feels like if you dont add weight class, evertyhing will just boil down to the same design since you want the 100 parts and there seems to be an optimal way to do this. Separate the classes into maybe "0-10"  "11-25" "26-50" "51+" or something, also increases the amount of "genres" you can compete in!

*Some of the menus while doing the tournaments are not really polished, the order i need to click is tedious and it feels like many things could be "remembered" if you want to try the same thing many times without me having to press the same drones over and over. I suggest the devs try multiplayer themselfs for a couple of hours and see what i mean, you want the menu to work quickly between "building - > testing - > building -> testing" but right now it's very many clicks unneccesary i feel like. Also, why cant i "test" my drone on all types of maps, in example "sumo" map? do i really have to acctually compete on the map to test my creation? Should be a test area for this so i can figure out what "mission target" represents for example, is it enemy or map center etc.

*Active multiplayer would be awesome, but i realise this could take more time to implement since physics etc. needs to be synced but it would make this game even more awesome, if i could do "multiplayer campain problemsolving" with me and another friend on the same planet, deploying at the same time, dividing the task omg please

Will update this as i play more, please keep updating this game!!

review:
如果你是在网上、直播平台或是其他地方看见别人玩的开心而打算入手
那么建议你三思而后行（要手的）
优点：爽快的射击、自由的组合、炫酷的特效、还有电器化设备。在游戏中你甚至可以制造自动化炮塔攻击的敌人，游戏中有着丰富的传感器，无需学会编程便能享受自动化的乐趣（要脑的）。武器可以选择升级的方向，你可以加强穿透能力或是分裂攻击、抑或是点燃、冰冻、辐射敌人，同理，护甲可以选择高温抗性、低温抗性或是辐射抗性。火力不够？那好，塞他一百门炮进去。打不中敌人？跟踪导弹安排上。星球的洞太小？激光钻头掏空星球。需要动手太累?自动化炮塔扔哪儿，等它自动消灭敌人。
除了游戏本身的乐趣，在游玩的过程中你还能感觉到进步的乐趣，尝试使用自动化模块吧。他们的原理和现实中的自动化模块相似，他们有着同样的设计思路。在游戏中熟悉各种传感器的使用可以帮助你在生活中寻找这些模块的应用场景。
缺点：本游戏需要用到大脑和手.jpg

author: {'steamid': '76561198042149499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1589833865}
review:
Originally this game was unplayable to me because of crashing whenever I entered the editor, I had to update my graphics card driver which fixed it. That being said, here's my actual review.

Nimbatus is good.

The robot building is relatively fast, but there is no mirror option (So you have to do everything twice essentially) and there is no option to select multiple parts to modify them together. This can become annoying when you have 16 guns that need remapping. Overall, it's good, but lacks tools (multi selection is the major one) and a bit of polish (dropping a part back into the menu should remove it, for instance).

As for the game itself, the "campaign" type mode resembles FTL in its format, with a threat looming behind you as you go to planets and accomplish objectives. I must say, I hate the threat mechanic. Instead of being forced to go quickly through the areas, you just get slapped with damage eventually and there's nothing you can do about it besides getting upgrades. It's annoying and stressful.

The gameplay is good, however, it can be frustrating to control the robots. I guess as you get better, you both make better robots and get better at piloting, but to me it was very frustrating at the start, especially my first run.

The thing I love the most about this game is the automation aspect. You can make a really big robot with moving parts that operate automatically, and it's very satisfying. I'm loving the hell out of "The Programmer" as a campaign option, to me that's the way to play the game and it's a blast. It's like all the mechanics suddenly make sense.

The strength of this game is the robot building, the weakness is the game and campaign.

Overall, this game is exactly my type of game and it's rather well-made, so it's an obvious recommendation for me. I feel like there's a lot of potential for more gamemodes in the future as well.
developer_response:
Hi Bean Salad

Were you able to fix the problem in the meantime (I was looking at your playtime)? If you still have crashes, we made the experience that updating the graphics card driver was helping resolve the crashes. If you could fix the crashes, how did you do it? Would love to hear back so we can give that information to other Players :)

Thank you for your help and cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198041916500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1589551178}
review:
シングルプレイヤーで３つめの星系までしかやっていませんが、作業感と理不尽さがちょっときついです（自分、作業ゲー結構好きなほうなんですけどね・・・）。
肝心のドローンを作るパーツがなかなかそろわないし、普通にやってると資源消費が大きいので大きなドローンは使いにくい。
また、資源も２種類しかないっぽいので、探索のドキドキ感が少ない。

敵に追われているということで、惑星の探索が気軽にできないのもマイナス。
降りるたびに敵に襲われる可能性が上がるため、一度は降りたら惑星の全資源を回収するべきとなってしまう。
しかし、毎回惑星の内部まで探索してあるかどうかもわからない資源を回収するのは、前述のように資源が2種類しかないせいもあって作業感が強い。

どっちかというと、惑星で必要なキーアイテムを発掘したり、ボスを倒すことで先に進めるようにして、そのために必要な部品のアンロックのための資源回収を工夫するようなシステムにしたほうがあっているように思う。
（キーアイテムが埋まってる岩盤を削るのに必要なドリルとか、溶岩を固めるのに凍結させる必要があるとか、強い重力に対応するために高出力エンジンがいるとか、ボスの装甲抜くのに強い武器がいるとか・・・）

とりあえず、蛇が最悪すぎる。攻撃もすり抜けるので、撃退不可っぽい上に、判定がでかく、動きも早いので大きなドローンだと回避しづらい。体全体に判定があるので、一度食らうと一気に破壊されてしまう（自動操作ではまったく対応できないんじゃなかろうか・・・）。

Race tracks as well.

A fantastic game indeed.

My recommendation for the first run is choosing the scientist.
No fuel tanks (all run on batteries)
Modifying weapons to your liking.
Getting weapon upgrades as rewards on planets.

Go buy this and have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198166220701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 233, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1589552881}
review:
[i]«А небо стало бесцветным. Как будто голубое небо — это лист бумаги, в центре которого выжгли дыру, а за той дырой — сплошная чернота. И всё в звёздах. Только вообрази себе, каково это — падать ВВЕРХ» - Джо Хилл.[/i]

Изначально, увидев этот проект, я посчитал его малоинтересным для себя. И знаешь, я рад что ошибся. Сейчас я расскажу тебе немного об игре, что тебе предстоит и как всё это будет происходить.

Первый взгляд и геймплей ты можешь увидеть тут: https://youtu.be/-xIr8xKXMZE

Футуристичная космическая песочница – звучит совсем нехило! Но мало взять интересный жанр, нужно иметь что-то еще, чем можно заинтересовать игрока, заставить его втянутся. И, да, тут это «что-то» есть.

[h1]Начнем с геймплея[/h1]

При входе в игру тебя встречают различные режимы – кампания, песочница и pvp сражения на аренах.
Песочница – да кто не знает что такое «песочница»? Строй что хочешь, делай что хочешь, экспериментируй, создавай, управляй, взрывай...и еще куча глаголов. Но, в этом случае режим очень важен. В игре присутствует огромное количество разных блоков. Это могут быть ускорители, пушки, аккумуляторы, баки, соединительные блоки, лазеры, кнопки и собиратели ресурсов. Каждый из них работает по-особенному, каждому нужна своя кнопочка управления. В общем, об этом чуть позже в пункте «крафтинг». Суть в том, что тут можно изучить, как и что работает. 
PVP – это арена. Думаю, это тоже и так понятно. Игроки против игроков, крафт против крафта. 
И, конечно, кампания. Самый важный и интересный режим, на мой взгляд. Тебе предстоит примерить на себя капитанский китель и взять управление Нимбатуса в свои руки. Нимбатус – это станция по созданию и развертыванию дронов в космосе. Каждый дрон, которого ты там сделаешь, будет уникален и очень интересен. По сюжету тебе будет необходимо путешествовать по разным звездным системам, прыгать по планетам и выполнять на них миссии. Естественно, за награду. Твоим призом будут новые части для новых дронов, ну или для усовершенствования старых.

[h1]На счет капитанов[/h1]

У тебя, в самом начале, будет выбор за кого играть. В игре есть 6 капитанов – Тяжеловес, Пилот, Шахтер, Исследователь, Инженер и Разработчик. 
У каждого из них свои преимущества, которые более подробно ты можешь увидеть в видео, поэтому я не стану сейчас тратить твое время и повторятся.
Но самый странный из них это Разработчик. Он может бесплатно выходить в миссии ( в начале каждой миссии ты платишь символическое количество руды), получает детали, которых нет у других, у него удаленная заправка топлива...в общем какой-то он имбовый.

[h1]Крафтинг[/h1]

Крафтинг тут реализован очень круто, по крайней мере, мне он пришелся очень по душе! В игре, как я писал выше, присутствует большое количество блоков, которые различаются по силе, размеру и назначению. Сам корабль ты можешь сделать, по сути, какой угодно. Можешь заморочиться и создать огромный фрегат, установить пушки с двух бортов, привязать к ним разные клавиши...а, кстати, важная фишка – к каждому блоку, либо группе блоков ты должен привязать клавишу, которая будет отвечать за его активацию. Простой пример – блок ускоритель, направленный вперед, активируется клавишей W, кинетические орудия – ЛКМ. В общем, обязательно пройди обучения и всё поймешь.
Также важно не переусердствовать. Если твой крафт будет очень тяжелым, то он не сможешь нормально маневрировать в космосе и тебя будут просто расстреливать. Либо крепежи будут слишком слабые и он просто развалится на части. 
По сути, тут, если применить фантазию, можно такой корабль забабахать! 

[h1]Графика, музыка и прочее[/h1]

Ну, про картинку тут мало что можно сказать. Приятная стилизация, лично мне, напоминающая платформер :) Когда облетаешь планету вокруг она становится похожа на карту из Worms. Цвета не токсичные, нет чего-то такого, что резало бы глаза.
Звуки и музыка вполне подходят к игре и атмосфере, дополняя ее. 
Иными словами, тут и говорить не о чем.

[h1]Планеты[/h1]

Важный, как мне кажется пункт. Планеты тут полностью разрушаемы. То есть, по идее, если тебе хватит энергии корабля (и терпения), то ты можешь пробурить планету насквозь, точнее сказать, поделишь ее пополам. В недрах скрываются ресурсы, которые необходимы тебе для дальнейшего прохождения игры – руда и алмазы. Так же по планетам разбросаны останки судов, растения, враждебные элементы, пушки, квестовые предметы. 
Разрушается планета выстрелами или лазером. Лазером, кстати, делать это проще всего. Интересно, что будет, если полностью ее уничтожить..?

[h1]Итог[/h1]

Эта игра для тех, у кого хорошо с фантазией, для тех, кто хотел бы отправиться в космическое приключение, на поиски новых миров, друзей, врагов и смысла всего сущего. Если ты один из таких – то сыграть в это явно стоит!

[i]«Из одной системы нам еще долго не выбраться — из солнечной» - Станислав Ежи Лец.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198206978865', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2357, 'last_played': 1685495935}
review:
This is a fun time-killer. 

It's a very well designed mashup of Space Engineers, Gummy Ships from Kingdom Hearts, and the 2D real-time minigame from Space Rangers 1 & 2. You get to construct drones, load them up with weapons, design overlay skins for them, and fly around a 2D environment blowing things up, towing items with magnets, and collecting resources.  

I've logged nearly 40 hours in the survival game type so far and it's pretty expansive. Taking missions to destroy or capture critters, hunt down and collect fossils, and blowing up various corp tech. Each gives rewards of new parts, resources, or weapon mods (if you're a Researcher Captain). There are even logic parts to automate your drones. (I'm not smart enough for logic parts. lol)

If I had to search for something lacking, I'd say the tutorials don't really equip you to build advanced drones. However, the learning curve is pretty short for this one. 

If you are looking for a game that will make you think a bit, I highly recommend this one. 

(Thanks to the developers for working with Keymailer, and thanks to Keymailer for a review copy.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198110438632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 2999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1589931864}
review:
======= 25 hours =======

As other reviews mentioned (and their average length should be noted) there is only so much to see and do when you play singleplayer.

I'm really tempted to try the other game classes and difficulty... but the problem with this is that, again in singleplayer, the repetition is too obvious.

More importantly, there is no other drones to face, at all. I've mentioned before that the game is very... bland, or vanilla if you will. Now I can confirm that the narrative is limited to an intro and outro and has no other NPC to interact with (and grow attached to!) at any point.

I'm hoping for more content in the future, and perhaps more importantly, a little "something-something" that would give the game a style and color of its own on top of the good mechanics.

======= 10 hours of gameplay review =======

Build spaceships ("drones") to run missions, race, play game and fight. Singleplayer or with others. It has some progression aspects to it here and there. The mechanics are well done. A lot of variety and option make me happy but it's not too complex for me (at first) to understand and I'm honestly not that smart. By example I really scratched my head in frustration just trying to get my ship moving at first... but there are tutorials and I found it it wasn't really complicated. There's also a ton of conditional switchs, sensors and automation to explore after the basics are mastered.

No campaign or story included. Generally speaking the game's style is extremely bland, flash-like and uninspired so don't expect much on that front. Singleplayer-wise, there's two modes. A Survival mode (running from a mean ship) where you get to pick a (barebone) class and play using all the progression rules and shops in 1 of 3 difficulties. A Sandbox mode where you make up your own rules.

5 way to multiplayer: Fighting, sumo, brawl and two type of racing. Didn't really try those much, don't know how peer to peer and cheating prone they might be, but on the surface they seem as well built as the rest of the game.

Not quite sure what to make out of it really or how many hours I'll play it but it nailed the "building a ship fun factor" and that's what count. Tried the game for the first time (as well as wrote this review) after release from early access.

review:
[2020-05-14 정식발매 후 바로 플레이함] [한글화 완벽]

2D라 오 쉽겠는데? 했다가 개박살이 났습니다.
무언가 진행하는 것에 의미를 두는것이 아니라
무언가 만들고 시험하는것을 좋아하는 사람이라면 
플레이 타임이 무궁무진하게 나올 수 있는 게임이라고 생각합니다.

간단요약
싱글 - 값 싼 단일드론 vs 값비싼 만능드론 그리고 대기업의 횡포
멀티 - 내가 바로 EBS 로봇파워의 주인공! 잘 만든다는게 아니라 초딩이 만든것 같다는 뜻!
           [타임 오버라고 제작진이 만든 괴물같은 드론이 등장하지는 않습니다.]

-------------------------------------------

싱글에서는 생존과 크래프팅으로 나뉘어 플레이가 가능합니다

생존 플레이에서는
대기업의 횡포에 맞서 기필코 죽이겠단 마음으로 
와신상담 하며 꾸역꾸역 항성계를 뚫고 나아가면
대기업이 또 나타나서 깽판을 칩니다.
자원을 모으고, 드론을 제작하고, 무기를 강화하면서 대기업에게서 벗어나세요!
자신이 전자회로따윈 모르는 문돌이어도 설명과 구조가 간단하여 쪼물딱 거리기 쉽습니다.
어릴적 빙빙블럭 하는 마음으로 새롭게 만들어 보세요!

-------------------------------------------

멀티플레이 에서는
타임어택 레이스 / 스모 / 난투 / 레이스 / 체크포인트 캐치 로 나뉘어 있습니다

난투는 현재 VTOL을 이용한 재블린 메타가 주를 이루지만, 의외로 많은 승부수가 존재합니다.
