review: В принципе игра вроде как прикольная, и русский есть, но управление..... Я не продрался дальше первой планеты после туториала. Не вынес, бомбануло. В общем если поставить двигатели вперед соплами, назад они тянуть не будут. И инверсия маневровых движков, с невозможностью переназначить клавиши прямо из кампании - это просто ж. И да, я зашел в игру еще раз, чтобы окончательно проверить что я не тупой и в главном меню таки нашел, что "w" и "d" можно поменять местами и управление будет почти что норм, но вот заднего хода у местных космических кораблей не существует. В общем об игроке, раз игра не бесплатная, можно было бы и заранее подумать. Палец вниз все-таки ставить все-таки рука не поднимется: люди как-никак старались и вышло даже стильно и прикольно, но такая фигня, полагаю, может испортить впечатление не только мне, так что рефанд.

review:
Ich habe das Spiel ein wenig angespielt und nach einigen Stunden doch eine gewisse Hassliebe entwickelt. Es ist ein knallharter Dungeoncrawler, der dich auch gerne mal gegen die Wand fahren lässt. Das ist auch erstmal nicht verkehrt, erfordert aber eine gewisse Frusttoleranz.

Aber die Wiederspielbarkeit bei diesem Titel ist so unglaublich hoch. Ständig gibt es neue Teile, die man testen will, neue Missionen die eine bestimmte Art von Drone brauchen und geheime Orte, die erforscht werden wollen.

Besonders gefällt mir auch, dass man mit guten Bauskills eventuelle Schwächen bei der Steuerung kompensieren kann. Ebenso kann man als guter Pilot auch mit nicht perfekt gebaute Schiffen vorwärts kommen.

Wer auf Dungeon Crawler steht, gerne an der perfekten Maschine knobelt und eine stabile Tastatur hat, ist bei diesem Titel goldrichtig.

Mein "Angespielt" gibt es auch im Videoformat auf Youtube:
https://youtu.be/_6kZSZGb_fc

review:
I was given this game by the developer.

This is a very very good building game. It has a lot of depth and clearly a lot of work went into making sure it all worked well. I honestly have not ran into any problems playing so far, despite the wild range of options this game lets you play with. The game gives you so many variables you can even learn how to program you ship to automate entire missions and it's actually a playstyle they encourage for people who want more difficulty. Really nice stuff!

The game is best described as a topdown 2d space shooter roguelike, but you are building ships like in Besiege/NutsnBolts, and there are a ton of challenging missions to tackle.  
Really awesome job, devs!

review:
So this is space drone constructor, its 2D, build your drone from varios parts and send it on missions 

I have kinda blast playing it

Planets have gravitation and different weather conditions, temperature works fineky right now -  if your drone froze, it will just stop moving, and you can unfroze it with heat parts andweapons, but if its overheat, oh boy, better restart. I once catch on fire by flying near some burning debreas, so there that

 Where is sandbox and survival mods, in survival you have different pilots with different perks and starting parts, and you have to gain other parts from missions. 

You need yellow cristals to deploy your drone and red cristals to upgrade your ship, repear it and buy new parts in shop. Both can be found on planets, but "cristal" progress saves in real time - if you die while gahtered half of cristals and killed half of enemies, enemies will respawn and cristals will not

Froze build works better then heat build, its much more simplier to froze enemy and then shutter it with kinetic weapone, then wait for it to burn. I guess heat good for dealing witn insect types and to unfroze your own drone

Parts spawns at randome, you can miss on some critical parts and some type of missions might be unavaleble, like if you dont have fridge block or stronge enouth magnet, then you just cant retrive cargo from flaming core of a planet

Where is also automation, which is a lot of fun as usial. Good luck figuring out all whis logic staff

 Music seem very familiar, I cant remember from where, maybe space rangers, or spacestation df-9, or alpha genesis

Whould recomend, good game overall

author: {'steamid': '76561198005777066', 'num_games_owned': 467, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1588732425}
review:
Jeu très sympa, mis a part quelques petits défaut, par exemple le fait de devoir équiper un drone d'armes et de collecteurs de minerais, puisqu'on ne peut envoyer qu'un seul drone par planète, sinon, la planète se réinitialise a l'envois d'un nouveau drone. On peut envoyer un drone minier récupérer les ressources, mais le fait est que si des ennemis sont présent, le drone ne saura pas se défendre, et si on envoie un drone militaire, on peut miner grâce aux récupérateurs mais du coup il faut avoir des tas de propulseurs pour le faire voler une fois remplis, il faut de l'armure pour les combats, des réservoirs pour le minerais, l'énergie et le carburant, avec un espace de création du drone limité, c'est limite impossible, en plus il faut des radiateurs et congélateurs pour résister aux attaques élémentaires, beaucoup trop de choses pour un seul drone, c'est a mon avis le point le plus négatif du jeu, quand on sait que les ennemis peuvent avoir une flotte...

A part ça le jeu est très sympa, je ne vois pas le temps passer quand j'y joue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048312377', 'num_games_owned': 1774, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 1014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1589400309}
review:
[h1] It's like Space Engineers plunged into the world of platforming, controlling your ship wasn't never easy, but building one is! The fierce chunks of fun, creativity and destruction never ceased to excist on both - I cheer, because this game can fill a gap in your tight gaming schedule! [/h1]

I had quite the hardship of controlling my ship. But it's quite neat that you can address each thruster to a hotkey. My preference would be, that the ship just had normal controls, but that would take away the creativity of building a custom ship. So I just have to deal with it. For me, it was like playing "I AM BREAD" with the keyboard instead of the game controller. Good thing I wasn't streaming this game (not allowed yet anyways) because I opened a lot of barrels or cursed words during my first play.

The story campaign is nice. The cutscenes are handdrawn I presume, reminded me a little bit of "HOMEWORLD", quite cool if you ask me. Back to the campaign here... Like, you don't have to do it, you can also just plunge into sandbox mode. My saying in this is, every game should have a story campaign. A slow paced way of playing and learning of the game, getting comfortable with everything what the game has to offer. My hopes for the Sandbox was dissappointing, I thought I had access to ALL the parts and would be able to build whatever I wanted, but instead, you have to build a ship with the limited parts for the different game modes like brawl / racing / etc...

Can't really call it a "skill tree" so let's call it a Tech Tree, which you can use to unlock better equipment as in duration / speed / range / etc... These you get by harvesting the red type of resources from planets. 

Revisiting a planet however, resets the planet, resets the mission... I have not done the same mission over again (Maybe you can farm the rewards too? Haven't tried that out yet actually), just farming for resources, because there is already one annoying factor: [b] It costs resources to visit a planet, no matter if you succeed of fail! [/b]
Even if your ship gets destroyed, you can relaunch your ship but you have to spend again the resources to visit the planet. That is bugging me... Like, I am willing to spend resources to visit a planet, mine it's resources and return to the mothership. But not if my ship get's destroyed and miraculously you get your ship back, but the resources you spend are gone. There should be a failsafe in this, in my opinion.

And the tutorial wasn't always clear, at least not to me, I did finish all the tutorial missions, but with a few I was really scratching the top of my head over it. Actually two, but enlightment came a little later then expected. Luckily, the game has very good music, it accompanied me without getting annoyed by it, during my first play (which lasted 3.9 hours).

I must say, Brawl modus is extremely fun. You build your ship, limited ofcoarse, not exceeding 100 parts and no weapons, just physical force. This game is AWESOME!

[h1] Build your own battleship and testing it out on the field, showing off it's strength as in firepower, innovativity and stability, that is cheer fun! After the tutorial, the story campaign teaches you in a slow paced, comfortable manner your way into the game. Then you can show the world what kind of a drone constructor you are! [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198059648965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1590618117}
review:
Got one-shot by enemy turret on third planet of campaign. Technically this one-shot didn't kill me, took some of my ships engines, but thanks to how drones control works, it effectively immobilized my drone and left me to die. Moved to other planet, got oneshot by other enemy there. Moved to other planet, only upon killing the enemy I've learned that its explosion clears screen on death. This killed me. Started visiting planets to find yellow resource for more ships. Resources don't respawn so I was forced to try mining on planets with hostiles. While retrying mining operations on planets I've died few more times, elevated my treat level, ran out of red resource needed for motership repairs. Died. Game deleted savegame. "Fun", but RNGod may have more mercy for you.

Tried sandbox mode. Hoped for campaign with more health on mothership so disabled all helpers. Still received 21321321 perks and parts for start. And first planet in the universe is treasure trove devoid of any enemies. So game is either frustratingly difficult or boringly easy depending on which mode you'll use.

I hate to say it because devs are obviously passionate about the game, but its been a long time when I've been pissed off by a game so much. :(
developer_response:
Hi SierotkaBezRysia

Thank you for calling us passionate about our game :) We love to hear where we can improve the game, so it can become enjoyable for lots of people.

Now that we released the into v1.0, can you tell us if we succeeded in improving most if the points you mentioned with the older version?

Would love to hear back so we can improve the game further.

Thanks for your help and cheers,
Markus

review: I originally found this game through the demo version of it on their website, so a few years later I found it on steam and decided "hey, why not? I had fun with it then" and now playing it I see what changed. Some of the missions are INCREDIBLY annoying, specifically the ones where you have to push an item into a place, which takes WAY too long to do, and the corp runs into you every 2 systems you go through and takes a hull point away, I was planning to get the red crystals through mining on the surface of planets, but I honestly have no idea how you are supposed to do that, since the container hotkeys appear to do nothing at all and you don't get resources coming back to your ship normally. I do not reccommend this game until the retrieval misssions are fixed or a claw system is introduced
developer_response:
Hi kepz3

Thank you very much for your feedback. You make a very good point. The demo is very old (2 years+) and Nimbatus plays now very different than this old demo. Also many systems and details got changed because of new modes. Because of that reason, certain things might be more difficult for you to understand as opposed to someone who knows nothing about the old demo version.

Can you tell me if you played the "survival mode tutorial" or any of the other "basic tutorials"?

Collecting missions are best played with magnets. You can build a claw yourself, but that's not needed. With a magnet you should be able to collect any object and bring it back safely to the container. There's a weak one very captain starts with, but later on you can find a stronger one with more settings.

Depending on which captain you play with, resource gathering works slightly different. But for most captains you need the resource tank and a resource collector (works like a vacuum cleaner). If you filled up your tanks, you fly back to the container and there the resources are automatically unloaded. In the main menu you find a tutorial which explains it in more detail. If you play as a miner, you might use a resource collector part, but additionally you can also mine resource with the drill directly.

The survival mode is completely revamped and did not appear in the demo. So you have the corp which attacks you if you stay too long in a system and try a mission too many times. We did this as a way to add balancing and challenge to the new survival mode.
If you prefer the old way of playing, the sandbox mode is the closest thing to that (no part restrictions, no threat/deploy mechanic). You can also mix and match features from the survival mode as you want.

Please let us know if this explanation clears up some misunderstandings caused by the demo.

Cheers and thanks for your help,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561197993671194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 6255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5154, 'last_played': 1619128144}
review:
An absolute YES for me!

I do love games that are about building things and testing them out. I usually get bored after a while because of the lack of creative options and/or possibilities to automate.

Well, none of these lack in Nimbatus. You can create all kind of machines to complete a lot of various challenges.
From racing alone, to racing against others, sumo battles, and a lot of others.
The career mode allows you to play with various styles and gives a good feeling of progression/evolution.

It is always very rewarding to find a new design idea that works.

But for me, the best part of it is that you can automate as much as you want, and even do absurd things like an infinitely self-replicating drone that will kill your FPS like nothing else! This is freedom!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002636573', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1587331885}
review:
The videos look cool, but it's a roguelike. No saving, no going back - the resources are spent. You don't have the parts for such a ship, anyway.
Would refund if realizing this wouldn't have taken me more than two hours.

Edit: Since a Dev replied to this, let me elaborate. I'll leave the original for now (with a typo correction).

I felt a bit cheated by the trailer vs what was delivered. I imagined the chance to progress through a story far enough to be able and required to build massive ships in order to beat more and more challenging enemies. Instead I got another FTL; static missions, at times impossible choices, and a constant struggle to balance resources, all the while existing on a minimum of ship parts. As far as I can tell it's hardly possible to build a ship depicted in the trailer during story mode, since there's barely enough parts to collect.
Had I known about the rogue-like aspect, I would not have bought the game. The tag wasn't present at the time of purchase (and isn't now at the time of this edit) and the trailer didn't convey to me that it was in fact a rogue-like.

The sandbox mode just removes any kind of accomplishment you'd get. Sure, it looks cool, but I can see other people build cool stuff on YouTube and it loses its appeal pretty quickly. I get that people like Minecraft Vanilla - I don't. The same applies to this game.

For what it is I think the game looks nice and I think the ship building has potential. After all I did buy it for its visuals and ship building demo. For anyone wanting to play a rogue-like like FTL - go for it! But it seems to me as if the main thing in the game is the drone builder and the rest was created around it to justify the existence of said builder.

@Markus I hope that clarifies things a bit. :)
#HoppSchwiiz
developer_response:
Hi Swofehuper Hemanmalemanson

I'm sorry that the trailer caused confusion and was not clear enough. Did you try the sandbox mode as well? There you can play either completely free however you want (no death there), or you can play like the survival mode (rogue-lite-like) but turn off the death mechanic separately.

I would love to hear back if that mode works for you. Write me back here or write me a private message and we see how we can sort things out.

thanks and cheers,
Markus

Hi OliWєr_!

I'm very sorry for this occurrence. This was bad timing from out side and is fixed now (April 16, 2020).

The reason was that we were testing all Achievements on the internal branch before publishing it to the main branch for all players, so that we could make sure they work properly. But that resulted in a time window in which Achievements were shown on the Steam Page but were not unlocked when you were playing on the main branch.

I'm sorry for the lost progress. We are still in Early Access and while we expect such things to happen we try our best to minimize it.

The Achievements should now work as promised. If anything still doesn't work, please report to us again and we'll try to fix is as soon as possible :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028664786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 26989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8559, 'last_played': 1613848583}
review:
What I like the most in this game is that it can appeal both to the engineering-minded and more action-oriented players.
The physics simulation and the variety of building bricks are enough to pose interesting problems if you intend on building fully automated probes. Yet the simulation is forgiving enough. For instance, a typical craft will survive a crash in the game's very mild gravity. Basically anything will fly with enough engines strapped on it, if a bit wobbly, twitchy, sluggish or unbalanced! This allows a more action-oriented player to whip up a simple drone and be flying around in no time, possibly going back to the drawing board for optimizations only later.

A word of warning about the physics implementation though. The parameters have been tweaked to offer an enjoyable experience, but all pretense at realism has been lost in the process. This is not necessarily a problem, just a point possibly worth mentioning.
The game obviously uses the basic Unity physics engine. This means you cannot link pieces together freely, but are limited to a tree structure growing from the drone central core.
This also means our old Kerbal Space Program friend the Kraken will be breathing down your neck. Worse still, contrary to KSP, the game does not provide any kind of "struts" to explicitly link two pieces together and strengthen your contraptions. This is a serious limitation and will cause many of your creations to wobble, unravel or explode violently if you only look at them sideways.
The game does simulate gravity, air resistance and elasticity to some extent, but the end result does not feel more realistic than, say, the pseudo-physics of Oxygen Not Included. While objects sometimes behave in a rather counter-intuitive way, this mild inertia and exaggerated air drag also allow to design simple servo loops (nothing as clever as PID filters here, just basic bang-bang threshold detection) without being plagued by too much oscillations.

I find the drone design editor solid and easy to use, with a few welcome keyboard shortcuts. I would have liked the possibility to merge designs (importing some functional blocks instead of recreating them by hand) and import drones from within a solo campaign (instead of having to painstakingly recreate the same designs each time you start a campaign over).

The automation system is pretty clever too, allowing to go progressively from simple key bindings (for instance, linking thrusters to the classic WSAD directional keys) to a true event system (handling pseudo-keystrokes as events that can propagate from sensors to effectors, possibly traveling through a few simple logic gates).
This is somewhat reminiscent of the logic layer in Oxygen Not Included, with the typical problems of this approach: though the game imposes no strong limitation to the number of elements or events, designs involving more than a couple logic components will become cumbersome and obfuscated very fast.
Building a simple machine with more than 2-3 states will soon end up in a tangle of a dozen logic gates and a score of various signals. You'll need to keep track of the keystrokes/events very carefully, and even so, debugging will most likely be laborious. Yet if you handle these limitations as the same kind of challenges posed by puzzle games, this can actually add to the fun. Having to do more with less is good for creativity.

The solo mode offers an FTL-flavoured procedural universe to explore, complete with a tech tree, random events, ever increasing danger level, and procedural variations on 4 or 5 generic milk runs (the usual mix of fun and profit, namely exterminating natives and plundering their stuff...) with the occasional specific scripted mission thrown in for variety.
The tiny planets and critters populating them are very cute and lively, but still this solo campaign feels a bit empty to me. More content might be added there though.

On the other hand, the various multiplayer modes are a blast, and would be enough to justify buying the game, as far as I am concerned.
Beside two types of races (one vs one or against the clock), there are three competitive events available: demolish your opponent, push it  outside an ever shrinking circle, compete at fetching balls.  These are perfect showcases for the creativity this game allows.
The drones you will compete against are full of surprises. Some can be comically over-engineered or downright puzzling. I have been humbled by clever and elegant solutions time and again, and had hours of fun trying to counter some subtly optimized or brutally efficient design.

This game is somewhat comparable to Zachtronics Industries productions (SpaceChem, Shenzhen I/O, Infinifactory, Opus Magnum...). I would definitely recommend it to engineers and likely minded people, but it might also appeal to other profiles.
Though this is no engineering course, it will reward logical and methodical thinking and, in that respect, might have some educational value. 
As a side note, the documentation is sadly lacking right now. The tutorial is OK but certainly not enough, and I had to scour the Net for vids from one of the developer to figure out a few game mechanics or somewhat obscure game terms. This screams for an actual old-fashioned documentation or possibly a serious wiki.

At any rate, the game manages to tackle design and automation in a fun, creative and consistent way, being among the few to succeed where so many failed. This alone should be a reason to support the developers, in my opinion.

review:
Not so much a "No" from me as it is a "Meh". Not quite worth the full price.

No matter what I build or how much time I put into the creations I never get the satisfaction I get on other, similar games.

This idea is great. Right up my alley. Engineer/build things to achieve some goal(s). I really love this genre... but Nimbatus just can't pull it off for me. I want to like this game, but can't.

In the early stages of a creation I'm hopeful and excited with a thousand ideas spinning in my head... but after hours of work I always have to reduce it back so far that is underwhelms me. Kind of like a DM that doesn't let his/her players push the boundaries with creativity.

Ultimately, the part selection combined with the much-to-be-desired physics engine fall flat. Far too limiting.

The autonomous competition aspect of the game is really the only draw for me. The single player is quite boring.

I'm sure I'll re-review after release. Fingers-crossed

author: {'steamid': '76561197989383204', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 4880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1597963024}
review:
Hi Steam, Xira here. This game sucks, but it's not obvious until it's too late to refund. I shall tell you why!

Basically the entire premise of the game is flawed - it costs you threat (a bad thing that accumulates and ends in defeat) to attempt a mission which you have no real guidance on beforehand. So you are paying a deadly price to go in blind with a 'drone' or drones you design. You don't get unlimited chances - you get threat with each attempt. This would be fine if sending down a 2nd drone picked up where the first wore off (so you'd pay a price but eventually be able to complete anything by chipping away at it) ----

But no. You restart fresh but in a worse position every time you fail a mission. You perhaps know what how to tweak your drone to better survive the mission but that's largely irrelevant because you only get to carry/use X parts which you have to pray to RNGesus you get in time for them to be useful. 

This results in extremely tedious missions which are sometimes impossible and it's down to pure luck if you get bent over by the procedural generation gods too many times and fail a play through. I got a snake mission in my first galaxy that was literally impossible to complete with the parts I had at the time - One of the eggs was buried in the middle of the planet. And I discover this after trying the mission 3 times and carefully flying around up and down and patiently waiting for the big snake to go away so I can chip away at an egg. These missions are extremely tedious.

In general the RNG is tuned to be *hard* on easy. I give you a 1/20 chance of it being possible to win an easy play-through, 1/100 for a normal, and impossible for hard. Unless you have lotto-like luck it's likely you'll end up failing a couple of missions and ending up with too much threat and nowhere to dump it. Ded.

Also, the instant you lose a part you might as well quit that play-through. Losing a part is (generally) crippling to the drone, which is fatal to the mission, which makes parts with independent (and tiny) hit-points pointless. You can drag it out as long as you like tho...

Don't waste your time. I haven't seen a game this fundamentally flawed since Sunless Sea.
developer_response:
Hi Xira

Nimbatus is now finished and will exit Early Access soon.
We have done a lot of mission balancing in the past months to improve the difficulty curve of the game and have also reworked some missions and added new ones.
Would be awesome if you have time to take another look at the game!

Kind regards,
Philomena

review:
This game has two levels to it. Both are great fun but for a different kind of player.

1. Manual drones. Making gods of war and destruction is a ton of fun in this game. Especially given all the freedom you have with changing the weapons and parts. Make drones for whatever situation you want and have fun.

2. Automated drones. This part is much harder. Using the logic parts and sensors to code an automatic drone is a lot harder than it sounds. I've barely been able to make a drone that just searches and destroys. This becomes even more fun when you toss in the factory part and just make an entire swarm.

Overall 9/10 game. An excellent game that lets you make your own fun. I recommend it to anyone who liked games like robocraft and such.

review:
This is a hesitant like.  I DO like this game, BUT it really needs a few things looked at to improve it to a truly great game:  

- The snake egg mission unfairly punishes engineers who leave a fuel/battery/resource bin in the big collector.  You will be on the other side of the planet and suddenly you have no thrusters because snek just blew up your fuel tanks.  Maybe I can instead of dropping it down, I can have it thrust up against the Nimbatus, but I am not sure I can still collect resources and have them get in the bin.  Yes I know, take it all with me....

- The programmer captain is an awesome addition.  I love the added challenge of full automation.  Now I just wish I could WATCH my bots easily.  Yes you get cameras, but if you are factory producing multiple of the same robot the camera ends up split in the middle of how ever many drones you have out.  It ends up with me staring at the center of the planet for most of the mission and I find it BOOOORING.  Perhaps I am to program my way into better cameras, but I honestly don't see how at least giving us some way to switch cameras easily would break the challenge of the mode.

- Collect the Relic cannot AFAIK be completed without incendiary weapons.  Period.  Well, maybe you can set something on fire by placing it on an altar, then carry it to another unlit altar, but I couldn't find a way that didn't set my drone on fire as well.  This mission can show up before you get an incendiary weapon, thus wasting your time and resources. 

- The altimeter is nebulous to understand and use.  Maybe give us an actual altimeter adjustment in +/- meters from the surface, as well as a little display saying my current height.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096289718', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 961, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1612765194}
review:
I will start this review off on a positive note, the base concept of this game I like. The sandbox mode is great fun. The drone building and crafting system is also intuitive and enjoyable.

For what I DON'T recommend this game for is the story mode. The RPG style character selection is cool and the level progression is nice. BUT the way you lose the game is so disheartening and uninteractive it kills the game. If RNJesus screws you and you dont get a way to lower your threat level through an event or find a shop to repair your hull enough, you lose the game AND all your progress. You also lose the ability to use the drones you just built in the story mode (you can transfer them to a creative save but its not the same.) I lost a 6 hour playthrough because I couldn't find someone to repair my hull (and you don't even know for sure when you will lose hull either, you just know it MIGHT happen). So if they remove the RNG and Rogue-Like aspect to the story mode I will thumbs up this game (even adding perma-death as an option would be nice) but until then I can't recommend this game.
developer_response:
Hi Not Impulse

Nimbatus is now finished and will leave Early Access soon.
In the past months we spent a lot of time to rebalance the missions to improve the game's diffuculty curve and have also put some more work into the galaxy generation.
It's still a rogue-like though. Would be awesome if you have time to take another look at the game and let us know what you think :)

Cheers,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561198062557851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1579367582}
review:
After a decent amount of hours in this game and a decent amount of updates since i purchased it, i fully endorse this game. It seems with the mother ship update, it is moving the direction of FTL but with a much more skill and less random factors in play. Here are a few pros and cons if you're on the fence:

Pros: With sandbox and survival, the game offers both a relaxed or challenging feel. Tons of parts and combos offer a vastly wide array of drone types and play styles. Also a competitive mode lets you pit your creative building against anyone else. With damage from the your surroundings or enemies, building a drone for task completion as well as survivability is a dynamic experience. 

Cons: Worlds and their design become monotonous quickly. Resources and terrain never blend together leading to a very simple design that contrasts sharply to the details put into other areas of the game. In the campaign, there are still a few bugs on the randomly generated worlds that can prevent completion of a task (generator towers inside of the shields).

In all, the cons do take away from your experience, but by no means impact it enough to make you want to stop playing. The devs keep putting out quality content that expands enjoyability, so i look forward to future updates and how they will change the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198934229427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1623860138}
review:
I originally found Nimbatus really boring. It only had a handful of missions and nothing was explained. Now, most of these problems are fixed. There are shops, more missions, boss levels...etc. I really like Nimbatus now, and I definitely recommend it. Everything positive you read is true, so I'll just focus on the negative.

1) Drones are slow. The whole game feels sluggish. Moving and rotating larger drones is a difficult task, and you'll probably spend more time trying to get to the objective, than actually completing it.
2) A lot of time is spent mining. I would consider this a positive because mining adds a lot of realism to the game, except the slow travelling speed makes mining a hassle. Again, more time is spent travelling to and from resources, that actually mining them.
3) While added levels and features make Nimbatus way more fun than before, after a few hours they start to get repetitive again. In Galaxy 1, every level was different. In Galaxy 2, I was seeing a couple repeats. By Galaxy 3, every level was something I had already done.
4) You can't fight other drones in the campaign. Killing bugs and turrets is fun, but I want to test my drone against another one.

Despite these negative points, Nimbatus is still tons of fun, and much better than it used to be.

review:
While building drones in the creative mode is fun, outside of that the game doesn't offer much substance except for the campaign, which was what I tried doing

The campaign is honestly quite badly designed, every time you deploy a drone your threat goes up and it costs currency to do so, which is quite unfortunate because you can't switch out drones in the middle of deployments

On top of this the difficulty spike in the campaign is hard, I beat the first two worlds pretty easily but the others beyond that were near impossible!! I don't understand how you can be expected to spend 10 minutes flying around a planet just shooting things chasing behind you.

The best way to fix this would be to add more parts that allow higher damage, or reduce enemy health because as it currently stands it's not enjoyable. Also maybe make a way for craft to hover in place as maintaining height is quite annoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041700774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4143, 'last_played': 1573706153}
review:
I'm a huge fan of the build-your-own-contraptions genre, particularly this sort that mixes in a bit of bullet hell and roguelike. This is a fantastic example of a developing genre that keeps getting better with each update. 

I particularly like the massively addictive arena modes, which pit your own creativity against those of other players- I've spent far too many hours now tinkering with off-the-wall strategies only to find my judo-flipping sumo bot's run foiled by a clever strategy I failed to account for, and happily heading back to the hangar to hammer out some counter-stategy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198407754984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1168, 'last_played': 1589572170}
review:
Ich habe erst vor kurzem das Spiel gekauft und es hat mir bis jetzt ziemlich spass gemacht es zu spielen.
Das Spiel hat meiner Meinung nach grosses Potenzial. Ich würde mir einfach wünschen, dass es bei den Planeten mehr Variationen gäbe und das es Waffen Skins gibt, sowie das man bei den Skin eine Möglichkeit hat den Skin auf alle anderen Teile, die den selben Skin haben können übertragen kann. Was auch noch schön wäre, wäre die Möglichkeit im Drohnen Editor Teile zu Markieren und die dann zu kopieren. Nun zu dem Fehler die ich gefunden habe; bei dem Planeten wo man nur Ressourcen hat fehlte bei mir der Timer,  ich hatte den Wissenschaftler als "Charakter"  und war in der 1. Galaxie der Kampagne. Alles in einem gefällt mir das Spiel sehr und würde es jedem, der gerne seine Kreativität unter beweis stellen möchte, sowie jeder der gerne mit Drohnen hantiert empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198199693302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1324, 'last_played': 1679248447}
review:
Every update it gets more "Challenging" What was once a lighthearted and fun drone builder is now an endurance test as you dodge bullets for up to 10 min a mission. It pairs you against stupendous odds expecting you to be a perfect dodge. I was 2 missions in and I was tasked with destroying a large armed ship and >20 drones with 2 mini guns. Not fun, not fair, not enjoyable. Don’t fall for your addiction of ‘build your own spaceship games’ this time and get Cosmoteer or something else free.

Developers: This game has great positional; but, just because the player is faster and has longer range, doesn’t mean we want to fly in circles around swarms whittling them away for 10+ minutes, or trying to manually hover in place just out of range of turrets trying to hit them with the inaccurate basic gun. I tried some creative mode with enemy health at 25 – 50% and 2 long lasers, and it was awesome. My advice to you is to giving the player more parts up front, (Long laser, and big batteries). Also, the whole “Deploy Threat” thing needs some work; you should be able to swap out drones mid mission. Swapping out your combat ship for a drilling ship should be faster than shooting a hole to the planet core. Remember how people made “Mother drones” than simply sit at spawn and produce many different drones (combat, miner, temperature control, and scouts). Make that part of the base game. Imagine, after the planet is safe, you can drive back to the ship, get a refund for ship launch cost, and then swap to your mining ship. This will be so much more fun than having to shoot through terrain. In the end, you have all the ingredients; you just need the right challenge.
developer_response:
Hi Cables

Thank you very much for the in-depth feedback. We're now close to the full launch and put a lot of effort into balancing and fine-tuning the survival mode. We tried to strike a good balance between not overwhelming new players as well as provide enough difficulty for recurring players. The survival mode is meant as a mode you learn, get better at and improve over time.

We need players' feedback if we achieved that, so if you try the game again, please let us know what you think about the game now. :)

About changing drones mid-way during the mission. We thought about that long and hard during the development of the game, but ultimately decided against it. So this is something we currently don't plan to implement. We allow you to build sub-drones which can split of or have the factory part which allows you to print new drones. For the time being we think this adds enough diverse gameplay.

Thanks for your feedback.

Cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198287989567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2703, 'last_played': 1711123764}
review:
The game is great. It has some bugs, but that it's why it's in the early access.

But there is one thing that bothers me. And it's the difficulty rise at the end of the campaign. Like all the way from the begining you: destroy small amount of hives, bring something from the planet, defeat 1 hammerhead, freeze volcanoes. That's pretty easy.
But suddenly you have to: destroy 8 eggs of supersonic snake couple, clear the entire planet fully covered in hives, fully prepared for battle, destroy        -lab- military base.

I understand, that It's not that hard. But the thing that bothers me, is not difficulty itself, but a sudden difficulty spike. It's like you are walking upstairs and at the very end of it there is a wall-high step.

P.S. if my request doesn't bother you, can you please give the player more logic/sensor/hull parts along the way

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198029903975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 2371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1590489050}
review:
I need a better tutorial. I got to the part about advanced drone racing and I'm confused about which button is triggering what in the sensor. The person in the tutorial is moving quite fast and is done in seconds. He has positioned about six parts and assigned quite a few keys. Its more than I can remember. 

I passed the earlier tutorials, but I feel like I have a weak, limited understanding of some of these important concepts and the game is acting like "okay, you got that. Lets go charging on into much more complicated stuff." I would need to do a lot more missions. 

The tutorial uses a window in a window. The result is tiny.  Why doesn't the tutorial use the full window? I've got a huge monitor but this game like many does things in smaller windows and my eyes are not getting better. Up on top in letter nearly an inch high it says I'm doing the advanced drone racing, but the letters that he's changing are kind of blurry to me because of the window in a window thing.

I looked at stuff on youtube hoping someone would show things in a different way but couldn't find the particular tutorial mission that I'm on. Its nice that people make instructional videos but they have all kinds of accents and abilities in explaining things. You can waste many hours trying to figure how to do things on youtube. 

Bottom line is that its a pretty good game and more complicated than it looks at first. Its better if you're really good at this kind of game or if you're some kind of genius or at least above average if you want to have a frustration free experience. Of course if you don't mind frustration and you don't mind putting in 800 hours almost anyone probably can figure out a lot of the concepts and mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198824017237', 'num_games_owned': 738, 'num_reviews': 286, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1566166908}
review:
[h1] Lost on Steam EP. 21 [/h1]

This is one of the 3 featured games in the weekly Sunday show. 
An unboxing for video games! You can watch the highlights of this game and the two others featured this week here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QHYP9sfoZJg


[b] [Thoughts and First Impressions] [/b]

Nimbatus is not for anyone ready for failure. You are going to sit there creating the PERFECT drone for 15 or 20 minutes, sure in your construction that you've created the greatest spacecraft of all time. Then you take it into the level and have to navigate and dig through planets only to realize that you didn't think about thrusters to help you turn, only to make you go forward. You go back to the editing room, fix the thruster problem... only to find out that your guns and lasers stick out too far and your ship gets stuck on EVERYTHING. Repeat this process x20.

Don't let that dissuade you from playing though, the fun is ABSOLUTELY in iterating your craft until you have something that REALLY WORKS. It cuts through dirt and planets like nothin and at the same time can defend itself against pirates and other hazards. The feeling of making a successful craft is pretty great, till parts of it get blasted off and you're left with drills and no engines. Crafts are fully destructible, so be cautious. 

The game has an objective in each little sector or system and you can mine resources to help you fly to other galaxies and planets. In fact, it's critical that you do because if you run out of resources your run ends, and you're stranded and have to start over.

Definitely check this game out, ESPECIALLY if you enjoy being creative and can dedicate some serious thinking time to making the best space drone of all time.

Join the Curator group for more reviews and "unboxing" of unknown games! https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34634494/

author: {'steamid': '76561197993326992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1653015139}
review:
I don't normally buy early access games, but this one wore me down, and I'm kinda glad it did.

I should start by saying, the game is 90% done. And like all good game development, 90% done means 50% of the effort remains. There are a lot of "ooh, yeah, someone's gotta fix that"s throughout the game, so don't expect a fully cohesive experience yet.

Now, that being said, I love it so far. I've spent hours tweaking drone design ideas I had, only to decide I screwed it up from the beginning, go get a drink, sit back down, and restart from nothing. I'm sitting for 10 minutes in 1/10th time in Sumo games (one of the mini-games that's supposed to only last a minute) watching exactly how my ship and the other ship are working against each other, and coming up with potential solutions.

Totally worth the money I paid ($15 on sale) to me, for what it is today. And it has the potential to be so much more once that last 10% is finally finished.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970698524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1566204580}
review:
Voici un jeu orienté crafting... petit jeu, ou pas?

8 heures de jeu et j'y retrouve les grands classiques du jeu d'exploration galactique à la Space Empires, FTL et consorts. Aspect auquel je n'avais guère fait attention en m'attendant davantage à un pur bac à sable type Astroneer ou encore un pur jeu craft à missions à la Besiege.

Ici, le mode campagne donne de la profondeur au jeu par les limitations qu'elle impose, et on se prend facilement au jeu de développer de petits drones économiques à lancer en mission, tandis que des événements aléatoires nous tombent dessus. Le plus amusant c'est qu'avec un peu d'expérience on commence à être de plus en plus prudent et efficace. :)

Concrètement, Nimbatus se trouverait entre Besiege et Astroneer, le tout mâtiné de cartes galactiques à la FTL. Si vous aimez les trois, vous adorerez Nimbatus. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198088264980', 'num_games_owned': 604, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1511608293}
review:
Заметил что в последнее время игры с возможностью конструировать свою технику стали довольно популярными и Nimbatus - The Space Drone Constructor как раз ягода с такого поля. В этой игре мы играем за такого себе исследователя дальнего космоса, который ищет полезные ископаемые на планетах, уничтожает местную фауну… Дьявол меня побери, да это чистейший Mass Effect Andromeda! Ладно шучу. Что б не рисковать собственной жизнью, мы спускаем на планету дрона, вот только одна загвоздка, мы должны сперва его построить, своими собственными ручками.

[code][url=store.steampowered.com/curator/11769719/] Еще больше обзоров на кураторской страничке Dreams of Genesis! Подписывайтесь, с нами весело!	[/url][/code]

В игре представлен довольно обширный редактор вашего аппарата, который к релизу скорее всего будет пополняться и пополняться.
У нас есть центральный модуль, от которого нам и придется танцевать. Навешивать оружия, двигателя, различные модули, которые помогут нам в процессе добычи ресурсов. Так же не стоит забывать что модулям необходимо питание, поэтому так же увешиваем дрон топливными и энергетическими ячейками. Первый пробный полет и… Что то пошло не так. Реально. Я понимаю, ты старался, но вышло как всегда. Перезапуск, новая улучшенная конструкция Mark2 и снова неудача. Но ты не расстраивайся, эта игра будет постоянно тебе подкидывать подлянки, что бы ты все время усовершенствовал свой дрон.

Графическое исполнение у игры довольно простое, но тем не менее выглядит довольно ярко и красочно, особенно когда на тебя ополчились представители местной робокультуры с лазерами, плазмаганами и прочими устройствами которые способны причинить вред нашему дрону. Все светится неоновыми огнями, взрывается и в общем смотрится круто.

Музыкальное оформление очень даже приличное, реально удивило.

Мне немного стыдно с тем что я задержал обзор на эту игру практически на два года, но что уж поделаешь, как говорится шит хеппенс. Сейчас уже в игре есть даже собственная страничка с мастерской стима с довольно таки обширным арсеналом различных модификаций и готовых вариантов дронов.

Так что если вы сомневаетесь брать или не брать или вы по каким то причинам не уверены в своих инженерных силах, я б посоветовал все же попробовать ее. Она действительно затягивает не плохо.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021696472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1563919401}
review:

Sadly I'll be returning it for a refund due to bad a experience, but that's not to say this game is doomed forever. I found the instructions are very poor and you will be very frustrated unless you go looking for tutorials online since the in-game tutorials just scratch he surface. It may look like the sky is the limit, but I felt very restricted when building and it blocked a lot of cool ideas I had. Hopefully others of you have better luck with this.

Oh and watch out for the death wiggle, sometimes your creation just shakes apart spontaneously lol. It's quite the spectacle!
developer_response:
Hi Pancakesburn

Nimbatus is now finished and will exit Early Access soon.
We have recently added a new ingame tutorial that explains the mechanics of te survival mode. Please note that the death wiggle is a consequence of building unstable drones (too much distance between parts, too many parts attached to the same part) and can be avoided.

Kind regards,
Philomena

I have an AMD Radeon HD 7800 videocard by the way, I have issues with it all the time but can't afford a different one. This game does not have any video settings. Please fix the lags, devs.
developer_response:
Hi drunk min

I'm sorry to hear that the performance is bad. For most people turning of AntiAliasing and lowering the resolution already improves the experience quite a bit. The game's weakest point is physics, so I'm not sure how much there's to improve with render settings alone.

We're feature complete and improved quite some bits in the meantime. Let us know if with the settings above you play the game smoothly now :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970648476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1033, 'last_played': 1564019690}
review:
Amazing game.  The endless varieties of drones you can build will keep you occupied for quite some time.  Then the game changes...you were sumo wrestling but now you are flying around a planet blowing things up, or racing...and you'll need to design different drones for all those things.

There is a lot of trial and error.  It's not immediately obvious how each piece works.  What does spring strength do?  How do magnets work?  What do all of the sensor options do, and so on...this is my only real complaint.  The tutorials are very easy and helpful, but good documentation for in-depth explanations is lacking.  That won't be a huge problem if you like figuring out stuff for yourself, but even then you probably will find it frustrating.  Hopefully they will add more documentation and explanations as time goes on, though there is a surprising amount of material on YouTube, and also some forums, guides, and so on within the Steam community and elsewhere.

Finally, they are not asking much for this game.  The developers created something unique and interesting, and it's well worth the asking price.

This game probably isn't for everyone...it's about thinking things through, coming up with new ideas to try, and a lot of failures.  It requires a combination of logic, ingenuity, and pure stubbornness.  I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for that kind of challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198311964130', 'num_games_owned': 32, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1168, 'last_played': 1587677201}
review:
What can I say? It's a fun game!
  I specially enjoyed the fact that besides just being able to make a drone, you can make a drone making other drones, and then control them! This was the moment I had the most fun playing around. (and it was a bit... imbalanced... because if you had, like, more than 10 drones being produced like a machine gun with only 4-10 parts, you can get an unbeatable army relatively quick. But I still liked it a lot!) Also, it was fun trying to make drones, but under certain limitations, aka only 50 parts, only one turret... 

The only problem that I've met while playing the game was that, well, in order to make a fully autonomic drone, you sort of need to make a logic block larger than the drone itself, that takes large amounts of space and even more space and weight to even defend these logic gates (and sensors), making the end result of making such thing kind of... even worse. It's much easier to just use your head for manually controlling all of the stuff. (at least that's the problem I've ran into while making battle drones)

Another thing that has scared me the first moment I played the game is that the first time I have entered a racing match, I already got beaten by a... drone... with just thrusters... and nothing else... Which made me try to *avoid* the versus arenas. 

But!!! It was fun to play around with making loads of drones and trying to improvise a lot on the things I couldn't have gotten myself to make otherwise, so I'm glad that I got this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198083123562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2474, 'last_played': 1562185159}
review:
Definitely worth the money if you like designing and building drones. They can range from fully manually operated to fully autonomous. Personally I enjoyed Sumo Arenas most, in which you compete with your fully autonomous designs - without actual weapons-  against other players' designs. The goal is simply to build a drone that can keep itself within a shrinking, circular zone. The last drone in "the ring" wins. It may sound like an easy task, but the drone designs players are coming up with seem to evolve quite nicely to keep it challenging.

I found the the mission/exploration side a bit lacking but for a while it was quite enjoyable. It just couldn't keep me interested for very long. I hope they're gonna come up with some new ideas to the single player side of the game to give it more depth. And to be honest, I'm quite confident they are more than capable and willing to do just that.

In a nut shell, it's been a solid, unique game from the get-go. The updates have been frequent enough and they've added a lot more parts and content to keep the game from stalling too badly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280228127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2067, 'last_played': 1702169817}
review:
Hello, im here to write a review, or more specifically, complain about the race/target/sumo aspects of this game, as they are quite literally the ONLY things I despise about this game; everything else I love. 

I like the music and it sets the mood well, 
I love the drone building and all the intricacies that come with it,
I love the planets and wondering what could happen as I delve within.

...and I will admit it is quite grindy when it comes to gun upgrades, it doesn't give you much information regarding parts and their functions, and it could use more diversity, but as im writing this review it seems some of those wont be a big issue in the future development of the game.

However...

The online aspects are terrible, just awful. They look incredible, they seem excellent, and the music is some of my favorite in the game, but every time I feel like I got a winner, It turns out to be garbage.

Take racing, for example. I built a good racer, it beats a few racers that just crash, and then some absurd, speed demon with flawless guidance completely dominates the whole track in seconds. That first try was my last, I decided.

Now take Sumo, I Saw my opponent's name "Slow Push" so I go "Ok" and build a little drone to test the waters, and this
"Slow Push" Blasted forward and without any hesitation pushed my done out. I build a much bigger, stronger one, and
this "Slow Push", while they DID struggle a tiny bit upon collision, it was the same story. Never tried Sumo since.

And finally, Targets. My favorite of the bunch, though it isn't much better. Fly around an arena to certain points, first to 5 or most when the drones die out wins. But, given my last 2 stories, its no surprise what happened when I entered an arena.

I work so hard on a unique looking, speedy, and clever drone and get outclassed by a generic win machine, every single time. the only thing that beast cheap tactics is cheap tactics, but I want to have fun, and I hate stooping that low.

I really hope the devs refine these aspects of the game, because being forced to either be slammed into dirt or make a generic win machine isn't fun. and if i may quote Reggie: "If it isn't fun, why bother?"

This isn't really a complete review, and its rather disjointed, but I just wanted to get the negatives out there, of course the game itself is fun, and I really enjoy it, but its got high highs, and very low lows, but they are thankfully contained.

Who knows? in an update or two this comment may be outdated by time you may be reading this, perhaps they had fixed the issues encasing the online aspects. I don't know. But im very excited for the upcoming update. just dont mess up them bosses. ciao.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980693579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1609734511}
review:
You build a drone in a cartoonish 2D Kerbal Space Program kind of way, and either automate it with sensors to pit it against other people's automated drones in a sumo arena or race track, or strap it with weapons and fly it around various planets to complete missions.

The concept is fantastic, and the arena modes are fun, interesting and challenging. You keep having to adapt, rebuild and experiment with your drones to beat your opponent.

[strike]The same can't be said for the single player campaign though. It's an endless series of samey planets with the same 5-6 missions repeated over and over. You can just build a drone with a pile of rockets and reuse it for every mission. It's essentially devolves into a really repetitive and uninteresting space shooter. [/strike]

The single player campaign has since been greatly improved, and now has a wide variety of missions that keep requiring different configurations and different weapons vs utilities vs maneuverability.
developer_response:
Hi koala_man

Nimbatus is now finished and will leave Early Access in 3 weeks.
Many new missions (many of which can not be solved with force alone) and a new biome have been added since you last played the game. There is now a survival mode which features part unlocking and part cost when sending out drones, making the approach of just building a huge drone that solves all problems invalid. We'd love to hear what you think about the latest version of the game :)

Cheers,
Philomena

Hi anzellott!

Thank you for thinking that Nimbatus would be one of the best games on Steam if we fixed all the things you mentioned, I'm honored :)

Since we will leave early access next week, we check if we fixed all the things the community wished for :)

- We added a new set of tutorials in the survival mode which should give you a smoother entry into the game. The other tutorials are found in the main menu and optional of you need more information (advanced ones are optional and not needed to complete the survival mode).
- The first galaxy was re-balanced considerably (difficulty, length) and should provide a much smoother entry into the game as well.
- Of course you are right about that the Minigun is not realistic :) We choose those parameters because we thought they were the most fun/balanced ones and chose the name "minigun" because we thought it described the upgrade the closest. Maybe we should have spent more time on finding a more appropriate name :) As philo said, combined with more upgrades you might be able to come closer to the way you want the weapon to work.
- Upgrade Slots are only important if you play with the researcher. There, each weapon you find has a fixed number of upgrades. If you need more upgrade slots you have to complete missions which reward you with rare weapons.

Please check the game out again and tell us if we fixed the things you didn't like :)

cheers, markus

review: I found the construction aspect to be liberating. There is a distinct lack of limitations once you understand the rules behind building. Constructiong a drone is always a good challenge in strategy, especially if you want to make it a general purpose one rather than with a specific goal. Gameplay is more or less as complicated as you make it to be with access to keybinding anything and everything. It can be as easy as complete automation or as hard as using a different button for every engine and weapon. I generally prefer pve combat to racing or pvp and so I would love to see some larger scale combat in that regard from what I have seen so far, bear in mind I have only been to the second galaxy so far so it might get better too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177648279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1547894977}
review: Almost the bigger the stronger, need "cost" to balance the game
developer_response:
Hi Wilkins

Thanks for the feedback. Can you tell me in which mode you played?

In survival we have part-unlocking, research tree, resource gathering and a deploy-cost/threat mechanic which prevents you from going all out in the early game. So you have to work hard to build bigger ships. Do you need an additional cost to those or are they not difficult enough for your? We added a "hard difficult" setting for the survival mode for that case.

In the sandbox you are free to build drones as big as you want. We have not implemented a feature which automatically scales enemy&mission difficulty according to the size of your drone (would be very difficult to make such a feature work well).
We added the feature that you can change sandbox settings on the fly, so if a mission is too easy, you can make enemies stronger, etc. It is now also possible to add the "costs" from the survival mode to the sandbox.

We're now close to the full release of the game and check back if we have addition feedback we can implement. Please let me know if the current version of the game now provides what you meant with "needs cost". Thanks for your help :)

cheers,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198039827748', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1121, 'last_played': 1574012936}
review:
Compared to other 2D ship building games, a genre I have a real weakness for, Nimbatus has one of the best ship creation studios I've seen. While the way ships seem held together with rubber bands is a bit hard to get used to at first, the diversity of elements at your disposal, and ability to automate and customize all aspects of your ship are very nice. There is a system of sensors and logical components in place that allows one to set up arbitrarily complex behaviors. It's rewarding to play with the ship builder.

On the other hand, the game play isn't currently very compelling. Once you get the hang of the building tools, and perhaps unlock some weapon upgrades (which is grindy, but not hard) most missions become tremendously easy. Only arena missions still pose an interesting challenge--and those place strict constraints on which components and building options one can use.

Since this is still in early access I'm hoping the great ship building studio will eventually be matched with some nice design challenges. But, in the meantime, this gets a positive review for the ship building alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116798506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1540337362}
review:
Got my money's worth out of it. The fun is in the building and arenas, not really in the levels, as these tend to be rather dull and repetitive, and can be completed with one "do it all" kind of drone. It's more in trying to do stuff differently than it is in overcoming hard challenges (because there aren't really any hard challenges here).

Thus: if you are a person who can entertain yourself playing in a sandbox and building stuff and checking how it works out, go ahead! The building part is good. As for the world generation, the enemies and such... they need some serious working on... or at the very least, some real combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263718236', 'num_games_owned': 1587, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1544120855}
review:
Un juego con unas ideas muy buenas, al estilo besiege, en el que debes construir una máquina que destruya cosas (pero sin límite de espacio/piezas), aunque extremadamente repetitivo.

Sus niveles son:
-Destruye zonas del planeta x.
-Coge barriles del planeta g.
-Destruye zonas del planeta h.
-Coge barriles del planeta t.
Y no os penséis que hay una variedad de biomas grande como para entretenerte yendo por esos planetas, no, que son todos bolas grises.

Es un juego que requiere que tú te esfuerces en que te guste, que tú insistas en abrirlo, en darle una oportunidad, y otra, y otra más.

Y salvo una actualización un poco meh no han hecho gran cosa desde su lanzamiento hace algunos meses. Es un proyecto a medias, ideas chapurreadas, sin más, que ojalá lleguen a algo más, sí, pero por ahora solo son eso, un proyecto.

El precio es relativamente bajo, pero para lo que es, y sin saber realmente si va a llegar a algún lado, yo no pagaría más de 10€ por él ni de coña (cosa que me arrepiento(y mucho)de haber hecho).
developer_response:

Las cosas que mencionaste que hemos mejorado:
- Hemos añadido un montón de nuevas misiones y un nuevo bioma
- Añadimos un modo completamente nuevo para un jugador con una progresión llamada "Supervivencia"

Si tienes tiempo, nos encantaría que volvieras a probar el juego y nos dieras tu opinión si logramos mejorarlo :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043825988', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 3354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2109, 'last_played': 1686040606}
review:
一見、ちょっと派手な全方位シューティングであるが、なんと言ってもウリは自律、すなわち自動でアレコレやってくれるドローン（自機）を作成できるというところ。
また、射撃系の武器はカスタマイズが可能となっており、掘削を特化して惑星を削ったり、壁面で反射するようになったりと、夢がひろがりんぐ。
しかしこれはアンロック式となっており、アンロックに必要となる各種リソースはそこらの惑星で採鉱できるものの、本来達成すべきミッションとは分離したコンテンツで、現状ではまだ EA ということもあってかパーツ不足によって自律ドローンでは回収が困難ないし非常に非効率的となっていることから、アンロック式そのものの必要性が疑問となる。

今の所一番アツいのが SUMO で、これはそのまま武装をとっぱらった自律ドローン同士で相撲を行うという趣旨のコンテンツ。
一方、シングルのミッションはというと、破壊系であれば適当に惑星を削っとけば達成されるものばかりであるが、一部では指定オブジェクトを回収するというものがあるものの、やはりこれも上記理由により自律ドローンではクリアが難しくなっているのが残念。

author: {'steamid': '76561198140340310', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1109, 'last_played': 1678844744}
review:
I played the demo for Nimbatus back before it released, and it had potential, but wasn't that fun. I made a few drones, but what I could do was very limited, and after a while got bored. Of course, that was then. This is now. And oh boy, am I happy with what this game has become. The different planets are great (except for snake planets! snake planets are the worst!), like for example, one variant is covered in magma, which means you need cooling systems so that you don't burn up. The options for creating your drones are fantastic too. One of my favorite drones, of my design, is one that orbits a planet and drops bombs!
The planets aren't all, as there are also sumo arenas, where you construct a fully automated drone to push another drone out of a ring. You'll see many cool designs by other players doing this.

To conclude: I had my hopes up for this game based on the demo and it delivered. Great for people who like sandbox games, or games that involve some engineering skills. All around just a fun experience.

Edit: I'd just like to add a small criticism - in the future, I'd like to see more mission types added. Currently we have, like, 4 or 5 not counting arenas. More variety would make Nimbatus even better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025673629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1613197539}
review:
I've been playing longer than I thought I would. 
The game is well thought out and has more content than I expected. 

As it's still in Early Access, the next things I think it would make sense to see is the ability to upgrade other parts.
Your battery for example; why not spend upgrades on battery capacity or shield strength? How about armor plated fuel tanks? 

Other than that, I'm enjoying the game. Music is great, the number of parts is plentiful, and the arenas are a great challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011400305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1545630837}
review:
The game is at best a technical concept. The gameplay is extremely repetitive, and the enemies very limited. There is absolutely no depth to the gameplay. It is NOT worth $20 in it’s current state.

In it’s current state it’s essentially a “shoot at dirt” simulator. Especially since the extremely limited selection of enemies (only a couple types that actually shoot back…) can be shot at from range without ever engaging you. I’ve yet to actually encounter more than ½ a dozen enemies of any sort in one spot. There is no difficulty progression either, so it stays dull and repetitive forever. I played for ~8 hours (I was offline) and it was pmuch the same the entire time. Destroy eggs, destroy hives, destroy beacon, or destroy lab.

===Edit 04/2019===

Some people will say that your imagination is the limit. But the same applies to MS Paint, and would most people go and "play" MS Paint for a few hours after work? Unfortunately the game doesn't have much depth, you can make whatever drones you desire, but at the end of the day you are just making drones, there really isn't anything to do with them. I stand by my "shoot at dirt simulator" statement, you can just shoot at dirt with different things.

===/Edit===

If this game was $5 - $7.50 this would be a good review, as the expectations would have been much lower, but it is in no way worth $20 in it’s current state. 

I bought Space Engineers for $15 when it was in alpha in 2013, and it was far more feature complete than this and had a strong dev team behind it.

Requesting a refund.
developer_response:

It would be really great if you could take a look at the latest version of Nimbatus and let us know what you think :)

Cheers,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561198044146972', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 1026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1608699969}
review:
This is an interesting game that can provide entertainment for the gamers that don’t mind working their brains a little. Although in early access, there is some major educational value in the game. It provides a lot of opportunity to “build and test” your logic. The game is in early access so I would recommend waiting for a sale as it is lacking a bit of content at the moment. 

=(video review located at the very bottom)=

The concept of the game involves the player designing a drone to navigate a planet. Every planet in different systems provide different, although at the moment, limited challenges. The [b]gameplay[/b] in this one is interesting to say the least. There are more or less two main screens the player will be looking at : build screen and the command screen. The meat and bones of the game is designing and building your drone. The interesting catch is the player can easily assign any key to activate a part – which in a sense acts like a variable. Sure your thrusters turn on when you press “W” to go forward, but if a sensor is going off, you can automatically tell the thrusters to go off. There are many different parts to play with to construct a drone to your style. You can choose to build a mining type drone, an attack type drone, a mother-ship type drone that drops other drones, or you can choose to combine all types together. There are different mining pieces, weapon pieces, armour pieces, thrusters pieces, mechanical parts, sensors and logic pieces. All pieces or modules have quite a few variants to choose from. Depending on your ability to program, there are some pretty insane possible combinations. Some users have made ships that are capable of zeroing in enemies while others will search for resources. Although the concept seems simple, it can take a bit of thinking/programming to get the right results. You can instantly test new pieces you put onto your drone to double check the results. The test screen is very friendly and does provide the player with options to change the situation or scenario. The player can choose to turn on gravity or activate enemies to see the drone react in a real situation. I would recommend checking out the steam workshop for a few ideas on what is possible. 

The command screen is when the player deploys the drone to the planet. Each planet will have different challenges for the player to face. So far, the challenges mostly involve destroying some sort of object. For example, one mission might be to take out a communications tower. Another mission might require you to take out 10 giant snake eggs. Some of the missions do have an interesting x factor. The snake egg missions will have a giant snake coming out of the planet to attack the drone. As far as I know, it isn’t possible to take the snake down which is a bit annoying as it’ll rip apart your drone fairly quick. This is where the early access barrier prods its ugly head out. In terms of actually playing the game, it can get a little boring. The designing process is awesome, the playing part is cool, but then the missions start making the game redundant. There was a solid effort to add variety to the missions as there is a sumo mode that is included. I would like to see the devs add more depth to the mission portion of the game as there is a lot of potential here. Fighting hordes or waves of enemies, creating some sort of tower defence with drones, or even races or object movement objectives might be worth a look. I saw some users try to replicate Rocket League within the game with drones!

The [b]sounds and visuals[/b] are suitable to the game. I think the visuals were well done and the details of the modules are excellent. I’m not talking 4K type of details, but I’m talking necessary details for the player to quickly check on modules. Some of the modules that deplete are fuel, energy, and factory parts. It is very easy for the player to see how much fuel they have left as the fuel in the module pieces will slowly fade away, the same goes for energy or the recharge of factory pieces. The planets, resources, and enemies all follow the same simple design. As I said, it’s not insanely detailed but provides the necessary effects. The sounds effects are suitable to the games atmosphere. I think a little more work could go into this domain to immerse the player further into the game. The sounds do cut out for whatever reason if you’re playing for an hour or longer. 

Overall, the game is at a decent start and it looks like there is a lot of promise. I really like the fact it can be very educational in a very game-like way. I think it’s really cool that you can build a “bot” with logic and instantly test it in different scenarios. I do believe there is a still a lot of room for improvement in all areas, especially for the missions and tutorials. The technology tree upgrade is definitely a good start. I would highly advise prioritizing mission variety, unique and new added missions would add a good twist. Tutorials are another realm that needs a little work. Templates of drones should be provided to help those who have no clue how to make parts connect, or at least having note/comment abilities in the build screen. Game is decent at the moment, it is slightly on the expensive side so I would certainly recommend waiting for a sale. 

UPDATE: The multiplayer features are absolutely awesome. Huge addition to the game! I also appreciated how career mode progressed, really neat way to introduce concepts (and the game) in a nice, flowing way. I would love to know how to program, but my abilities to expand in that area are limited. Career mode was a nice educational tool. Thank you for caring Devs! 

[h1]RATING : 7.5/10[/h1]

review:
A very very good game i love it... but maybe its not for you.

I read the bad reviews and noticed one saying that this game has no controls, well thats right but thats not a problem that has to be fixed its the core of the game, and as an programmer my self i enjoyed every aspect of it, it is true that it can be repetitive if you dont enjoy building and programming, because the levels are at the moment very limited but its not about that its about what you are capable to do with the power of a good code and drone architecture.

There is a sumo arena probably the best aspect of the game, you launch your creations against other players in a sumo match its very fun reminds me to the 90's early 2000 in a wierd way.

This game tickles me in a spot i didnt know i had.

PS 56.7 hrs at the moment of this post and i got this game 3 days ago... happy new year.
