review:
正式リリースもされたので久しぶりに遊んでみたところ、バグはほぼ改善され、ストレスなくプレイできるようになっていました。やったぁ！もっともパーツをちょっとでも伸ばすと機体が激しく揺れ始め、終いには爆発四散しますがね。そこは工夫で回避しました。
ただ、あまり熱くなれない。なぜなら戦闘が楽しくないから。せっかく「ボクのかんがえたさいきょうのきたい」を作っても、活躍させる場がない。つまり強い敵がいないのです。強い装備は用意されているのに、それに見合う敵がいないとはこれいかに。もちろんこのゲームは戦闘メインではないことはわかるのですが、私は戦いたいのです。だって男の子だもん。それなのに雑魚と中ボスっぽいやつしかいないんじゃね…ということで評価は変わりません。まぁでも、ロボコンみたいなのが好きな方にはオススメできますよ。

---

Mac及びLinux版では物理エンジンまわりに致命的なバグがあるようです。ものは良いだけに残念ですね。
[url=https://www.reddit.com/r/NimbatusGame/comments/8mdtch/drones_begin_to_shake_uncontrollably_and_fly_apart/]https://www.reddit.com/r/NimbatusGame/comments/8mdtch/drones_begin_to_shake_uncontrollably_and_fly_apart/[/url]

早期アクセスということもあるし、本来はバグがあってもオススメするのですが、問題はゲームコアにプレイ不可能レベルのバグを抱えておきながらKickstarterで資金を募り、かつ未だに修正していない姿勢に悪い印象を抱いたからです。残念というのはこの点です。

ともあれ、正式リリースされたらまた遊んで確かめてみたいと思います。
（しかし開発ロードマップを見る限り、2019年3月のリリースは難しいのでは？という疑問も…。）

author: {'steamid': '76561198098589331', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1546357511}
review:
So far this game is both immensly fun but also very frustrating.

I thoroughly enjoy building my drones and testing them but I think that there's too many options to build with. On the first mission I found myself building something too big, OP or simply packed with irrelevant parts. On the one hand it does give you a crash course of what works and how to design better; but it also means the learning curve is steep.

The first mission is a nice start but I found it completes on its own? The transmitter was marked as destroyed as I was digging for resources, but it was physically still there.

I reccommend this game if you enjoy building and experimenting. Furthermore if you have younger children then this game may be a great way to get them interested in engineering or etc.

This is a visually simple game but it is very unique when building.

Edit: I'd like to point out that this game allows manual keybinding for just about everything. It makes controls complex but this also allows so much more freedom.

review:
Leider viel zu wenig Abwechslung. Immer die gleichen Missionen. Hat man einmal ein potentes Schiff konstruiert, spielt es sich sehr eintönig. 
Am Meisten Spass macht die Konstruktion des Schiffes ansich. 
Der Techtree ist sehr unübersichtlich und ich sehe keinen Sinn darin, Resourcen zu sammeln, um meine Waffen zu verbessern, wenn ich eh schon ein Schiff besitze, dass alles in Sekunden tötet.
Mehrmals habe ich die Mission geschafft, ohne zu wissen, was ich zerstört habe, da meine Raketen das Missionsziel ausserhalb meines Bildschirms zerstört haben.
Persönliche Empfehlung von mir als bessere Alternative: Reassambly
developer_response:

Nimbatus ist nun fertig und verlässt in 3 Wochen Early Access.
In der Zwischenzeit haben wir jede Menge Verbesserungen am Spiel vorgenommen und neue Features und Content hinzugefügt. Im Spiel gibt es jetzt auch einen Survival Modus mit einer kleinen Story. author: {'steamid': '76561198442430696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 3420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3420, 'last_played': 1688829617}
review:
I had to delete my early access review for this so this just shows how much this game has gone downhill since the betas/alphas. First of all, im gonna talk about some things that are in the final game. 
The campaign: really half baked as another person said, its boring, repetitive, feel unfinished, and lacking. the planets are basically all the same, once you've seen one of a certain type you've seen em all. Collecting resources. Wow is it tedious, you have to fly around winding caverns trying not to get stuck on a SINGLE PIXEL because your physical drone cant even slightly damage the terrain by hitting it. and collecting the resource is even more annoying you have to fly really close to the material and use your vacuum things to suck it up and because of the whole getting stuck thing i mentioned its really hard to get to the actual materials because, again, you have to get really close to the resources to collect them. Another thing about the resources: VARIETY theres only 2 resources and they are EVERYWHERE meaning theres no incentive to explore the much more dangerous lava planets because originally in the early access there used to be a blue resource that only appeared on lava planets encouraging you to explore them and design specific drones specialised to traverse the winding caverns. Another thing about the resources: there used to be different coloured resource containers which encouraged you to build specialised drones for different planets plus the different coloured containers generally just looked cool and as the theme goes, they got rid of it instead opting to go the lazy route and make the resource containers all be one colour and while this may sound better its just really boring.

Now then, on to the actual building part.
So, the drone creator: Im gonna keep this short. Its clunky, un-intuitive and time consuming.

Conclusion: game was waaaaayy better in the early access and has only gotten worse since.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077485825', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 17986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1788, 'last_played': 1705785219}
review:
A really fun game for people who like robots and automation. I see a lot of potential in this game but I have a few things I think could be better.

1. There are way to few quest types. For it to be a fun game in the long run, having at least 100 different types of quests will be great. They don't have to be too different, just eliminate enemies but add more enemy types and maybe make some enemies fight eachother or have some allies even. Maybe find friendly stations on some planets that help you through powerups or follower drones.
2. After a few hours of playing, I have a drone for every job. There is no need to make any more. It's a shame because I really liked the building aspect of this game. One solution could be to give players better and better stuff the more they play or having an option to force people to make new drones for new galaxies. This problem could also partially be solved by adding more quests.

Anyway, keep up the good work. Cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561197970956133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1718, 'last_played': 1559580190}
review: This game was gifted to me during a little christmas pass-along, and I was initially very sceptical. But now it has cost me a couple of sleepless nights, I have played 25 hours so far and am only beginning to really understand the myriads of possibilities to build drones and explore the planets. While you can still see and feel that this game is not completely finished yet, it is already highly addictive and very stable. The 2D artwork looks amazing, you can discover many different planet styles, and the ressource collecting and upgrade system makes your old drones even more versatile over time. If you are a fan of games like Kerbal Space Simulator or Minecraft, give it a try - you won't regret it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006525169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1596526675}
review:
Do not recommend. Couldn't even complete the tutorial.

The game doesn't have good controls. You have to manually bind keys to parts to use them. Even binding specific keys to forward, backward and side thrusters and firing them individually does not turn the ship. Basic movement controls are a must for a game like this and is WASD or Arrow Keys do not work to control movement, then you can't proceed at all. 

Until this gets fixed, I'd avoid the game.

EDIT: 

Thanks for the reply. 

While doing the tutorial, I wasn't aware of that. I had simply assumed that the controls were different in the tutorial from the rest of the game, as my drone didn't control like the drones controlled in the videos. 

Having better tutorials to explain that point, would really help a lot. 

If you end up implementing said tutorial, or further improvements to existing tutorials, I'd be more than happy to delete this negative review. Game looks really cool in the videos, and would have liked to have gotten into the game back then.
developer_response:
Hi Bonegrinder

Thank you for the feedback. I'm sorry that it was frustrating.

Only for the tutorial we do not provide default mappings for the drone parts, because we want to teach you how to customize them yourself.

In the game we provide standard mappings for thrusters and weapons, and if you build a drone which points to the right, then you should be good to go (forward, turn left/right, shoot).

If you plan to build a drone which can strafe left and right and move up and down, this is a more difficult problem, as you need additional thrusters and sensors which can stabilize your drone if it tilts.

Nimbatus is a game where you have to build things from the ground up and do certain things the hard way which other games simplify for you.

I think we need to add an additional tutorial which helps you build such a advanced drone, since a lot of people would like to play this way. Thank you for the help.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135226460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2170, 'last_played': 1596678069}
review:
Nimbatus is a lot of fun. It is essentially a 2D drone-ship design and engineering type of game, featuring your personal creations at its core. You pilot your drone to accomplish single player missions on planets, or pit your own wild and fully autonomous drone designs against other player-created autonomous drones. Its not completely fleshed out yet, as I can imagine so much more for this game, but what is here is incredibly solid. I am desparately hoping for more mission types and gameplay avenues to be created.

Sumo is an awesome 1v1 automated drone king of the hill, last drone standing in the centre of an ever-shrinking circle. There is a lot of depth as to what type of drone you can design, and how drones have a very nuanced rock-paper-scissors design.

The single player mode has you visiting different planets, piloting your drone to accomplish different mission types. You can redesign your drones, and find different ways and styles of accomplishing each mission type.

These two modes are essentially Nimbatus at this point, but if Stray Fawn keeps making more modes, and keeps increasing the depth, this game is going to quickly become one of my all time favourite digital engineering/design type of games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000621442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2114, 'last_played': 1599084168}
review:
Neat drone construction and you really can customize your drones however you like. I found myself copying/tweaking drones for a variety of purposes to better solve each mission, and to make better more complex machines. It's fun to see what you can do with the components available. There's a variety of sensors and logic gates, and figuring it out is a lot of fun. I spent so much time tinkering with my drones.

Sumo mode (automated drones vs. other drones) was great, and figuring out the pieces and tweaking and sumo-ing tournaments is great. There's a real sense of pride when you manage to get through and win a tournament, and I loved watching my drones smash apart enemy drones.

The planet missions themselves were fairly shallow, and there doesn't seem to be a purpose / goal to the continued exploration of galaxies other than to keep generating new planets for you to explore. Once you find planets with the resources you need to progress through the tech trees, you can re-play those planets over and over to re-mine resources infinitely.

I dumped 35 hours into the game, and it was fun and definitely worth the money. I've stopped playing for now, as I feel like I've "beaten" the game -- but I'm eagerly watching the development notes to see when new features are added. I'm looking forward to the racing update.

Things I'd love to see:

1) Drone minibosses or something at the end of galaxies, maybe something that showcases the various drone parts that you might not have used. Maybe something that makes you use specific types of weapons instead of just overwhelming rocket spam.

2) Different mission types -- the missions on the planets get stale quickly. Maybe new mission types, like a race to retrieve a thing from the center of a planet vs. a rival drone ship 

3) Fix the altimeter, I have not been able to find a use for it because it's staticly set to % of planet's radius -- maybe that could be used in SUMO mode -- but that doesn't translate into something I can do anything with on planets. Give me a keypress option that I can use to "fix/record" the current vertical position on an altimeter. I'd love to be able to use a Factory to print mini-drones w/ altimeters and make them float in the spots I've dropped them. I was upset that I couldn't do that, and it seems an obvious missing option.

4) A better reason to dig into planets. Maybe missions like I described above, but the terrain destruction is *so perfect* in this game that I really found myself wanting more of a reason to spend the time digging to the center of a planet.

5) Make it more obvious what special features the transmitter on any given planet does. Show that on the drone selection screen and not just the map/planet screen. I would often find myself forgetting what the transmitter actually did, and being frustrated that it wasn't visible as I'm trying to select what drone I need, only to have my rockets not work on a planet, or my ship having too many parts, etc.

===

Overall, definitely worth looking at if you like tinkering and customization and it's just very *neat*. Once you've seen all the planetary mission options and figured out the logic gates and sensors, and lost a few tournaments, you've seen the whole game. For the price of 1 movie ticket in parts of the US, this will get you 20-40 hours of enjoyment, so it's very worth a try.

review: This game is pretty awesome. I got in during their Kickstarter, and never looked back. The game is fun, and presents some challenging things that you must work around or solve on some missions and others that are just go and kill these things. There are tricks to both that once learned that will help you complete your missions. There is also a battle arena type planet, where you have limitations to what you can have on your drone, like no weapons, it must be no larger than 100 pieces, and must fit within a certain area. The arena is sumo in style, the last one inside the circle wins. As time progresses the circle shrinks. There are many strategies to win, avoidance, speed and mass, sensors and logic. I have spent over two days of game time playing and building in Nimbatus since its Steam release. I recommend you get the game and contribute on their forums, they want you to enjoy the game, and right now the community is still small enough that every voice is heard. I recommended they remove camera parts from arena's so that the view isn't centered around a part that goes flying off the screen, and in next patch, that is being removed from arena. I love the game and can't wait to see where it goes from here!

author: {'steamid': '76561198087363746', 'num_games_owned': 554, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4153, 'last_played': 1593369364}
review:
I like this game for the freedom in building it provides. You can build almost anything you can think of! 
There are currently 2 different game modes in the game, Exploration and Sumo Arena.
Exploration is sort of a campaign where you complete missions on different planets to progress and mine resources to upgrade your weapons.
The Sumo Arena is where you'll build drones that the AI that you built onto that drone using "yes or no" kind of blocks, the drone will then try to stay in the circle as long as possible and or try and push out other drones that people have made. I've spent many hours in this mode trying to perfect different drones and make my AI do the things I want it to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982449156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 17654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11288, 'last_played': 1598859647}
review:
Still in a pretty early stage of development, but what's there is promising!

The PVE portion needs a bit more work to keep you hooked, but it's fun to approach the missions in different ways. Or you could try to automate everything. It's your sandbox, do whatever you want.

The PVP sumo mode in particular is cool. You pit your autonomous drone against random ones other people submitted and duke it out. It's really cool to see all the different strategies people have come up with, and developing your own strategy to counter them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971672370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1542391363}
review:
TLDR: Nimbatus is an awesome construction game and a lot of fun. It lacks in terms of world building and is - at the moment - just an empty sandbox. But that's about to change: the devs plan to inculde drone racing, improved single player campaign progression and more drone battle arenas, just to name a few things contained in the roadmap.

TLDR video (4 minutes):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KsWuWkmD0Ro

Nimbatus is about building drones which is a lot of fun. And since the game is physics based construction is quite challenging too. You have to thoughtfully place every part and bind a key to activate it - or your drone will only fly in circles or not at all. There's a ton of parts and I haven't tried out all of them yet. Lasers, shields, batteries, fuel tanks ... just to name a few basic ones. Advanced building allows automation to create semi-autonomous drones using sensors and basic logic blocks. You can even build drones able to construct remote drones thus creating a drone swarm. 

So the core mechanics are quite nice but how's the actual gameplay? Your job is to travel around several star systems. There always are SOME planets with different threat and gravity levels and  resources for you to mine and objectives for you to complete. They force you to adapt and to build new drone as you progress, but ... yeah, what are you progressing towards? There's no story to follow or goal to reach. No ever increasing threat to fight and nothing is chasing you, like for example FTLs rebel fleet. 

There's lots of intrinsic motivation because the construction mechanics are awesome and building drones is a lot of fun. But sadly we're stuck in an empty sandbox like so often during early access. The best part of the game is the "sumo mode". Some kind of passive pvp where automated player made drones fight each other. This takes places within an arena which is getting smaller and smaller as the fight goes on. You encounter these events on the star map during the campaign. Players get quite inventive when it comes to automated drones. Like this one which just escapes if another drone approaches it. I solved the problem by letting my drone just advance a little bit so the shrinking arena can take care of the opposing drone.

Nimbatus is awesome in its core but it severely lacks in most other departments. But well that's better than the other way round isn't it. So if the devs add a challenging campaign and/or expand on the PVP aspects I'll surely be back for more drone construction.  Keep a close eye on Nimbatus if you're losely interested in advanced constrcution games.

disclaimer:
I played some more on my second account. Don't be confused by the 1.7 hours listed here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990285653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1542802859}
review:
If you like building lego and spaceships, this game is for you. The sheer amount of possibilities the game provides is incredible, almost overwhelming. Thankfully, there's was an easy to follow, yet rewarding tutorial that led me through the basic principles of the different parts, how to build drones and play the game.

The only negative thing I can say about the game is that, as of yet, you get all the parts right from the start of the game. Which is cool because you get your hands on a giant sandbox and unlimited drone power. But I think a forca or need for speed like story mode where you have to progress through different challanges to slowly get more parts and therefore better drones would feel very rewarding. Keep in mind that the game is still in development though. I am almsot certain the devs are going to add a feature like this in the future.

But allready now, building the drones and playing with them feels incredibly rewarding and fun and I have yet to find any sort of bugs or issues. Which is more than you can say about many finished games nowadays. All in all an alreay great product with a lot of potential to grow in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198370922961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1636061082}
review:
Incredibly fun game, but I think it'd be best before purchasing to watch someone play it a bit.
Pros:
Limited in a way that forces ingenuity
Enough freedom to build pretty much anything
Requirements and transmitters force you to rethink your designs
Factory allows for low stress play, allowing you to feel not so high-strung about the security of your drone
Motors, hinges and springs allow for exploration of new mechanics and new combinations
The multiple variations for sensors allows you to build drones that can follow your mouse with no other controls
The fact that Melee weapons exist
TNT and other weapons for use, such as heaters and coolers
Camera trackers & Logic gates for the more experienced players

Cons/Suggestions (minor)
Temperature below setting on the temperature sensors, just another output so you can have one fully stabilized
Resource can be tedious to find, but not as tedious (with practice) to harvest
I kind of want to see a cold world, to put in a more frequent use (besides simply keeping your drone warm when using cryo weapons at close range) for the first suggestion
A buff on the melee weapons, as it's not worth the time and effort to use them if they prove to be so ineffective
A VERY minor buff on the shields, without a larger number of weapons it can prove difficult to withstand the firing of the hives
The Corp's little drones follow you for too long, I feel like they should be giving up at a certain altitude or distance away from the transmitter
The little baby hammerhead things. They aren't that hard to deal with, just so annoying. Maybe slow down the fireballs? It's hard to keep your mouse on them so a sufficient number of weapons can take it down, it keeps getting out of the mainstream before I have a chance to see what's going on behind the blinding light of laserfire
 Although I don't want this, it probably needs to happen. A minor nerf on factories, maybe it uses 1/5 the amount of fuel and energy being put into the product? It uses energy to produce things? Using them, I can spam in a whole bunch of little robots each equipped with shields and lasers and heaters to not only self destruct when I'm done, but also as cover from hammerheads and shields from hives. Not to mention the sheer quantity leads to abusive amounts of firepower. With the requirement of a decent amount of fuel and solar panels to build stuff, I feel like that scenario would be less likely. (Srsly, I barely even have a weapon drone, just a little one that spawns in more and more) 
EDIT ON PREVIOUS SUGGESTION: DO NOT DO THIS SUGGESTION FOR FACTORIES DIRECTLY CONNECTED TO THE DRONE CORE, I REPEAT: DO NOT. For scenarios on disposable mini-drones, this suggestion is amazing. For replacing bits of armor and using different types of armor, like cryo weaponry gets discarded for plasma or kinetic, not so much. 

Cons (Major):
It gets repetive quickly, so I play it now and again building drones that I'll never use to their fullest potential. Honestly sumo and building drones has kept the rest of the game decently interesting, if I hadn't been as invested and pleased with sumo and building drones, I would've already stopped playing it. Sure, there's something new after a few wormholes from the beginning. Oh wow! The Corp lab needs destroying! Oh wow! It needs destroying on a different planet! Oh wow, it's here, too?
I feel like there should be something more at stake, optional worlds that cost resource to enter and if you complete the mission first try, you get double the entry fee or something. But if you fail... you lose the resource you used to get in. I think that would be neat and make me much more willing to play all the worlds instead of just beating every sumo arena I come across.

Suggestions for you, Reader!
Learn some basic logic stuff
Watch Lathrix/Lathland play Nimbatus, it helps you get a grasp on what's going on.
Stick with the building system, it's tedious at first until you learn how to do Ctrl C/V/Z automatically
Do not be frustrated by the orientation thing, if it messes up, just flip the two outputs
Go ahead and subscribe to other people's creations, look at the logic and break it down. Look at what's connected to what and break it down. It helps you build better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976088506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 17975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15783, 'last_played': 1605146390}
review:
I really like this game.  It has alot of potential and an active developer.  Discord community as well which is a big plus.

My Likes:

Sumo Arena - Its the current PVP of the game.  In this mode you design a drone that is fully automated using logic blocks to automate its intellegence.  Weapons are disabled as well as the factory parts.  The objective is to push the opponents drone core out of the ring before your own.  So many fun designs to make and V.S. against.

Building Drones - Being creative with logic blocks and building designs for various needs.  Just making something for fun as well.  Want to make a bunch of flashing lights for kicks?  Bah have at it.  Contains a testing grounds as well so you can get an idea of any initial problems on your drone.  This testing ground also mimics your current location so youll have a great feel of its performance in the given tasked area.

Potential - The developer is active.  Things like PVP racing will be coming to the game and I hope in the future many more game modes.  These offshoot game modes are really where the game shines IMO

*Note at this time PVP is not with an active opponent but rather vs there drones design which is handled by AI or automation.

My Dislikes:
Single Player Planetary Missions - I have little interest in the single player planet hoping campaign through the cosmos.  It is indeed fun at first with making all sorts of weaponized designs as well as being able to create monsterious drones.  It just gets a bit repeatitive after awhile once you know all the planet missions.  I specifically hate collecting barrels.  I would definitly change this view if it was possible to create a fully automated drone that could handle complex tasks though.  The available logic however does not currently allow you to automate designs on planet missions. Generally you are designing manually controlled drones to perform the tasks such as kill, collect, or mine for resources.  I am okay with this but I would like the ability to design fully automated drones.  This would let me play a mission and observe how my automated drone is doing and make any improvements.  Once I am happy I could get up and do other things and come back hoping the drone completed the tasks I programmed it to do.  If this was possible then the planet to planet adventure would be SO much better IMO and I would actually enjoy designing automated drones to accomplish the planetary tasks instead of manually controlled ones.  Missing (Mineral Sensors/ Better Enemy Detection Sensors/Object detection sensors such as barrels).... I believe at the minimum those are some of the logic block needs to make a drone for planetary dives automated somewhat effectively.

All in all however I have dumped tons of hours designing SUMO drones in this one simple side mode and having tons of fun.  I am confident with  updates.. logic blocks, drone parts, additional PVP modes this game is going to be even more amazing.  It is up to you if drone design and logic design is your jam.

Thanks for Reading o/

author: {'steamid': '76561198139967041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1548563112}
review:
The game is awesome, the devs are awesome, the potential for this game is pretty much unlimited. Can be a little hard to design your first drones, so don't hesitate to use a drone from the integrated steam workshop.

I would love the ability to "cycle" through the cameras, because once you start mass producing bots with cameras, they become sort of useless since it averages the position of all of them. Or have the ability to zoom out even more, to have an overview or the planet.

Oddly enough, there aren't as many bugs as you would expect from this type of game, especially in early access. I haven't come across any annoying bug yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047328753', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3157, 'last_played': 1605014898}
review:
I see you all gathered around this altar to Our Great Drone Overlord, and I am pleased by your fervour. Let us begin the service.

As you know, in the beginning there was only darkness: the malware entity known as The Corp, moved to the Recycle Bin be its name, had taken hold of most of the Computed Universe, and there stood nary an opponent to their nefarious processes. From a galaxy to the other, the servants of the Uninstallers of All That Is Drone carried on for cycles with harming the very core of our worlds, and there was no rationale out of this arbitrary.
Until, one day, Our Great Drone Overlord Nimbatus, praised be all its Storage Addresses, deemed it was time for the logical balance of all things to be restored; and so it granted us Administrator Privileges over the Module of Implement, the embodiment of Its Grand Equation in our physical plane, through which we were to become Its Logical Processors. Our Great Drone Overlord, sung to the Logical Plane be Its existence, in all Its computing magnificence, then shut down Its display functions and went back to what we irrational beings only see as a dormant state; but It is still there, sensing, and analysing our praising and pleasing It.
Not a person could decipher the divine processes of Nimbatus, may all Its Logic Gates compute, but in Its grandiose accomplishment it gave us the interface to communicate with Its Module. All believers, no matter how well-versed or neophyte they are, are thus able to comprehend and use the Module of Implement, even though only the most fervent will make the most out of it through the teachings of Its Great Helper, the Divinity Automation.

All of this, my friends, to put a stop to the malevolent actions of the dreaded Corp, may their circuits fry and melt! But, as you may have understood, no Divine Being such as Nimbatus would meddle directly in the affairs of our kind; instead, It sent Its Harbinger and Creator, and it is now upon us to implement the wish of Our Great Drone Overlord.
And by "us", I mean you.

[b]---[/b]

*ahem*
I honestly have not had this much fun with a drone builder in... well, my whole life, I would say. It is simple to get the hang of, lets one craft extremely complex designs, and while it currently suffers from a certain lack of extra feature, or balance between available options (particularly in weapon upgrades), most of your wishes are to be implemented during development. There is enough logic available to grow fed up of it, the ultimate Sumo Arena mode (even more brutal than the real-life competition), loving developers, a handy forum on which all things Nimbatus are to be found, and most importantly: your imagination and craftiness are pretty much the only limits. Whether you want to raze planets, mine ore, make a racing track for two players to compete (before the developers implement it!), or organise a drone ballet, it is all possible.

Join us [url=https://strayfawnstudio.com/community/index.php?/forum/4-nimbatus-the-space-drone-constructor/]on the forums[/url]! A demo is available there, and I suggest you try it out very soon because the game is changing quickly. Also, if you would just like to take a peak at current possibilities, come and say hello! We welcome all newcomers with open arms.

One last thing: the developers earn more if you buy on [url=https://www.humblebundle.com/store/nimbatus-the-space-drone-constructor]Humble Bundle[/url]. I actually bought my copy of Nimbatus from there, and it is the same game all around.

Thanks for reading, and have fun building!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967805614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4226, 'last_played': 1595807857}
review:
Nimbatus is a game about making your own drone, and flying it on missions.  The basis for it is quite simple.  The logistics of construction is where it really shines.  There's almost nothing you can't do.  

Would you like to put an explosive TNT block on a detachable mount with sensors, to create an enemy-seeking missile, instead of using actual weapon?  Maybe instead of flying, you'd like to make a walker?  It will be challenging, but can be done.  Would you like to chain together a masive chain of ships into a massive snake-ship, spewing death in all directions?  Maybe you'd like to install logic modules, to create a turret that detects and targets enemies for you; or even a drone whose sole purpose is to autonomously eradicate every scrap of mass on the planet.  You could even set up factories that deploy swarms of subdrones, or that discard one weapon set to manufacture another, as needed.

If you have the mind of an engineer, I think you'll enjoy this game immensely; and as development progresses, the roadmap looks promising, with racing drone challenges coming soon. (As of 11/20) 

If you take an interest, visit http://www.strayfawnstudio.com/ and check out their community; they have a feature request section that can get your idea in the game, if it's good, and the developers are constantly monitoring it.  Their previous game is still getting updates and is still monitored by the devs as well, which I think is a good sign that this game, as well, will not be neglected even after it comes out of early access.

Pros: 
Very involved building system, with the ability to use a network of logic to simply but effectively coordinate complex activity.  

Weapon workshops let you upgrade and adapt weapons, both for more effectiveness, and to adapt them to unique purposes.  

Diverse mission types involve more challenges that require multiple builds, or a very careful and complete single build.

Asynchronous multiplayer arena called 'sumo' in which you craft an autonomous drone to push an opponent designed by a human out of a ring, which shrinks over time.

Asynchronous Racing Arenas coming soon, with Combat Arenas coming soon.

Planets and missions are procedurally generated, providing a wealth of unique worlds.

Weather system on the roadmap for development.

Cons: 

Mission types are limited, and can get repetitive with time.

Only a few very challenging enemies as of yet.

Progression mechanics are intended, but not yet implemented.

Currently, only one arena, sumo, is available.

review:
This is a game for everyone who craves a bit more depth in their contraption-designing games. 

For an early access title, there's quite a lot of depth here already. You can design everything, from agile small fighters to huge battlecruisers or even fully autonomous drones operating only on sensors. You can build tiny spaceships that can launch a huge wall of steel, or swarms of homing drills - there's really no limit.  

The sumo arena is great for letting your drones compete against others.  

Being an early access title, this is still in active development. I had the pleasure of playing this game at a few conventions already, and it's always great to jump in again and see how much has changed.  

In short, I can definitely recommend this to all tinkerers out there. The content is still growing, but it's already more than enough to keep sandbox fans entertained for quite some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195573459', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 5825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4479, 'last_played': 1660133690}
review:
[strike]At its current stage of development, it is a sandbox game, but not an ordinary sandbox. In the main game mode, instead of restricting you to create challenge, it uses a make-your-own-rules system to let you express your creativity. Break the game with factories. Have the biggest ship in the universe. The logic gates in this game are very fun to play with, allowing for even more possibilities, especially in automation. There are also plans to have sandbox planets, I believe, allowing for even more creativity. The only limits are your PC's capabilities (and maybe the game's physics capabilities) and there's never any downside to going bigger, using certain parts, etc, as you can always just add more thrusters and such. Currently, there isn't much variety on planets and transmitter effects, so making your own rules is quite important, especially in the game's current stage. The best/most fun ships aren't always the most efficient/effective.

If you like to be creative, and make your own rules, this is a decent game. However, as many of the negative reviews point out, if you're more of a survivalist, or looking for non-self-made challenges, it may not be the best and will likely become *very* repetitive for you during this phase in the game.

There is also a sumo mode, where you ram, avoid, or do... something else to stay in the ring, and it is a very balanced rock-paper-scissors-style mode. It is more for the challenge, and is more restricting, but still very fun to make different styles of drones to combat each other. I believe new modes are also planned.

I'd say the community is *very* important is this game, as there's no point sharing your cool drone to a wooden wall. I'd recommend joining the Discord.[/strike]

This review is less applicable to the current version of the game. However, it remains a gem to be played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198336660052', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1889, 'last_played': 1629491884}
review:
I got the game for free via a gif competition, so take my feedback on if it's worth buying with a grain of salt.

Nimbatus is a sandbox game about building and (sometimes) piloting ships.
There are two modes an "adventure/endless" mode were you fly to an endless amount of proceduraly generated planets with different objectives environments and terrain, the missions can vary between destroy an enemy at the middle of the planet to collect leaking bio barrels with magnets. The planets do look a bit similar and monotone, and the missions are pretty similar (it's usually a mission were you have to kill/destroy something) But the game is still in early access and has improved.

The second mode is "sumo" and this is were most of the meat and replayability of the game is (according to me).
In sumo you have to build a fully autonomous drone with some restraints (no weapons, can't be too big, and a part limit). Once the drone is complete it faces off against another playermade drone, and you get to watch (NOT control) as the two drones fight against eachother, trying to push the other out of the shrinking ring.

This game has a variety of parts, simple blocks, hinges, springs, weapons, thrusters, fuel, and most importantly logic and sensors.
These parts are what you can use, you can connect them together and create huge or small drones. The physics can get a bit whacky and the parts aren't really balanced. But that's part of the fun, trying to find "weird" physics and workaround it or use it to your advantage.
The game also has a "factory" part which can create new parts (and thereby drones) out of thin air, it can even make more factories, this is one of the most fun parts of the game and can be used to create various different fun stuff.

In short, it's a decent game with a fun building system, the physics can use some polishing and the planets get a bit repetitive. This game is best for those who like to use simple components and logic gates to make powerful creations.

If your not sure if you want to buy the game there's a free demo, it doesn't have all the parts, it's less polished and it's overall worse but it gives you a decent look of the game. https://www.nimbatus.ch/SuperSecretDemo/

author: {'steamid': '76561198054195233', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1589527134}
review:
So I'm still new to reviews, go easy on me-

gonna keep it simple-

This game is really fun to drop in and mess around in. I like making random weird designs just because I can and seeing what works and what does, though that can also be a big frustrating at times. I played the tutorial buuuut it didn't really help me too much. I feel like this is the kind of game that if you know what you're doing it becomes infinitely more fun. I enjoy it as it is, I'm not the brightest bulb so I have troubles building some of the more awesome designs, but what i've seen people pull off is just insane... the amount of things you can do in this game is crazy.

Weapons have their own little upgrade trees that you can research into to make them better (which I'm a big fan of. It's always nice to not be stuck with just the base weapons) but the game can be a biiig difficult for folks like me who don't really know too much about how logic gates work and stuff like that. It's not fault of the games, it's my own ineptitude that's to blame. But it doesn't detract from the fun I can have just putting a ton of rockets on a drone and seeing how fast I can slam it into a rock for my own giggles.

You can really get into the customization of this, hell I know a few friends who'd probably get lost in it for days on end because of how far you can go with it... which actually makes me want to get better at the game so that I can do something of the cool things too!

I only have a couple hours in the game, but I'm doing my best to try to learn and do better with it. Can be hard though, but the game has a decent number of tutorials you can go through to try to learn. Though if you're like me, it's going to be difficult to understand lol.

All in all, the flaws don't outweigh the positives. If you're really into programming, logic gates and building giant hulking robot monstrosities, I think you'll enjoy this game. If you just want to goof off, probably not the best choice... there is still quite a bit of work you need to do to make the drones fly properly... trust me, after about 5-6 failed drones i'm slowly learning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063975226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 983, 'last_played': 1540997114}
review:
自分でドローンを設計して操作し、色んな星のミッションをクリアするゲームです。

メインストーリーはアーリーアクセスという事もあり、似たようなミッションばかりで次第に退屈してくるのですが、SUMO ARENAという所でドローン同士のスモウを楽しむ事ができて、これにすっかりハマってしまいました。

スモウには非武装の自律型ドローン（回路を使って全自動で動くように設計されたドローン）しか出場できないのですが、回路やセンサーを駆使して色んな戦略を試すのが楽しくてたまりません。

特に「カルネージハート」とかが好きな人には断然オススメです。対戦相手をSteam Workshopからダウンロードできますし、トーナメントモードで世界の誰かが作ったドローンと戦って勝ち抜く事もできます。
私はメインそっちのけでスモウドローンばっかり作ってしまうほどハマってしまいました。
さらに、他のバトルモードも予定されているようです。

日本語には対応していませんが、そんなに難しい英語ではないので、頑張ればどうにか意味が分かるレベルだと思います。また、チュートリアルをこなせば、それなりのドローンは作れるようになります。
メインの方もアップデートによって徐々に拡充されているようですし、自分好みのメカを設計するのが好きな人にオススメです。

author: {'steamid': '76561198231809984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1563676584}
review:
I gave this game a  thumbs down thoguh it is in early access so I'm hoping thiey'll change it a lot.  I've been anticipating this game ever since I saw it on game jolt.  It looked so fun and I couldn't wait to get it.  I eventually forgot about it.  Then I was browsing around on steam and found it again.  I bought it and, well, it wasn't at all what I thought it was gonna be.  I guess it was my fault.  I should've done more research.

    I expected this game to be a sandbox game in which you gather resources to an ultimate drone.  What I got was a game where you get infinite resources to tediously make a drone using the limited  of parts they give you to launch it into a repetitive, prodecurally generated world with dry missions and boring enemies.

    Okay, I'm being a little rough.  It's not like I hate this game.  I am and still intend to continue playing this game.  I just think it wasn't worth the $20.  I just hope that they add more ways for exciting gameplay.  Maybe even a multiplayer?  Multiplayer would be freaking fun(not talking about the sumo gamemode).  

    The devs have a great foundation to make something great, With the gathering resources and all that, but they made a perk tree for it?  The perks are boring and unsatisfying.  Just make the bricks cost money.  Also PLEASE remove the snake monster.  It's so annoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189528214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3097, 'last_played': 1595829170}
review:
Nimbatus is a great game that ha sucked away my free time.

Tutorial:
The tutorial is not the best, it only tells you the bare minimum in its first section on how to build a mobile craft, and all the other tutorials are basically useless, the only usefull one for the ingame content is the logic section that teaches you how to build a basic ramming style sumo drone even thougb the objective is to create a drone to fly forwards with no context as for why you need to know what this could be used for. ALSO the in the harvesating tutorial the ore does not get harvested correctly, it shrinks into the center unlike chunks being ripped off of the ore in the acutal game.

Missions
The missions are fun for the first few times, you go kill some bee hives and you can go kill some snake eggs, and you can go collect some explose barrels of pain and missery, that kind of stuff, exterminate and collection missions nothing else other than the sumo arenas. But after a while the missions get repetitive and you will need new ways to entertain yourself, here are a few ideas, use a rover style craft, or use only guns to move, or even use the torque of the wheels to turn your craft as you fly arround as a rover climbing the rocks or magma. But the point is the missions are repetitive and the only way to make them more challanging or fun it to make impratical machines such as a magnet cannon to shoot creatures with, and saddly blunt force truama is not a effective way to kill things.

Building
The building is great, you get a while bunch of parts that you have no idea how to use and experiment on how to use them in interesting ways, such as regrowing armor, carpet bombers, and creating a logic gate that allready exists but a tiny bit differently. You do need to do a bit of math for fuel and energy consuption for sheilds and thrusters but that is to be expected if you want sheilds to stay up at all hours of the day. the alerts for things such as possible instabilities are nice and the kebind alert is useful if your building something with alot of parts and it all has to work proporly, the tag system is also wonderful but i personaly dont use it since typing out all the tags is annoying. Also you get to set ALL of the controls, you can have your shields on LShift or e dosent matter, same with the movement parts.

Worlds:
NOW here is were it gets to be the worst... you can fly around for a while untill you go under ground and then you suddenly cant move because a molecule of dust us in the way, this is the BIGGEST problem for the game in my oppinion, the fact you cant see what is stopping you movement even after a laser sweep is not the best for when your in the core of a lava planet harvesting resources. But other than that HUGE problem the worlds are great since usally they have resources unless the game hates you for one specific moment when your in a transmitter field that compromises all of your mobility.

Overall:
Thats basically all i can think of for this game, its fun when you can be creative enough to use its mechanics in werid unexpected ways, and a molecule of dust can be the most infuriating thing in existance.

also we need a way to detect different types of surface materials, such as basically impossible to dig through or its a hot knife through butter, also i want to detect resources, the fact you can detect everything but surface density and resources is kind of sad.

review:
[RECOMMEND ON SALE]
Awesome creative experience. Design crazy drones, dig up all da treasure and destroy (most things). 

The locked (up in your face) zoom rate does throttle the fun for me to a degree Im probably not going to play the game again. It works for small drones but for larger ones its just annoying. You can try to solve the issue with cameras but its a pain in the a... 

I foresee this game going in one of two directions: 

A. Paternalistic design that limits the players creativity based on (lets face it: arbitrary) developer opinions. => This game will prob. do fine and be an ok game. Worst thing that could happen would be to emplore some kind of "cost" on components - making experimentation tedious and grindy. Will appeal to some people - but not most. 

B. Full player autonomy and freedom (such as with zoom levels). This could basically become the minecraft of 2D side-perspective space games. Will appeal, with better tutorials, to the wide masses. 

I got, as you have probably guess, my fingers crossed for outcome B.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061644371', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1561985520}
review:
比起别的那些「We need Chinese」，我想这款游戏在游戏机制和图形交互上才是真正的「We need Chinese」



配置：I7-6700HQ

           GTX 970M

           16G RAM

           WIN10

讲道理这个配置五年之内应该没改编，要不观众老爷们就默认了吧



各位好，我是长弓，感谢奶牛关野蔷薇和作者给予的免费体验资格。



本次受评游戏是Nimbatus - The Space Drone Constructor，STEAM报价70￥



最近比较忙，就像这款游戏的体验一样，匆匆忙忙，缺少的东西还是很多。



首先不得不说，这确实是一个很有意思的游戏，他拥有一个飞船建造系统，玩家可以在这个系统上设计自己的飞船。

但问题在于，这个飞船设计功能中最为重要的结构件链接，他用的是A-B的连接方式，并且这个方式不能逆向。

也就意味着，A方块与B方块的链接只能通过A链接B或者B链接A单向完成，这会导致一个问题，有些需要反向加固才能加固完成的结构件在这款游戏里变得很难处理，不论怎么操作飞船都会出现晃动甚至是散架，十分麻烦。



另一方面，这款游戏的内容上目前还不够完善，除了收集和打击敌人之外，这款游戏上目前还没有体现出其他比较丰富的玩法，这是对这款游戏一个比较严重的打点，也是我这几天一直没能够长时间坚持下来玩的主要原因——她太没劲了。

如果你下载创意工坊图纸进行游戏，你会发现这个游戏就变成了很单调的2D飞船射击搜集游戏，游戏本身虽然地图很庞大，但给人的体验感并不丰富，只能说还需要一定程度上的优化。

当然，70元的报价加上后续内容还是十分值得的，如果这款游戏能够保证对后续的内容进行一定程度的更新，我想是没有问题的。

author: {'steamid': '76561198045704341', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1735, 'last_played': 1539403511}
review:
If Beseiged and Starbound had a baby this game would be their offspring. The game has some really good points, and things that are mind numbingly boring. There is a ton of freedom in creating new drones and after some experimentation finding what works for your mission at hand.

Pros:
Fully Customizable Creations
Soundtrack

Cons
Missions become repetative fast.
Tutorials are too basic.

Unfortunately the progression gets bland. You end up doing the same types of mission over and over to get to the next galaxy. Luckily they change between galaxies but it quickly falls back into the same progression. The saving quality is the autonomous sumo arenas that are brilliant. I also find fault with the tutorial system. On complex ideas the tutorial breezes by and doesn't dedicate any time to the building concepts needed to manufacture a drone that will successfully utilize those components.

I still recommend this game for it's gameplay and potential. If you enjoy building mass mechanized creations and destroying planets then this game will be for you. If you don't enjoy spending an hour on build screens before you actually get to play then this game may not be for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087708598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1539944169}
review:
コアにパーツをつなげて自分で自機をデザインし、小惑星の資源採掘や敵殲滅のミッションに挑むシューティング。ゲームコンセプトはReassemblyによく似ている。Reassemblyとの違いは見下ろし式ではなく重力の影響を受ける横スクロールシューティングっぽいことくらいだ。Reassemblyより優れていると思った点は明示的な攻略ミッションがあって、ステージごとに機体設計を試行錯誤できる楽しさがあるところか。非武装の機体でエリアから押し出しあうVSモード的なものもあり、なかなか面白い。

日本語なしだが簡単な英語を読めるならそれほど問題ないレベル。機体の設計をダウンロードできるため、一通り入手し、挙動を理解すれば、複雑な設計もできるようになるだろう。



早期アクセスだが、気になった点は以下の通り。

最初から重量制限やパーツ制限がほぼなく、いきなり巨大な戦艦を作れてしまう。資源を回収するシステムはあるが、アップグレードにしか使えず、パーツを買い集めて少しづつ強化していくような楽しみがない。ここはReassemblyより劣る。せっかくステージ攻略の楽しみがあるのに強化の楽しみが乏しい。Reassemblyのようなパーツを買うシステムにして煩雑なアップグレードシステムはなくしてしまったほうがよいのではないか？

全般的に移動が遅くてモサい。推進機をたくさんつけても高速化の頭打ちが速い。視点が自機によりすぎて周囲の状況が把握しにくいのと相まってゲーム進行が緩慢な感じなのはもう少しなんとかならないだろうか。

削り残した１ピクセルくらい小さい岩に引っかかっても、機体が完全につっかえて進まなくなる。小さい岩とかは体当たりで削り落とせるようにしてほしい。また壁や地面に機体が接触すると接着剤で貼りつけられたかのように動きが止まり、接地面をレーザーで削る等しないと離脱しにくいのも、もうすこし緩和してほしいところ。

敵が固い。最初からほぼ制限なく機体をつくれる弊害か、一番弱い雑魚ですら何十発もビームを撃ち込まないと破壊できず、爽快感に乏しい。

ファクトリーをつけると無限再生・増殖できるので、このへんが理解できてしまうと急激に難易度が下がって緊張感がなくなり作業感が急増。



現状は「屋台骨はいいが、もう一声」といったところ。今後のアップグレードに期待。

author: {'steamid': '76561198094288481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 28818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6931, 'last_played': 1586032891}
review:
See all those cool inventions on the store front? You won't be building anything like that in campaign mode, or ever, probably. Creative mode has tons of cool tools for you to use and absolutely zero reasons to ever use them. Campaign mode gives you reasons to innovate and punishes you for doing it. Competitive still shines, but that's one out of three game modes, two of which I can no longer recommend. 

The game isn't what it used to be.
developer_response:
Hi Garheardt the Black

I see what you mean. You know the game really well and your point is a valid one. If you play survival as a normal captain, building big drones is not feasible or a good strategy. But that's how we designed that specific mode.

To counter that somewhat, if you play as the programmer captain in survival, you have no parts limits whatsoever. You have unlimited part and no deploy cost and therefore can build drones as big as you want. But you have to use logic parts only, no direct input allowed.

So it is definitely possible to build big drones in the game (I mean, most of the big drones from the trailer and screenshots are from the Nimbatus community). But to build all these huge constructions we advise you to play in sandbox or play around in the test drives (we added a new one with a test planet).

We also improved the sandbox mode considerably. It is now possible to play exactly like the survival mode, but you can turn off all limits. This way you can build big drones if you like to.

I'm happy that you like the competitive modes. I would love if you could check out the newest update which is the release candidate for our full launch. Let us know what you think.

Cheers and thanks for your feedback,
Markus

author: {'steamid': '76561198002536629', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1044, 'last_played': 1539693907}
review:
変な構造物を作って体当たりをする様子を見て楽しむ物理ゲームです

さあ、みんなでSUMOをしよう！



センサーの出力と論理装置の入出力は全てキー入力になります。
例えばジャンプスラスターは、溜めて離すという複雑な操作を要求されますが、次のように設定することで使用できます。

1.ジャンプスラスターでMキー
→これだけでは動かない

2.NOTでNキーが押されなければMキーを押す
→チャージができるようになる。まだダメ。(ボタンで動かそうとするとどうすんだコレってなる)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359498', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1539594276}
review:
What if Kerbal Space Program got a little weird?  Well… weirder?  Maybe if a little Besiege snuck in there and got mixed up in the crazy drone building.  Take all of that and throw it at some odd missions like destroying giant space snake eggs or picking up toxic explosive barrels.   Then toss in an extra game mode that almost feels like an entirely separate game tacked on using a handful of the same parts and mechanics.  Is it fun? Well, most of the time…

Abbreviated Review: https://youtu.be/94GMv4BVkec

[h1] If you build it… use some guns [/h1]

The core of Nimbatus is about building drones.  The limitations in drone building are very few in number and the defining factor in whether or not a drone is at all useful for each of the missions you’ll end up encountering is if the thing can actually move correctly and do the objective that it needs to do.  In most missions, there is only the requirement - that it has a weapon. The mission will suggest some things like basic ‘you’ll have to dig’ kind of stuff, but you’re free to use as many parts and make it as big or small as you want.  It makes it possible for you to generate some truly wild drone designs.  It becomes sort of a challenge in itself to build multipurpose or super specialized drones to make each mission easier or more fun to do.  Personally, I don’t even think I have a fraction of the creativity that some other players have.  Taking a peek in the Steam Workshop integration showed me that quite early on.  Thankfully, if you want to see some extra wild stuff, you can download some drones from the workshop and try them out yourself.  Technically, you don’t even have to build anything for most missions because of that, but even with minimal creativity, you can have a lot of fun trying to put together something that actually works and succeeds in a mission.  Given the dynamic aspects of the different planets and mission types, sometimes a drone that works for one thing, for instance destroying snake eggs, may not work for much else – or even that same type of mission if something like gravity or air density is different.  There really isn't a do-it-all drone to be crafted given the variety of missions available, or at least if you do try to create one, you're going to work extra hard flying it effectively in a lot of scenarios.  

[h1] Mission: Avoided [/h1]

The progress through each galaxy has you hopping to different systems and doing missions on some or all of the planets in them in order to unlock the route to the next one.  Of the ones I've seen so far, there are two branching paths that lead you on to the next (apparently) procedurally generated galaxy.  It reminds me a bit of FTL from that map perspective.  Each defeated planet marks some triangles underneath.  The more difficult the mission, the more triangles are marked.  The path to the next system has a triangle requirement and once completed you can move to it.  This means, if a planet's mission isn't what you want to deal with, you can just do a different one and still potentially progress.  I have noticed that there's a little bit of repetition in the missions and sometimes I avoid them on that basis alone.  It seemed like in the first galaxy I visited there were half a dozen snake egg missions.  The second comprised mostly broken planets that required small drones to navigate through.  What is ubiquitous though – and what can get you far with the right drone – are Sumo matches.

[h1] SUMO ACTION [/h1]

Within each system, there's a relatively high chance of there being a Sumo arena.  These require you to build a drone that is entirely automated without weapons to push (or avoid) a drone in an enclosed arena.  First one to have their core knocked out of the ever-shrinking circle loses.  The missions in the systems require that you only to beat one drone to proceed and the drone varies in quality – but all seem to be player made.  However, in every galaxy there's a separate Sumo arena at the bottom that allows you to put your creation into a tournament that has it going in a series of matches against increasingly tough opponents.  This ended up being the most entertaining thing in Nimbatus.

The tools you have to make your drone self-sufficient are pretty extensive.  While my greatest sumo drone relied only on being nimble and having a ton of sensors, there are tools that essentially allow you to build rudimentary AI with programmatic functions like “if then” “or” “xor” and branching paths.  There are tracking eyes and special switches that can all go into making some incredible creations that blew me away in how great they were at the simple task of pushing a drone out of a circle.  After spending so much time in Sumo tweaking my drone and trying to imagine one half as cool as some that I went up against, I could see this game mode being its own game and probably a pretty successful one at that.  

[h1] A Tale of Two Game Modes [/h1]

Nimbatus would have been somewhat forgettable in its current state if it were just jumping from planet to planet desperately wishing you had a bigger FOV to shoot things from further away.  That portion of the game, while enjoyable in the short term, lacks the staying power to carry this game on its own unless you are really in to trying drone variations.  Thankfully, the relatively hands-off Sumo mode is super exciting.  Sure, it gets cheesed a little bit, but it really shows off ingenuity of players and proves for some extremely tense moments when you're desperately hoping your drone can survive.  At $20, Nimbatus may be a little steep for an early access game, but if you can get it on sale it's worth picking up to test your imagination and ingenuity by building automated drones for the Sumo competition.  I hope that they flesh out the core gameplay, perhaps improving mission structure or making it easier to ships to obtain resources without bulking out your designs.  The research process itself probably could use a rework too as I still find it clunky and a little confusing when trying to upgrade or create new weapons.  In general though, unless you want to get in on the ground floor of Sumo, you can probably wait for release or a sale.

[quote] If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28346672-Endyo-Gaming/ and https://www.thegamemessiah.com[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198001627754', 'num_games_owned': 549, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3393, 'last_played': 1545146105}
review:
Do you like using logic gates to create moving, functioning objects?
Do you like using logic to create automated or controllable objects?
Do you like the idea of friendly competition?
Do you believe in continual improvement and that all things may continue to grow?

If the answer to any one of those questions was yes, you would enjoy this game. Games aren't always about being immersed in a world or being enticed by beautiful visuals (not that the game is ugly to look at). Games at their core are about enjoyment and interaction.

The community is great. Opening the game and utilizing the Discord button from the main menu makes this game incredible. Capturing GIFs with a single keystroke to share your creations and show off a little bit is cool. Uploading your drones to the workshop and fighting in sumo tournaments against other players feels friendly and inclusive.

The devs are active. They are working on this game. It is clear that it is well tended. They are friendly, and interact with their Discord server as well.

I'm a frugal person. With the 44 (2/3 is likely idling) in my current playtime, I feel like I have already gotten my money's worth at retail price. I'll be buying the game twice more at least, for my brother and my son.

Best yet, there's more to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000652622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 968, 'last_played': 1539388964}
review:
Nimbatus seems pretty fun. The drone construction part is quite entertaining as is trying out a drone on a new world and trying to overcome the challenges you find. I find although the specific experience in the first video don't match mine, they capture the essence of the gameplay very well. Try-Fail-Improve-Rinse & Repeat

Overall, I'd say Nimbatus is very promising and is currently quite fun, if a relatively short experience. I'm looking forward to when they add new mission types and other new content. Despite my gripes below, I managed to find myself addicted for over 14 hours the first day I started playing it.

However, some things are less than ideal - 
1) You'll quickly get bored of the rescue bio barrel missions and most of the other missions get kinda easy once you get better at designing drones. Worse some missions are more bugged than hard, like XOPICY (beatable, but better hurry before the meteors, otherwise you'll just wonder why you can't find more than 4 barrels)
2) there are certain quality-of-life things that would really improve the experience of the drone editor, like being able to split off sections of a design and replacing a non-leaf item with another without a ton of dragging, etc.
3) the progression system for weapons feels lacking still, and all the ores only seem to be used to unlock new weapons. Basically, at first you can't get all three ores, so your stuck with super imprecise weapons. Later you'll unlock a lava world and be able to get all kinds of ore simply by griding as much as you want, so it basically goes from being a gating system to being a slight grind, and then you can unlock almost anything in the tech tree without a lot of effort. Also, you can't pick custom icons for the custom weapons so it can get pretty confusing
4) some of the nodes are pretty non-self explanatory so you'll probably have to google the sensor node, the no-key passing node the key-passing node, and the factory nodes if you want to understand them, but even then the documentation online was pretty sparse atm (the game was very recently released into early access)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054544579', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3075, 'last_played': 1587941246}
review:
I think Nimbatus is a very good game that has the potential to be great. Potential. Right now it's in early access and unless you can get creative with building drones there's not much to do. There are 2 types of planets and a total 7 types of missions plus a sumo mode. If you want to see challenging missions that require you to build special drones, you may want to wait a bit before buying this game.

If you're like me and are perfectly happy spending 90% of your in-game time building drones, then the good news is there is still a lot you can do even in early access. There's a small variety of parts that can be used in countless ways to create unique drones, along with a collection of logic parts allowing you to make automatic drones or simply make your drone a bit more sophisticated. There are several types of weapons with a variety of upgrades that range from nearly pointless to overpowered. There are no limits on how you build your drone (unless you're building a sumo drone), so you can go crazy and build a massive mothership or make an actual [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1528556734]skeleton[/url] that does nothing.

Overall, I think the game is incredibly fun, and while it has lots of small flaws I am hopeful that they will be fixed in the near future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001665911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1533, 'last_played': 1621055141}
review:
I've been playing this game quite a bit with my kid.  I manage the drone while she does the guns.  So I guess multiplayer is possible even with one PC :)

Overall, I recommend the game.  The build system is simply brilliant.  It gives the capability to build extremely sophisticated drones using very simple systems.  I haven't played yet played the game long enough to discover an 'ultimate design' though I'm sure such a thing probably exists.

Although it's in early access, the game is also very stable.  I've never seen it crash, and I've seen no serious bugs.  I feel the game does deliver enough value for its price tag and that the developers aren't just selling promises.

Pros:
+ Awesome build system gives lots of space for creative expression.  You'll go to bed dreaming of what you can build next.
+ Missions are hard enough to challenge you but not so much that they frustrate you
+ Unlock system is quite well implemented.
+ Good UX.  The game feels like it's been well tested and is fairly streamlined.
+ Minimal bugs and issues
+ Sumo rings are pretty cool, though I'm sure that in a few weeks all the drones will be unbeatable

Cons:
- Needs more mission types.  The procedural generation helps to prevent things from getting too bad, but I got really sick of picking up those barrels.
- Progression needs more work.  Right now you'll get only 3-4 different mission types for the first galaxy, and then the next galaxy you'll get another 2-3.  This makes the game feel repetitive, even though the later missions do give more variety.  Sadly I think that many people probably give up before they finish the first galaxy, because they think that's all there is to the game.
- No multiplayer, unless you like sharing a PC with a friend to control different components of the same drone
- Background music can get very repetitive, especially in the drone edit screen (can be switched off though)

author: {'steamid': '76561198202899841', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1057, 'last_played': 1666063084}
review:
This is a great game with awesome building and physics mechanics.  You can build pretty complicated drones, and as of now there isn't really a limit on how powerful or big a drone can be.  The main downside right now are that there are just 4 missions, which will of course change as more updates come out.  As of now, once you build four drones, one for each mission, there is no real incentive to build more or keep progressing them since they can easily complete every world.  A sandbox mode is also needed in a game like this, but we don't have one yet.  I assume there will eventually be one implemented.  We also need a higher fov default for drones.

If they continue on the current path, this game will be a beauty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198394798090', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1539253268}
review:
[code] 
[h1][b] Nimbatus —— 一个充满创造力的游戏 [/b][/h1] 
本评测来自于[b]小黑盒安利计划[/b] 
[url=https://api.xiaoheihe.cn/bbs/app/api/web/share?link_id=7672501]完整文章内容请点击[/url] 
[/code] 
 
[h1]前言[/h1] 

       本作和《重组》相似，都是2D的太空建造类游戏，但两者在同一个题材下玩出了不同的花样。相比于《重组》里边划分的三个种族，本作并没有这样的设定，而是设计为，一个探索宇宙的种族或者说侵略者更合适，然后你会探索各个星球，完成一个个小任务，打怪，采矿，或者是别的什么的。
 
[h1]长文不看者专属[/h1] 

[b]Pros[/b] 
[olist] 
[*]优点1 丰富的战机配件，可以制作出任何东西。
[*]优点2 新颖的游戏玩法，与众不同的游戏模式，一边造战机一边检验成果。
[*]优点3 支持创意工厂供玩家交流作品。
[*]优点4 丰富的技能树，调教出属于自己的武器属性。
[*]优点5 目前游戏只有英文，可以锻炼英语。
[*]优点6 游戏有新手教程，方便新手上手。
[/olist] 
 
[b]Cons[/b] 
[olist] 
[*]缺点1 游戏设计界面有的时候操作有些捉鸡，交互还待改进。
[*]缺点2 机体的形状和颜色有点少，在造型的设计上有些不便。
[*]缺点3 期待联机和好友互怼。
[/olist] 
 
[h1]购买扫盲[/h1] 
[list] 
[*]我觉得这个版本可以买。虽然目前游戏只有英文，但是并不难看懂，而且文本量也不大，主要是需要玩家自己的创造力，来帮助制作属于自己的独一无二的战机，发挥你的想象力方可实现一切。 
[/list] 
 
[h1] 模式与玩法 [/h1] 

    游戏主要就是两种模式，一种是用你造的飞船去攻击摧毁各种东西，造的飞船一般没有人要要求，自己想做成什么样子都行，对战的时候你可以用炸弹炸死敌人；用毒龙钻等近战武器，或者单纯靠自己战机的身体撞碎别人；还可以使用远程武器打击敌人，在武器的使用上要比《重组》丰富（我玩重组是比较早的时候了，所以如果有什么变化，导致写的不对还请见谅）。

    而另一种模式则是相扑模式，顾名思义，相扑就是两个人单挑，然后尽可能的把对手推出圈子就算成功。如果一段时间内没有把对手推出去，那么圈就会缩小，战斗范围会更小。不仅如此，你还要注意的是，相扑模式要求的战机是不能带武器的，同时要求战机全自动驾驶，也就是说你要在开始之前调试好你的战机，对决开始之后就只能看场上两个战机各自的表演了。

[h1] 战机的制造 [/h1]

与任务和玩法相比，感觉这个游戏造战机才是最主要的，这个游戏从拿到手，其实我花了4个小时研究了战机制作的系统，虽然在建造时候好多操作很让人捉急，但确实是一个非常强大的制作系统。

    相比于《重组》里边的多彩缤纷的几何体，确实这个游戏的模型太过于单调了，基本上都是矩形，而无法做出三角形等各种形状，我觉得这个官方后期会考虑增加以下。不过在连接件上，就没有《重组》那种固定插槽的限制，一个东西上你想接多少就可以接多少零件，当然接太多会提示这个零件有些承受不住，这个时候你就把想接的接在别的零件上就好了，而且零件的方向可以自由调整，可以说自由度非常的高。

    除此之外，机体的系统也是更加的复杂，武器需要安装能量装置（姑且这么叫吧）为武器提供能量，动力系统需要装油箱，提供动力来源。而且这些能量装置和油箱都不是无限的，你用的时候，里边的能量会减少，然后你不用的时候就会慢慢自己回满，尤其是你武器越多，或者推进器越多，那消耗的就会更快，这时候你就需要根据你自己的设计，调整油箱和能量装置的数量来保证游戏的时候有足够的能量提供，万一打着的时候，没能量了，那就成了任人宰割的鱼肉，多么的尴尬。

说完了整体的，还有官方所提供的各种零件，零件有普通的方块、推进器、能量模块、油箱、防御装置、工厂模块、武器模块，采矿模块，传感器以及电路这十种模块，尤其是电路模块这部分，可能学过数字电路的朋友应该会有所了解，官方在游戏中提供了7中逻辑门，两种开关，四种延时电路等各种元件，玩家可以通过电路可以做出任何的东西来，假以时日，没准儿8位CPU也会被大佬在这个游戏里实现。

还有一点就是，游戏拥有技能点的设定，你需要采集各个星球上的矿物，作为升级武器技能的点数来让你的武器更加强大。

author: {'steamid': '76561197987323362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1606058905}
review:
I last played Nimbatus: Metallic Bio Barrels Collection Simulator some time back, and since then pretty much every one of my gripes has been addressed. I love the new cutscenes which evoke a real 2000's Newgrounds flavour, and the campaign has been expanded to have way more depth to the actual development and progress of your ship, and weapon types/mods. Enjoying the mission selection a lot more because it's no longer "every mission is juggling a bunch of bulky cans of what seems to be extremely sweaty dynamite because sometimes jiggling them used to result in them just blowing the ass off your drone."

Protip: Snipers have massive recoil, so fire backwards for an early replacement for boosters or use them to steer
developer_response:
Hi Izunundara

We have released a new update!
The bio barrel mission has been reworked to be less tedious :D
We also added 2 new mission types, which makes be barrel mission rarer.

Would it be possible that you take another look at the game?

Cheers,
Philomena

review:
For those just interested in gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXfLqyEUp3k

Nimbatus is an incredibly customizable and indepth game of creating ships ("drones"). There is seemingly nothing you CAN'T do. On top of that, the missions force you to inovate. It doesn't seem like there will only be one good or ultimate build that would dominate the game. Each weapon and part has its use. This game is great where its at, and I'm eager to see how it far it goes in the future.

Side note: People are INSANELY creative, and the workshop addition is a great feature.

review:
Klasse Bastelspiel. Durch Logik- und Mechanikbausteine können die verrücktesten Drohnen gebaut werden. Die sich, wenn man will auch mal selbst bis zum Spielabsturz duplizieren oder autonom Missionen erfüllen können. In der Sumo-Arena kann man seine unbewaffneten Kreationen gegeneinander antreten lassen und sehen, wer die verrücktesten Ideen hat.

Natürlich ist das Spiel noch im EA und eine große Missionsvielfalt ist nicht gegeben. Forum und Discord zeigen aber, dass die Entwickler stetig am verbessern sind und auch den Input der Community suchen und beherzigen. 
Aber auch mit den gegebenen Möglichkeiten kann man etliche Stunden verbringen, allein schon durch das Basteln der Drohnen. Es gibt eine gewisse Lernkurve, wenn man gute Drohnen bauen will, aber das sollte bei dieser Art Spiel auch zu erwarten sein. Genug Videos, um sich inspirienren zu lassen gibt es allerdings auch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042863866', 'num_games_owned': 456, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1538951506}
review:
Nimbatus apealed to me instantly. The idea of getting to design your own drone and dig into plannets and develop your drone further and make aditions to where you failed made me almost instantly buy the game. Sadly though, this game was a massive let down.
I understand that it's currently in early access but it felt nothing more than a early access to an early access. Upon starting the game up i realised that Many things like the buttons where just rectangles. They didn't fit the background and just was ugly.
There was no guidence on how to play. I like to explore my games and don't like being hand held but this game had no sort of introduction of any kind. Just click to start then your thrown into building your drone. There was barley any information about each part and what you should value over the other or even if you needed it.
After finally throwing together a drone i decided to play the first mission. Again there was no guidence on how to control your drone. I instantly got stuck inside another ship because the controls are never explained and you have little control anyway.

This game could have a lot of potential but is lacking massivly in basic areas (again no instructions.. no story line no nothing just build a drone and dig i guess?)
I uninstalled and requested from steam a refund. High hopes and will keep an eye out on this game once it's fully released but until then, Is it worth £14? No.
Does it match the trailers? No. Far from.

TL;DR: Don't buy it yet. It has promise but not worth the hassel of going through getting a refund.
developer_response:
Hi mazom

Thank you for your feedback.

While there is a tutorial in the game, many people missed it. We are now working on a new update that makes it more prominent. The tutorial provides information on the most important parts and explains how a drone can be controlled. Controls are designed by the player. 

You are the first person to raise the "ugly UI" point. So if you have any more details on which screens you are talking about, that would be helpful :)

It would also be great to know what kind of game you expected after watching the trailer.

There is indeed currently no story in the game. We'll give you a heads up if that changes. We agree that more world building and story would add a lot of value to the game.

I hope you will take another look at Nimbatus in the future ^^

Cheers,
Philomena
