author: {'steamid': '76561198067608206', 'num_games_owned': 4450, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 3045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2865, 'last_played': 1581781145}
review:
Fantastic and very adictive game for those who enjoy building things. Currently I'd say 95% of the time I'm crafting my drones, and only 5% of the time I'm either playing.

The construction is a little rough currently, not very intuitive at first (although the tutorials help a little), but once you learn the basics, you'll notice how much freedom it gives, and it'll probably drive you nuts with joy.

Most of the stuff are done through trial and error (lots of errors), but the ending result is very satisfying in the long run. Currently, you buld drone for 2 goals: doing missions in planets, or autonomous bots for Sumo Battles.

The game features missions scattered across its galaxies, which usually resolve around very simple tasks: kill hives, collect toxic barrels, destroy snake eggs. What makes it complex is how you do the job, how you build your drone for the task, and the differences between each planet, in terms of gravity, air resistance, planet diameter and enemy force. There're also enviromental factors such as lava on some.

In these planets you'll also be able to mine colored resources, in which you must have appropriate drone setup to collect and storage them, and then deposit them on a ship above your Mothership. These resources are currently used to unlock the Tech Tree for weapon customization, which gives lots of freedom to tailor your own weapons as well.

Now for the sumo battles, it's some sort of asynchronous online PvP: you build a drone with lots of limitation (maximum number of pieces, size, and lots of banned parts), and the main , and are set to face other drones build by players around the world in tiny  circular arenas that get smaller and smaller, and the first drone core to leave the arena loses.

The main deal about sumo fights is that the drones must be autonomous, so noone controls them directly: they must use sensors to coordinate their behavior, and the fights are really quick in general, with lots of possible strategies around drone building for this purpose, and many possible counters.

The best part of it is that the game isn't deterministic, varying very little on lots of variables all the time, so the same battle between two programmer drones can have different outcomes. Every single time! You can have individual fights, participate in tournaments fighting a series of enemies, or even set two of your own drones in a battle. It's really fun to watch and design for it!

The game gives so much freedom that you can actually use a drone to build multiple ships, and even give yourself a local co-op multiplayer if desired. More detailed info here:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1531844785

On top of that, the game already has workshop integration, so you can easily upload your drones for others or download drones to test them.

Anyway, the game has a long road to release, and certainly can use lots of improvements in all areas to speed up drone building, give even more freedom for certain tasks and have more things to do, but it's already a very functional and potentially fun game to sink lots of hours into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111470954', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1543128217}
review:
ミッションを取り入れてステージ制になった「Reassembly」。２D版「Besiege」とも言える。
PV映像でゲーム内容は大体合ってる。
最終的には無尽蔵に作れるドローンを親機で作って、子機ドローンで仕事をするゲーム、みたい。
「回復」の概念はないようなので使い捨てこそ正義なのか？
機体を作るゲームとしては、ブロックの繋ぎ方が独特なのでそこに戸惑うかもしれない。

センサーやAnd・Or・Not・タイマーなどの論理回路が各種取り揃えてある。
が「Gladiabots」のようにAIを作ってドローンを働かせたり、「Reassembly」のように自動搭載のAIで勝手に働いたりとは今の所いかないようなので注意。
子機ドローンが勝手に仕事してくれると思っていたので、そこがガッカリ。２D版「TerraTech」だと思っていたから買ったの！

ミッション中に稼いだ資源を使って「研究」を進める事ができるけど、これアンロック制にする必要あった？

author: {'steamid': '76561197993702204', 'num_games_owned': 956, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2953, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1211, 'last_played': 1654577549}
review:
I really enjoy how the "campaign" doesn't limit you for the sake of limiting you.  You have access to all the blocks at the start and the progression is mainly for unlocking weapon power ups.

I do have a couple complaints, the editor doesn't have area selection or the ability to quickly set key bindings like Besiege.  I wish you could use a connector or strut like Kerbal/Besige.  And finally, I wish there was a toggle'able Splitter/Connector.

This is a great sandbox game and the content is great.  I haven't experienced any bugs either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125203020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1587750111}
review:
the game is so bad and flawed that i cant even write a review otherwise it will be several thousands words long.


EDIT: upon developers request I decided to take out a few minutes and try to describe the problems of this game to the best of my ability.

I want to start by saying I was eager to play this game for a very long time. Ever since I first saw the concept I put it on my wishlist and waited. The idea is very good and interesting since I haven’t seen many games like this and that is a big plus for the developer. The problem lies in execution of those ideas. And I will talk about this in detail later.
The idea that you can make your own space drone where your imagination is the limit, and then use that drone to destroy the planet is awesome at first, only to be ruined by horrible construction mechanics. I feel like the person in charge of making it was thinking “why make it easy when you can make it hard and horrible” (see details below). If you can manage to make something resembling a space drone you are greeted with next problem, one that comes all about 3 seconds after loading the map, your drone might not be good enough for that map you are currently playing meaning you need to quit the game and go back to constructing your drone again to fix the problems you didn’t even know existed. 
My first drone had only 4 blasters, and I thought that was going to be OP only to discover my drone was laughably underpowered and didn’t have enough engines. So I put more guns and more engines on it only to discover that this time I didn’t have enough batteries and fuel to run my drone for more than 10 seconds, back to drawing board. This trial and error went on for a while until I had something that was playable. I finished the first few missions after an hour of pain and agony in the constructor. Next I knew I had to modify my drone again because I wasn’t getting enough resources, so add more resource containers, make your drone even heavier, add more engines, more shields to protect the new parts, oh wait you don’t have enough batteries anymore add that too, oh to many parts on your drone now it is all wobbly… the point I am trying to make is that it is hard to balance your drone and by the point you understand how things work you no longer give a duck and just decide to struggle with half working drone. (Understand that if your drone is not good enough you have to quit the mission and lose all progress just to make the smallest of changes)
Later I was introduced to a different objective, pick up toxic barrels and bring them to the mothership (one where you have to deposit all resources otherwise you will lose them all even though you collected them) only to be confused as to how am I supposed to pick them up. After some confusion I found out there is a magnet that attracts barrels so I put it on my drone and went collection toxicity. Only to find out that if you don’t handle them with care they will explode and destroy your drone making you restart the mission. Now I could fix this problem in the constructor but at this point we have established that I would rather struggle with gameplay that go back to the constructor. 
There are more problems that I will not explain in detail since I value my time instead I will just name them and hope devs understand what I am trying to say.

-	The drone constructing is very limited, as in you can’t copy a part of the ship and set it 
aside, edit it and connect it again or insert a block in between easily (you can do it just not simply)
-	Once you place certain part you don’t get another one automatically attached to your mouse, this is pain in the ass when you have to place 20 something engines and even more blasters
-	Heat seeking mother snake with attachment problems that refuses to let go
-	Blasters having enough recoil to move a planet
-	Jammers are somehow able to effect your engines and render them half as useful 
-	There are a lot of weapon upgrades In this game, have fun choosing only 3
-	Resources in your resource containers don’t count as collected if you choose to leave after completing the mission, instead you have to deposit them first (stupid since your drone, the collector and mothership are all going to spawn in the next mission)
-	Gravity is constant, even though I destroyed the whole planet once just to test this
-	You can’t overlap any parts of the drone even things like logic nodes must have dedicated space.
-	Your view is so zoomed in if you have bigger drone have fun figuring out where that left resource collector is, or rotating the drone. (zoom can’t be controlled)
-	Radar (map) is useless since it is one perfect circle and shows your location relative to the mothership. I doesn’t display any caves, objectives, resources or shape of the planet.
-	Drones center of gravity has to be balanced otherwise drone will rotate itself under the influence of gravity. 
-	Shooting blasters pushes your drone and rotates it (a little bit is fine but you overdid it)
-	If your drone touches the ground with just a corner it will be immobilized. As an extra the drone is just a bit bigger than it is actually shown in screen so you might hit something even though it looks like you should clear it. Also the drone might get stuck in 1 pixel big rock flying in midair, have fun finding it.
-	Lasers don’t have enough range to be enemies fighting weapon, they should be used for mining terrain.
-	You set up your own controls, so if you make a mistake have fun quitting the mission just to change it, instead of just being able to edit small stuff on the fly.
-	Not enough option in settings, no hud options what so ever
-	Music get boring after few hours to the point I started playing youtube in the background, sound is just fine, nothing exceptional or bad about it.


I could go on for a while or be much more detailed but I just can’t be bother with at this point 

I hope the developer asked for my opinion because they genially care about the their costumers and not just to look as if they care and I hope some of these design flaws will be fixed/changed in the future.

Also I would like to point out that I don’t like when a dev hides behind early access badge. Most stay in early access for too long so I lost trust in it and consider the game in early access to be finished product. Because by the time in gets out of it I already experienced everything the game has to offer

With that said I never uninstalled this game and I will give it a second try once it gets a few updates.
I hope this helps.
developer_response:
Hi gamingneeded

A few dozen would be appreciated too!
Especially since you played the game for a couple hours we would be very interested in your opinion.

Cheers,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561197996606723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 795, 'last_played': 1628539843}
review:
You can listen to/watch my review [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8H6Z4JTlDHQ]here.[/url]

I've got a lot of mixed feelings about this game in its current state. A lot of it good, a lot of it bad.

[h1]Good:[/h1]
[list]
[*]The ability to program automated functions with sensors and logic gates is a thing of beauty. I've never felt happier than the time I built a hovering platform that mass-produced fighter craft that followed my cursor and stopped to fire, or the time I figured out how to program a turret to scan and lock onto enemies with a handful of operations.
[*]The construction system is robust, and it's very easy to create a drone that fits what you want to do with minimal fuss. Even then, you'll spend a ton of time tweaking and perfecting a design, seeing what you can get away with and discovering new possibilities through experimentation and inspiration from the Workshop.
[*]I can see the "sumo" mode or other game modes that take away direct control getting a lot of mileage, even if I'm terrible at building them.
[*]Weapon variety is excellent from the jump, though any weapon besides rockets needs some research to get up to par.
[/list]

[h1]Bad:[/h1]
[list]
[*]The camera is zoomed way too far in, especially for the minimum size of drone the developers seem to want you to make. To have a jack-of-all-trades drone that can at least attempt any mission type, you'll need a battery, a fuel tank, three resource tanks, a resource harvester, a weapon, thrusters for going forward and backward, thrusters for turning, and a magnet. Most of those parts are static 2x2 boxes, which means your drone will be eating up a lot of real estate on the screen. Add to that the fact that enemies can aggro and attack you from off screen, and certain missions become a matter of memorizing which enemies are where and blindly firing in their general direction.
[*]There are only three mission types I've encountered so far. One where you have to track down and destroy an enemy transmitter, one where you have to destroy eggs around the planet while avoiding a giant snake, and one where you have to use a magnet to pick up and transport barrels to your resource deposit station. The barrel missions are the worst by far, as enemies can blow the barrels up with only a shot or two, and often do since the barrels usually spawn right on top of them. I can't understand why metal barrels are so fragile, yet do so much damage when destroyed. If you're carrying a barrel and it takes a stray shot from an enemy turret, it can absolutely total your ship. Add to that the fact that enemies have a bit too much health and the best weapon (the rocket launcher) is hilariously inaccurate, and barrel missions end up taking way too long to complete. At one point I couldn't get to 2/3rds of the star chart because every single route was gated behind a barrel mission I had given up on and was trying to find a way around.
[*]The tech tree is an interesting idea hampered by some questionable design choices. Most of the upgrades require blue minerals to research, which I haven't seen any of in the 9 hours I've been playing. This means you're limited to boring stuff like damage upgrades, energy cost reduction, and digging power.
[/list]

[h1]Lingering questions:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Why are there so few mission types?
[*]Why does every planet have to have a mission? Why can't I just go onto a planet for the sole purpose of mining resources?
[*]Why are barrels, resource crates, and mineable resource terrain destructible?
[*]Why do we only have a single shield part, and why is the shield it creates so fragile for its energy cost?
[*]The 3d printer part is amazing, but is it wise to give it, of all things, [b]no energy cost?[/b]
[*]Why is air resistance so heavy on every single planet?
[*]Why does rubbing against a tiny outcropping of rock all but immobilize my drone?
[*]Why are [b]downgrades[/b] in the tech tree at all? And why do I have to research them to unlock certain branches of the tree?
[*]What's the point of plasma and cryo weapons when killing an enemy is easier and faster with kinetic weapons? If there are special interactions I don't know about, can they be signposted better?
[*]Why would I ever use bio weapons?
[/list]

[h1]Suggestions:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Let us zoom out the camera.
[*]Either take the blue resource cost out of some of the tech tree, or spawn it on earlier planets.
[*]Add more mission types -- hell, give us a mining expedition a la Deep Rock Galactic where the whole point is gathering things.
[*]Seriously, zoom out the camera. I can't see a damn thing.
[/list]

In conclusion, Nimbatus feels like a bare bones game tacked onto an excellent base of logic-based drone construction. If you like the idea of pushing a construction system to see what's possible within it, I'd say give it a shot. If you want to spend more time outside of the drone editor than in it, maybe wait on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037809811', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1539101287}
review:
[h1]In Short[/h1]
Nimbatus is a spaceship building game where you have lots of freedom when it comes to building ships.
You can even automate your ships and do all kinds of crazy stuff with the parts you're given. You can do missions with the ships you've built and travel to other galaxies.

[b]🔵Pros[/b]
+A lot of parts to choose from when building ships
+A lot of weapon upgrades
+Possibility to automate your whole ship
+You can download other peoples ships from workshop

[b]🔴Cons[/b]
-You get stuck in invisible spots very often
-There is almost no variety to the missions
-The game heavily relies on you knowing how to build big ships

[h1]🎮In-Depth Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
When you begin the game you start in a galaxy that only has 4 planets in it. You unlock other galaxies in the game by completing these planets. Every planet has their own difficulty rating that is used to unlock other planets, for example, if you need 4 points to unlock the next galaxy you can complete 4 one star planets or you could also complete 1 three star planet and 1 one star planet.
The first thing you have to do while entering a planet is building a ship. The shipbuilding in the game is very complex and difficult. You are given some tutorials in the main menu but they didn't really help me a lot with building a ship that stands a chance against the enemies on the planets. 
So naturally, because I didn't have the slightest clue about how to build a good functioning ship I just decided to go to the workshop and download a ship from there. Once I downloaded the ship I went into the first 1-star planet and played through that. It was pretty easy my mission was to destroy 5 giant hives and the enemies were weak.

I completed another 1-star planet before trying the Space Sumo mode. The space sumo mode requires you to have a totally automated ship to even compete in the game mode. Your ships goal is to push the other ship out of the area so your ship needs powerful thrusters and lasers to keep the enemy still.

And once again I didn't know how to make automated ships so I downloaded one from the workshop and won it easily. I got out of the first galaxy and unlocked 2 more. I struggled with the next two galaxies since they have 2- and 3-star missions which are way harder than 1-star missions. Overall the game's missions don't have a lot of variety. 

They're always about destroying or capturing something the only exception is the sumo arena, but that also is very repetitive since the only thing that will change is your or the enemy's drone. During my playtime, I ended up getting stuck a lot even though there was nothing there which was quite annoying since it could sometimes take me over a minute to get back moving which was quite annoying. I don't know if it's the ship's problem or the game's, but annoying nonetheless.

You can also participate in the sumo arena not only through regular galaxies, but there's a sumo arena at the bottom of your galaxy map as well. In that sumo arena, there is a tournament and training section in the tournament section you can only use automated ships you have built yourself unline the training section so I couldn't get to try the tournament section, but I would imagine it's an online 1v1.

[b]🚀Shipbuilding[/b]
The shipbuilding in this game is very complicated, but on the other hand, you are given a lot of freedom when it comes to building. There is a large variety of armored blocks, batteries, fuel tanks, turrets and all kinds of other parts you can use to build your ship.

The parts that stood out to me the most are the logic parts they are probably not of benefit to people like me who have no idea how coding works, but if you know coding you can make great things with these. The logic parts have gates that are basically the same things you have in coding you have if or not gates, for example, all these kinds of stuff you would find in coding that can be used for automating along with sensors.

Other useful parts for automating and for general use are sensors. There are 6 different sensor types that can be all used for different things, for example, you can use the directional sensor to follow your mouse and automatically rotate your ship so the ship doesn't rotate and is easier to control.

There is a wide variety of weapons available in the game ranging from close-ranged sawblades to high power rocket launchers. You can have your weapons set to follow your cursors or remain fixed in their spot depending on what you want your ship to do. You can also completely automate your turrets to aim at the closest enemy automatically.

You can also create your own weapons in the weapons workshop. There you can select the basic weapon preset and choose from your weapons damage type. There are four damage types in the game and I'll explain them quickly: Kinetic is your standard damage type, Bio is used to terraform planets, Plasma heats up enemies, but does less damage and finally Cryogenic freezes enemies, but once again does less damage.
All of the damage types have different uses so you have to choose what fits your ship the best.

You can also choose from a lot of weapon upgrades in your weapon workshop.
You do need to research them before equipping them on your weapons though and that requires you to gather resources from the planets. You will, of course, find rarer resources from more dangerous planets so your weapons won't get really good with just grinding low-level planets.

There are a lot of other parts in the game that you can use to build your ships, but there's so many I can't talk about them all, but here are a few more you can use to improve your ship: energy shields, magnets, resource collectors, springes, hinges and a lot more.

[b]💰Content & Pricing[/b]
The game costs 17€ and I wouldn't exactly recommend to you if you're just looking to just go in the game and go kill some stuff with huge ships. The charm of the game is clearly the shipbuilding and unless you're interested in learning how every part works and how to utilize them, then this is probably not the game for you.

[h1]Technical Analysis[/h1]

[b]🎥Graphics[/b]
The game's graphics look great. They're mostly some clean cartoon style models and the bullets light up the game really well.

[b]🔩Performance[/b]
For the first 3 hours I played on my first day I had great performance I had almost 200 FPS on 1080p max settings, but for some reason when I launched the game today I constantly had 15 fps which made it hard for me to play the game anymore. Luckily I could go in the ship editor and still have great FPS. (GTX 680, I7-7700K, 16GB DDR4)

[b]🐛Bugs[/b]
I didn't encounter any game-breaking bugs during my playtime.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Nimbatus is a great spaceship building game. There is plenty of stuff to do when it comes to building ships, but the game's missions/game modes are lacking.
I would recommend the game if you're creative, like building stuff and don't mind learning how to utilize all of the parts in the game. The game is still in early access so they will most likely add more interesting missions.

[b]Review based on version 0.5.7[/b]

[b]This copy of the game was received for free for review purposes[/b]

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/23741321/]Follow our curator page,[b] Alexander's Club Curations[/b] if you like and want to see reviews like this one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006758332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1538868129}
review:
I should have known better than to try this game. I got it yesterday and lo: My assignment, due in 30 min, is yet to be complete!

This is another take on sandboxy "make your spaceship" gameplay, the way you place your guns and thrusters will affect all the parameters of your ship. Does it turn on a dime or shuffle around like a caterpillar? Does it blow everything away with a beam of destruction or is it bristling with turrets and fighterbays? 

The gimmick in this game is that youre given a lot of granular design responsibility, you dont just smack a turret on it and call it a day! All the bits and pieces need to be keyed to buttons, certain bits and pieces can be made to "press" buttons for you, for example a Laser-sensor that "detects" everything it touches and "pushes" a button, said button is then hopefully keyed to something else, and so on and on until the input of "Sensor detects!" becomes "Enemy blown up!". This is acomplished by placing modules on your ship that basicly boil down to simple programming, you set up a matrix of "IF"'s and if you did everything correctly your ship will fly and survive.

This is Nimbatus's feature that sets it apart from the rest. Compared to Reassembly where you can slap anything together and the game AI will take care of the rest, building a ship can take even more time, so the fun here is all about trying to build something interesting and then seeing it go up against the world. I spent 800 hours on reassembly but I dont see myself doing quite the same with this game, if only because I prefer the wholesale slaughter of spaceships over the constant logic puzzle of trying to make a ship actually function as intended.


This is an early access review, so this may(will?) change, but as it stands I dont actually like the selection of stuff to actually do with your ship.
Many scenarios pit you against elements that will outright destroy you if you dont have the right kind of build (Fire planet, time for my icebot. Snake Planet, time for my mongoose bot, ETC), so your creative freedoms are rather limited right there. You have the option of creating fixed weapon placements and designing complex weapon logic, but the challenges you face at no point require that you do any of this (Just leave all your weapons un-programmed and kill things by pointing your mouse at them), and there doesnt seem to be an option for pitting your complex designs against someone else's designs, unless you strip all the weapons off.
TL:DR, this game lets you design totally awesome robot spaceships, but there is a dramatic lack of things for you to actually DO with your awesomebots.


You will like this game if: You like programming and planning, setting up and solving logic problems. (Hint, if you watch Robotwars or Robosumo, or if you've ever played around with custom machinery (lego technic maybe?), then this is probably a game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083927079', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1596, 'last_played': 1641508644}
review:
It is quite a masterpiece, this one!

You get to design, fly and program space drones.

There is even a Multi Player component where your creation will do battle in a tournament with drones designed by other players.

It's a lot of fun to optimize the drone for a specific task, and make it work well.

For an Early Access game. it is quite polished I must say, and hard to see why it couldn't be a fully released game at the moment (other than the missing Steam Achievements / Leaderboards.)

The single player mission types are recycled quite a bit from planet to planet, but that's OK.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041737245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1570411079}
review:
I think Nimbatus is an enjoyable game as is, and has a lot of potential for the future. 

Let's begin with the player's first choice; to go into Tutorials immediately, or to go into playing immediately. I did the tutorials first, and I think you should too; if you don't get a sense of how the game works, you'll end up confused and frustrated. That said, this is one of the prime areas I think they should improve; the tutorial is very bare bones, and can leave you floundering around for a little while. I recommend that the devs provide optional example drones, so that a new player can get a concept for what works. This is especially important because of how complex things can be in the game proper- once you've made something janky enough to cover all 4 of those buttons.

When you get into the drone builder outside of the tutorial, you get struck by the intricacy of the game. It may be daunting, but I found myself eager to experiment with what could be done. There are many design philosophies one can have with their drones, whether they want a compact thing with a few select tools, a factory hub polymorph, or a world eater snake designed to frighten other players by the fact you took the time to make it. The many options suits the game well, though as is there's only so many reasons to take advantage of it.

In all, the game suffers from a number of Early Access problems, most notably a shortage of missions. That said, I'm optimistic; I've played over 100 hours of this company's other game, Niche. I came in late, but I've seen how they were willing to [i]completely[/i] change the games mechanics to improve it over the course of its Early Access. as such, I'm confident the developers will listen to the players and make this a truly great game. 






Oh, and Mama Snake is too terrifying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126765060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 686, 'last_played': 1677110491}
review:
Note that this is still in early access:
=============================
TL;DR
Ups: Good Concept. Good mechanics. Can be really fun to create your own drone. PvP with automated drone.
Downs: Not as fun as when it was in beta, Upgrade and progress can be halted by procedural generation.
6/10
=============================
NOTE THAT THERE IS SPOILERS:

The game was fun in beta (befoer the eraly access on Steam), getting random weapons and upgrades as rewards for progression. Just focus on making weird and wonderful drones that fits your imgination.

Now? Nah. Upgrades? You need to spent time digging. Special guns? Nope, just a skill tree now. Progress? Nope, all the remining missions are the ones you dont like ... Fun? Well ...

Excluding the PvP drones, which are still really fun.

Most of the other missions are basically the same thing. The snake eggs are annoying, because they can be quite hard to find in a large planet. So everything else seems .. the same. There is the barrel mission, but there is special place in hell for it later.

Amongst the other missions, (which ae mostly the same thing anyways) there is only one that i hate fromthe bottom of my soul. Perhaps it is because i dont find it interesting, or maybe it really is a stupid mission. I would like the devs to take a serious note.

The barrels, oh god the barrels. To put this simply, you are asked to design a drone with a magnet, in order to pick up 5 barrels to clean up a planet. What they dont tell you is that every barrel is guarded by ITS VERY OWN PERSONAL tower that outputs a large amount of damage, and explodes when you shoot it down. (Who guards interplanetary bio trashwith high tech towers?) These towers are generally placed practically next to the barrels, so have fun picking the barrel up and carrying it back to your mothership ^^. Oh, did i mention that the barrels are destructable? and they explode? and sometimes they explode for no reason? And that while 5 barrels may not seem like a lot, most of the time they only give you around 7 per mission? And that there may or may not be other enemy which may or may not explode which will blow up the barrels if they hit it a couple of time? So its just reset after reset, and hope that the barrels' gurdian angel dont shoot the barrel to ruin your mission every reset.

This will be bearable if you effort is rewarded, but guess what? the only reason you do them is to progress to later stages (like every other stage). You get nothing from doing them. NOTHING, not even resources. Thanks to procedural generation, sometimes, you may be as unlucky as I am. Where all your missions are done except for the barrel missions (I have like 5 of them ...) and every barrel, in each stage, is nearly impossible to pick up. I can kill the enemies and scout out where the barrels are. However, if i do that, the towers will explode with the barrels (because they are touching, not just close to each other, touching), and the mission is a fail. 

Your may think that i am stuck .. but no. I am already on my second run of this game, and the same problem occurs. Its not that it is impossible. No, it is simple not fun after a while (after you created a robot that can finish each type of mission with no problems, and when you try to make something else work it fails miserably) And trying on the literally same mission on different planets just adds to that misery.

Since this is still in early access, I wont grill the game itself, I likse the game, a lot in fact. 
But some of these things, like a single pixel of terrain that cant be removed by a LASER scan. Can completely stop your ship and force a reset. i dont even want to mention the number of times i had to reset because the bloody tower shoots the barrels that are your mission criteria. 

Maybe when the game is officially out, i will review it again. But right now, the game is only about a 6/10 in my book, better than most, but still needs a lot of work.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977820099', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1623531289}
review:
This is what happens when a game misses a key element of gaming - being "fun".

While it's interesting, it's semi-unique and enjoyable from the engineering/programming standpoint, the game lacks the basic concept of actually being fun. 

There's zero, in terms of story to be told and there are no characters to keep you engaged or caring about. "Ok then, there are other game like that, that are quite enjoyable though!" you're thinking, I bet. Other games are like that and I have enjoyed many of them, but many of those games have an overall "character" to them; be it in their design, art work, theme, etc. Nimbatus vehicles, however, are just a bunch of dull two-dimensional blocks with flashy lights that do stuff.

The building is repetative and "monotone"; you simply take similar parts and move them around in similar ways to get the desired effect. You can simple make a square for everything and get the same results as any other ship. There's no reason or incentive to make anything more complex than that. And beyond the same handful of similar "missions", the game gives you no reason to expand your ship building abilities.

It has no unique art style that grabs the eye. It has no meaningful characters to relate to. It has no immersive atmosphere to keep you engaged. Other games have that going for them, this game, though, doesn't.

Best I can say, is that it is to this very niche genre, as Avorion is to it's equally niche genre. They are both games that techncially do everything right, down to the core mechanics, but both are games that lack any real "flare" in terms of their gameplay.

In addition, the game is very "simple" comapred to other titles in its price range. For instance, BeamNG was in the same price range when it first came out, as a tech demo. However, that was a pioneer in soft body physics, never seen before in any other racing/driving game. Nimbatus doesn't pioneer anything new, or add incredible features to an already stable design.

This game would have best been left as a tech demo for a much larger, immersive Adventure/RPG style game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960275516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 782, 'last_played': 1538788563}
review:
I'm giving this a yes mostly because neutral isn't an option. $18 or whatever I paid isn't a lot, this is very close to a $20 game but right now it's more of a $9 game. Whether or not it's worth this price depends on how much you care about the money and how much you'll keep yourself entertained. 

Why? Because the mechanics are really cool and the ship builder is pretty good. You have a ton of possibilities with different ship pieces, including adding logic gates and sensors to automate certain things. The "Sumo Arena" is a cool idea - basically you have to build a ship that controls itself, without any weapons, and you try to see which ship can stay inside a closing circle the longest. Awesome idea, but very lacking in implementation (at least for now). With a few more mechanics it could be a really interesting mode, but it ends up being entertaining for a few minutes and that's about it right now. 

The main quests are fairly boring and repetitive. The planets are visually different but effectively the same. There's not a ton of quest types. The quests are pretty boring. 

So why positive not negative? Because the ship builder is really cool, it's cheap, and it's early access. If you'll have fun with completely overbuilding your ships purely for entertainment you can get some value out of this, but there's not a lot of real "game" here (yet).

review:
As the name implies, this is a game centered around building drones.
This aspect of the game feels fleshed out and is very enjoyable.
Currently, the scenarios get repetative quickly due to lack of variety, but the planets are unique enough to promote replayability. Although, some size variations would be welcome.

I would recommend this to those who enjoy creating things and feel like they would get their money's worth even now.
However, those that are seeking puzzles, combat, and/or exploration, I suggest you hold off and check back at a later date.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055780740', 'num_games_owned': 5600, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 917, 'last_played': 1538656597}
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7871885/]Follow our curator page:[b] OCG-Curations[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

👍 [u]Pros:[/u] 👍
Tons of customization
Pleasant Graphics
Excellent drone building suite
Extensive logic components allow for almost autonomous drones
Weapon lab that allows for lots of control of weaponry

👎 [u]Cons:[/u] 👎
Could use more parts, especially weapons to experiment with
Needs more specialized game modes like sumo to increase drone build style diversity

[h1]Overview[/h1] 
In “Nimbatus”, it is the player’s job to create a drone. This drone will then be used to complete the objective that is on various planets. The only limit to drones is the player’s own skills. Gigantic drones with deployable sentry turrets are just one possibility allowed in the in-depth drone creation suite. Once the player has a drone base, they can add weapons. Weapons can be customized extensively and only further the amount of customization in the game. The graphics are pleasant and the weaponry is the colorful highlight to an otherwise gray world. The sound design isn’t exceptional, but it isn’t terrible either. 

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]

🎮 [u]Gameplay:[/u] 🎮
 
Drone Construction
Drones are the player’s main vehicle. Every drone is made up of a drone core that pieces are built around. If this core is destroyed, then the drone ceases all function. To protect one’s drone, there are various parts that can be attached to it. The first part style is the armor block. These are heavy metal plates that have a lot of health and can take a lot of punishment. To move a player’s drone, they must have thrusters. Thrusters come in a few varieties such as jump thrusters and normal thrusters. Jump thrusters give the player a quick boost of speed while normal thrusters provide constant acceleration. To defend oneself, the player must use weapons. Weapons appear in two main variants: lasers and bullets. Laser are sustained damage but they drain a lot of energy. Bullets also drain energy, but not as much as laser do. To fuel thrusters and weaponry, the player must equip their drone with battery banks and fuel tanks. These supplies can be either large or small, and besides one variant, they recharge if the player doesn’t use them for a while. Two categories cover making a drone semi-autonomous and adding special parts. An example of a special part is the hinge. The hinge is an important piece because it is integral in making mini drones or sentry guns. The parts that make a drone semi-autonomous are sensors and logic parts. Sensors are customizable pieces that will detect various stimuli such as enemies. Logic gates help the player make a drone that can do specialized autonomous functions. Finally, missions will have mineable resources and there is a category with resource tanks and a resource collector.  Weapon parts are the most customizable of any parts.

Weapon Lab
The weapon lab is a feature found in the built in editor. Once selected, the player can create presets. Lasers and bullets can be created with one of four damage types: kinetic, heat, cold, and bio. Kinetic is the most basic type and doesn’t do anything special. Heat will warm up objects and enemies hit by the weapon and will cause them to overheat. Cold will also cease functions of enemies if an enemy doesn’t have a defense against it. Bio is the best damage type to mine planets. Once the player has created a preset, resources collected can be spent on improving the weapon. Increased damage, less energy consumption, and increased attack speed are just a few of the upgrades that can be used. Better weapons are important too, because the main mission type in the game has the player destroying enemies. Part placement is also important.

Part Connection
Parts can’t all be connected to the drone core as it will cause the player’s drone to become unbalanced and difficult to control. Instead, parts must be connected to one another so that balance is maintained and the connection limit isn’t hit. This can be a tricky undertaking that is almost puzzle like in nature as a player tries to maintain the perfect balance. This is also one of the places that could use some quality of life tweaking the most. If parts are connected to a single part and I want to replace that single part, then I have to delete the entire section. This can become frustrating as large chains appear with complex drones. 

Missions
Mission appear in two main varieties: Destruction and Sumo. Destruction missions require the player to build a drone that can survive enemies’ attacks and that can destroy these attacking enemies. It is also helpful if the player includes some resource collection utility on their drone as every planet has resources that can be used in the weapon lab. It is quite fun to build drones for these mission types as they require drones with two vastly different requirements. Sumo mission have the player creating a drone that the player can’t pilot. The drone must be made completely autonomous with sensor input. The drone must then push their opponent outside of an ever shrinking ring. 

⚙ [b]Overall:[/b]⚙
If someone enjoys building crazy vehicles with lots of customization options, then this is the game for them. It has one of the deepest editors for this kind of game, and since the game is in early access it can only get better from here.


📚 [u]Story:[/u] 📚
There isn’t much story in the game. The plot summary appears to be that the player is a drone operator who does odd jobs from the safety of their private space ship. 

🎧 [u]Sound:[/u]🎧
The sound design is average. The music is mainly made up synthesizer beats with a slow tempo. These do add a bit to the overall atmosphere, but I didn’t feel like any moment were made better thanks to the influence of the music. The sound effects for the weapons and thrusters are well recorded.

📺 [u]Graphics:[/u] 📺 
The graphics in the game have a sleek artstyle that delves a bit into the abstract. The game does use a muted color palette which can make it displeasing to look at sometimes. The game becomes fully vibrant once the player begins shooting weaponry. Weapon colors contrast heavily with the backgrounds and drones. Where a planet might be a deep purple or a forest green, lasers are unapologetically neon red. A laser light show occurs that may only be rivaled by tittles like “Beat Hazard”. This makes every battle a spectacle to behold as weaponry from the player and their enemies help to brighten up the bleakness of space. 


This product was reviewed with a key provided by the developer for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025559520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1538708094}
review:
I regret to say that after once you have finished one planet you have essentialy finished them all.  proceduraly generated yes so all planets look different.  but the task is always the same.  shoot something, pick something up, dig a hole, colect 1 of 4 minnerals.  this feels a little to much like Nomans sky without the graphics, though a splash more depth as you can build your own ship.  unfortunatly even that is limited.  making new weapons is just selecting the 1 weapon type they didnt give you by default and adding it to your weapon list.  or taking one of your other weapons and changing the damage type.

that said this game does show the potential to be enjoyable.  however this game is not a $20 game, or even the $15 i bought it at. at least not in its current state.  right now it falls under $4.99-$9.99 while its in early access.  and i suspect at compleation it will be a $14.99 game
developer_response:
Hi neupanda

Thank you for your feedback.
We are currently adding new missions (and will continue to do so over the course of this and next year) to add more variety. We're also looking into inlcuding more progression in the game. If you have some ideas, we're happy to hear them :)

When speaking of weapons, I'd like to add that you can also add a huge variety of upgrades (such as reflective beams, sticky projectiles, etc) which you unlock using collected resources.

Doing Early Access for us means including players' ideas in Nimbatus.
We run a forum where people can vote for new features/desired changes: 
https://strayfawnstudio.com/community/index.php?/forum/4-nimbatus-the-space-drone-constructor/
Of course we also really appreciate if players let us know about bugs. But that is not the main reason for us to release in Early Access. We want to turn Nimbatus into the best game it can and a game that is loved by its players :)

Edit (April 2020): Nimbatus is now finished and will exit Early Access in 3 weeks.
We have added LOTS of new features and content in the past 1.5 years. This of course includes a ton of new missions and planet types to add more variation to the game. Nimbatus now features a survival mode with a small story and difficulty progression.
It would be really great if you could take another look at the game and let us know what you think!

Cheers,
Philomena

review:
You can tell a lot of love went into making this game, and seeing how it's early access I'm sure it'll only Improve

You'll find that each level brings something new to the challenges that you progress through, so you'll have to make entirely new drones for each level. And while most games get repetative as the game goes on, this doesn't seem to have that problem at all. I'll be re-reviewing this as the game gets updated but as of right now it's a 10/10

review:
1.0更新了，但依然没有区域框选或多选，依然需要手动挪动每个方块和调整结构关系。
=====
18年旧评：
2D舰船设计类游戏，类似Reassembly的视角/画面 + Besiege的玩法
很有趣，但是过于早期，尤其编辑器很不友好，改装设计非常不方便（你看宣传片里都是直接拆掉重来的），价格也有点贵，不推荐现在入手

大体玩法就是设计舰船，完成任务（多数都是消灭敌人开采矿物之类的），去到下一个星系，如此往复，貌似是有最终关卡的，但是我还没玩到不知道是怎么个机制

有两个亮点
· 武器有天赋树，可以自定义武器，机枪、火箭、激光、火花，速度、大小、距离什么的都可以通过天赋树调整，设计你喜欢的武器
· 有各种电路逻辑门，理论上你可以设计出一个无人机自行应敌。（开采缺少对应的传感器，无法做到自动）

缺点也很明显
· 编辑器很不方便。每次只能修改一个方块，如果你装了一排炮，要挪个位置，你只能一个一个移动，很麻烦。
· 玩法比较单调重复，Besiege也是这个毛病，你通关了就全靠自己想象力在玩。也有的人说“因为其他人机器造的太好把自己玩的兴趣搞没了”，这个游戏也有创意工坊，自己对号入座吧（

author: {'steamid': '76561198127617898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1538697324}
review:
商品紹介の画像にある通り、好きなパーツを組み合わせてドローンを設計する2Dゲーム。
ドローンの動作設定は自分でかなりカスタマイズできるので、シンプルにも複雑にもできる。
さらに、条件式（XOR、XNORなど）の論理回路を使って自律的にドローンを動かすことも可能。
空母のように、親ドローンから子ドローンを作る機能もある。

Sumoアリーナという対戦システムがあって、他の人が作ったドローンと対戦させることができるが、この場合は自分で操作することは出来ず、完全に自律動作するドローンを作らなければいけない。

EA初期ということもあり、現状では殆どサンドボックスがメインになっている。
ストーリー、ボスバトルなども今後順次追加していく予定らしい。
開発者はユーザーの声を取り入れるのに積極的。
実際、ストリーミング中に私が「マウスカーソルが見づらいので、もっと見やすいのを選択できないか」とコメントしたら「対応リストにいれておく。ありがとう」という趣旨の返事が返ってきた。

日本語対応はしていないが、内容の理解に困ることは殆ど無いと思う。
サンドボックスで色々といじるのが好きな人には楽しめる機能が備わっていると思うが、現状で2,000円の価値があるかどうかは人を選びそうだ。
今後の発展に期待しつつ推奨票を入れておく。

author: {'steamid': '76561197966753233', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1538669238}
review:
Hallo zusammen,
Ich habe das Spiel vor einigen Monaten mal gesehen und habe es auf die Wunschliste gepackt da ich die Art von spielen mag.

Leider hab ich mich damit wirklich vertan, ich habe wirklich gedacht das es richtung Casual/Arcade geht, wenigstens von der Steuerung. Das ist aber nicht der fall, man muss sich wirklich rein fuchsen und logic Gitter erschaffen damit man z.B ein Triebwerk 2 verschiedene Tasten zuordnen kann.
Insgesamt finde ich es frustrierend hier ein Schiff zu bauen, das habe ich mir anders vorgestellt. Das Tutorial ist auch sehr seicht ( es ist ein EA Titel der aber recht komplex ist, ein besseres Tutorial wird sicher nachgereicht aber jetzt grade reicht mir das nicht).

Für alle die gerne Logiknetzwerke aufbauen und basteln wollen ist das Spiel sicher was, ich selber habe dafür nicht die Zeit und den Kopf mich da reinzuarbeiten. Es bereitet mir keinen spaß, habe auch Schiffe von anderen hier getestet die haben sich leicht besser gesteuert aber auch nicht zu meiner Zufriedenheit. Dann kommt auch noch die Gravitation ins Spiel ( was logisch ist bei einem so riesiegen Körper) die dann auch noch nervt, das Schiff lässt sich schon bescheiden steuern und dann kommt noch die Gravitation womit es noch schlimmer wird.

Für alle die schnell spielen wollen und evt Arcade/Casual als Steuerung erwartet haben sollten einen Bogen drum machen.
FÜR DIE, DIE SICH DA REINARBEITEN WOLLEN ist es genau das richtige und man wird sicher VIEL SPASS haben.

PS: Mir tut es auch leid das es eine Negative Review geworden ist, vor allem weil die Entwickler sich mühe gegeben haben aber für alle die , die das mal eben schnell spielen wollen ist es leider nichts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019394853', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 961, 'last_played': 1634183914}
review:
This is a wonderful spacecraft piloting game, or a wonderful programming logic puzzle, or both at the same time. You can build each drone the way you want to. It will control as well as you can build it, It will fly as well as you build it, and it will kill as well as you can build it. The game provides all the tools you need to turn your drone into a fully automatic killing machine. Just start the mission and watch as everything dies.

   The demo was amazing. This game is amazing. 10/10 Ready to buy in its current awesome state.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979941991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1665527021}
review:
If you enjoy building games such as Even Horizon, Starship Constructor, or Reassembly you're sure to enjoy this one!

Though still in early EA, the game manages to hit all the right notes with building complex drones and engaging gameplay.

Play controls are smooth and the keybinds are extremely flexible, (you can set each individual component to a different key if you so desire.) and capacity to create complex creations came as a pleasant surprise, (including several logic gate circuit parts you can add to your drone for diverse functionality,) and the weapons workshop where you can design your own guns is easy to use but still offers plenty of flexibility.

Though I'm only 5 hours in and haven't seen all the game has to offer, so far the procedurally generated galaxies and rewarding gameplay have make this well worth the $20 price tag.

(It's also worth mentioning the devs are very involved with the community and listen to player feedback, something a rarity in the current EA age of abandonware and half finished titles.)

developer_response:
[edit]
Hi Snerpes

We're close to the launch and we're checking old reviews to see if we fixed all problems which got reported.

We added new tutorials, one separate for building and one for how to play the new survival mode.

You still have to build the drone yourself and set the keymappings to your liking, that did not change (we focus on building instead of more arcady action). But we added tutorials to make the learning curve more acceptable. If you play the game again, please let us know if we improved that :)

cheers,
Markus



-------
Hi Snerpes

Please note that the controls are completly built by yourself.
Depending on where you place the thrusters, how you rotate them (using the mouse wheel) and which keys you assign, the drone is controlled differently.
Using a directional sensor, you can even build a drone that follows your mouse cursor!

Please try it out and let me know if this info helped you :)

Cheers,
Philomena

author: {'steamid': '76561198022195583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 403, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1538590178}
review:
It pains me to do this, but... no -- Not unless the game is reworked pretty significantly.

The game itself is incredible, the idea feels like Kerbal Space Program but 2D, and I love that. Unfortunately that's all there is to it. The rest of the gameplay just feels repetitive and shallow, with no real direction or variety in missions.

It's a real shame, because there's such wasted potential here - If the game were multiplayer I genuinely feel like it could be the next Discovery Freelancer, where players can engage in combat, piracy, and trading. I really don't see the devs doing this, so ultimately the gameplay feels pretty shallow with repetitive missions.

It's not a bad game by any means, but it feels like a hell of a lot of wasted potential considering the great foundation.
developer_response:
Hi Ben

Thanks for your feedback.
I feel like it maybe is a bit to early to talk about lost potential, since the game just launch on Early Access and will be further developer over this and next year :)

Talking about multiplayer, we have sumo tournaments and will soon add a racing mode. These are indirect multiplayer modes though, were you let automated drones fight / race against each other.

The new update coming up soon will feature two new missions, and there will be plenty more! We are also looking into adding an "end goal" and a stronger feeling of progression in general. If you have any inputs/ideas we'd love to hear them!

Cheers,
Philomena
